151188420.review:
It took me 20 hours to finish Eastward, which in some respects felt like 10, but in others like 200. Overall I would say I liked it, but there are some flaws that will definitely stop me from ever playing it again.

First of all, the good. Graphics, music, atmosphere, world design and animations are astonishingly fantastic and feel just right throughout the whole game. Most major and some minor characters are so likeable and/or well-written that this alone drove me towards continuing to play for most of the 20 hours. I daresay that if the game had only been a bonding roadtrip of an unlikely father-child relationship it would have been a much stronger game emotionally and pacing-wise. Sam is endlessly adorable and John is a suitable main player character despite never saying a word. As I said, side characters are strong throughout and I had an emotional connection to many of them, especially considering their respective fates.

The Zelda-like gameplay loop, both light puzzle-solving and fighting, was overall solid. The world and story is more linear than one would initially think, with few side quests and even fewer reasons to deviate from the main objective most of the time, as you visit nearly every location in the game anyway and if you go there too early you mostly cannot progress anyway and have to fight enemies twice. Enemy variety is not that exciting that you should go out of your way to find fights.

Story-wise, I am conflicted. I certainly liked the road trip aspect of travelling East and learning new parts of the world and finding new friendships. However, I did not really enjoy the motivation for travelling East or the very gloomy, very tragic consequences that accompanied each and every location. Despite the game desperately trying to portray a "happy ending", it is anything but. Without going too much into spoiler territory, nearly all of the main characters suffer a tragic fate and have to live ([spoiler]or not[/spoiler]) in the post-game world in some fucked up emotional states.

Aside from the story, the game has some pacing issues. On quite a number of occasions the quest progression requires you to walk back and forth between NPCs or locations, looping back to the main path or fighting enemy hordes in gated arenas. The "rule of three" was strong with the designers as many of the more annoying diversions come on groups of three before the story picks up the pace again. There were also a few late-game sections involving stealth, timed traversal puzzles or shifting/changing walls while being chased, all of which were particularly fun to play and more annoying when I had to repeat them due to somewhat arbitrary conditions that did not exist outside of those sections. I prefer games that do not betray their own universe's rules, especially not when it feels like it was made to pad out the game time, as those sections did not add anything to the story. The final dungeon also felt overly long, to be honest, and I actually started to speed past minor enemies whom I had fought until that point all the way.

As I wrote above, I believe the game would have been stronger and more emotionally fulfilling as a pure roadtrip story. The characters were strong enough on their own to carry even a somewhat fluffy story about growing up or bonding between two people (one adult, one child) and the relationships they build along the way. The principal end-of-the-world sci-fi story is more a hindrance and a distraction, and ultimately a betrayal of the bonding story, as the game does [spoiler]not end on a high note for any of the characters[/spoiler], as I already noted. This (and the padding) are the main reason why I won't replay the game.

That being said, I do consider it overall a worthwhile time investment. Even if it was 25% longer than it needed to be, many of those hours were fun to play and experience thanks to John, Sam, Alva, Isabel, William, Daniel and many, many, many other characters. I could have done without the darker and horrific undertones and fates, but maybe that's just me.

148744113.review:
Awe-inspiring aesthetics and a heart warming story of family and friendship. 

The writing can be a bit bland at times and character motivations seem a little... confusing, but the charming co-leads do more than enough to make up for some minor narrative shortcomings. The pacing is a bit slow in places and the game's action doesn't offer much depth.

On the plus side, I've never seen a pixel graphics look this good. It's truly a work of art. I was constantly surprised by the variety of puzzles and never felt tired of using my frying pan and my wits to navigate a wide range of well-designed levels. The ramp up on action at the end is incredible and stuck with me well after finishing the game.

Who will love this game? 
Players who enjoy experiences inspired by traditional JRPGs or narrative-rich titles that don't mind a little more action. Players who want to feel immersed in beautiful and diverse environments. Players who enjoy a wholesome story.

Who will dislike this game?
Players that want a game where the majority of experience is action. Players that want a mature and thought provoking narrative. Players who expect deep role playing options and a variety of play styles. 

Who will hate this game?
A soulless monster.

148114368.review:
The best parts of this game are the art style and the music. Seriously, this music is excellent on its own, Hyperduck Soundworks can do no wrong as far as I'm concerned.

The side characters were funny and most of them were pretty interesting; conversely I think the main characters were pretty weak because they kept making bad decisions to pad out the plot, and were often inconsistent (except for John, who's consistently a non-entity as a VERY silent protagonist). The tone was all over the place; from major tragedy to funny fetch quest to major tragedy to funny sidequest, and the "funny" parts were always way too drawn out. It can't decide what kind of game it wants to be; weird or dark. And that ending was just not satisfying... It just feels like they left too much to speculation.

The gameplay was okay, though attacking was weirdly inconsistent and it has the Breath of the Wild "cooking makes health a joke" problem. Once you have the the ability to easily refill ammo combat is rarely difficult except for figuring out boss patterns, which is fine; I feel like if it was actually hard it'd be really frustrating. Puzzles were rarely hard (except when I was being dumb) but could get a bit repetitive.

Overall, I can't in good conscience recommend the game. Buy the artbook and the OST, look at/listen to those and imagine a good retro game. Unless you're okay going in knowing that the story just isn't, it's just not worth it.

147902401.review:
Charming world and visual style! The vibes of the world are immaculate and well-realized, I loved all the unique character and location designs, and who doesn't love a cooking minigame?

Combat was simple, but still fun. Switching between the two characters and using them together is satisfying! The controls are occasionally clunky, and attacks would sometimes lag on my system, but the difficulty is forgiving enough to keep that from being terribly frustrating. There were a couple boss fights near the end that became frustrating because I didn't understand what I was supposed to do, or the timing window for a simple attack was just a little too small, but those instances weren't many. 

The writing is charming when the characters are bantering, and pretty strong thematically in Chapters 1-5, but I think it falls apart a bit after that. Several threads are left unresolved in those chapters, in a way that's less thought-provoking and more just plain confusing. Eastward is at its absolute best when it's about towns of regular people living out their regular lives, and just not great when it's failing to clearly set up the motivations of its villains. I also have some other small gripes with the writing, but nothing worth spelling out here. Nonetheless, I loved many of the characters (Alva and Isabel, William), and think the game is still worth finishing for the genuinely cool moments sprinkled in at the end. 

I do wish the final area was a little more in service of completionism. Seeing as you can buy pixball tokens there, I was sort of expecting to be able to buy any ingredient there too and fill out my recipe book before moving on, but that was not the case. I do also wish the game would indicate which areas you missed treasure in after you beat the game. Just be aware of all that, if you're the completionist type.

147730964.review:
It's not really a totally bad game, just not very good. But would I recommend it to someone: no, I wouldn't.

I love retro 2D action adventures even though there are only a few worth playing on the PC. Judging from the screenshots, I assumed Eastward could be the game I was waiting for, but after finishing it in ~28h I'm pretty much disappointed. Actually, I was from the very beginning.
Letting aside the odd and mostly annoying music or the few blurry animations in a totally different graphics style, mainly the story and overall game design are a total mess. But also smaller design choices made (at least) half of the time I put in it more of a hassle than fun.

It starts with the dialogs which are badly written, can't be really skipped and seem to take forever. I feel that during the 28h, I tried several hours to skip dialogs while pressing mouse buttons and keys for a million times. Even when you save a game at a fridge (for whatever reason), there is a stupid dialog each and every time. Why make a every little thing such a pain?

While the level graphics are generally good or even great, the character design is very weird and doesn't really fit the tone of the game. Together with generally unfitting music (happy Caribbean music when walking through a cold and dark city), the game feels off most of the time.
Besides, it's very linear game and there is no large world to explore. It's separated into 8 chapters where you can never go back and most of these chapters leave no or little room to explore. There are two chapters with somewhat larger areas, but even there, there is not much to be found except for a chest here and there. Besides, one of the design issues is that you never know if you can get back to a place. I.e. you can't say if you can't open a door or solve a puzzle right now of if you overlooked something and will never be able to come back. This is worsened by the fact that some events and progressions are triggered by just walking somewhere and that there is only one manual save slot per game.

Then there is the fight system and I can't say I liked it. Generally, you need to switch between the two main characters all the time to stun and hit enemies. This permanent switching is just not really fun and when you mastered it, the game punishes you by separating the two characters. Repeatedly. Also, switching bombs and forces doesn't seem to be possible other than by entering the menu. There generally doesn't seem to be a keyboard configuration and the menu navigation is somewhat strange. Again, everything in this game is a bit of a pain.

For whatever reason, there is an embedded super-simplified, unpolished and pretty difficult Gameboy-Style role playing game called "Earth Born" which can be played at some arcade machines (?) in the game or from the "Extras" menu after finishing it. In a nutshell, it seems to be a fully playable mini-RPG where you can use items bought in the main game but due to lack of saving and poor design it's not really worth wasting your time. There's also an embedded slot machine game each time you cook something which influences the status effects of this meal. Again, this is a very weird and really stupid idea.

The game itself is not very hard and all the cooking and buffs wouldn't be really necessary but there are quite a few annoying time based puzzles (especially the time rewind things towards the end) and sequences where you need to flee from "Miasma" etc. under time pressure. Generally, the game doesn't explain most of its mechanisms, i.e. that you must use charged or double/triple charged shots at some points. Which can be super-annoying in boss fights under time pressure. Generally, the game doesn't give you a lot of direction what to do. Sometimes you need to visit certain places to go on with the story but the game doesn't really tell you so.

It's hard to explain, but all in all, with all the cut scenes, lengthy dialogs, places where you couldn't use your weapons, stupid mini games, very small rooms etc., Eastward never really felt like a real "whole" game to me but more like an accumulation of pieces that didn't sum up to a believable and enjoyable game world. This is worsened by the writing which combines annoying pointless dialogs with a convoluted story that seems to be pieced together from different ideas and doesn't really make any sense in the end. The "museum" and "cyberspace" (?) parts towards the end and actually the whole ending show that even the developers didn't really know how to conclude this mess.

In a nutshell, I didn't really enjoy a lot of the 28h I put in this game. I never really wanted to come back to it, actually I put it aside for some months until I decided I must somehow finish it before starting another game. But that alone tells a lot about my enthusiasm to play Eastward.

147623266.review:
great game. the art and music are outstanding and definitly what lead me to buy the game. i got in on sale after having it on my wishlist for ages. 
usually i play games in the life sim genre but the art in this one intrigued me. 

the game has some issues with pacing. i would love to get a asked if i want to continue not after saving but rather before jumping to the next plot point because you can't go back to any area once you left it and triggered the corresponding plot element. and since the game encourages exploration it is rather easy to meet a boss or trigger the next scene when you haven't finished exploring. the world is beautiful and the characters are maybe  bit shallow but fun.

the combat and little puzzles play nicely and kind of remind me of the browser flash games of the early 2010s. it is not too hard but still challenging a bit. up until chapter three i encountered one timed challenge where you had to run from something while defeating monsters and solving small riddles which was by far the hardest part of the game yet and i died multiple times.

the game doesn't really tell you how it works but you get a oment to explre everything new you encounter. it is still intuitive enough to not need a ton of guidance. 
there is game within the game which is also interesting and not neccessary for the plot. you will need to play it for the achievements though. 

right now after playing it for about 10h i would definitly recommend eastward. it is a nice game and worth your time. even if it is just to listen to the music and look at the great pixel art.

I really wanted to like this game. For a brief moment somewhere in the middle I did, then I didn't.  

The game's main negativity is its story, which is all over the place. It wants to be lots of things at once, but fails at being any. 

The pacing is terrible, each chapter is left with an unsatisfying end, and when you're done, youre left confused as what the hell just happened? 

The game would've been leagues better if there was a dedicated writer, or even an editor that went over the script, that is if even there was a script. 

The art style and character and world design is what redeemed the game, And what made me finish it. The characters are endearing, And full of personality when given a chance to show it. The level design is some of the best out there. The pixel art? Gorgeous.

This is one of those games that does not need hyper realistic graphics to become a good game.

Story 9/10: It will start a little slow as the world building progresses, everything becomes engaging and you'll have enough time to be invested on the surroundings and characters. It somehow helps that player keeps on tabs with npcs per certain events and see their reactions.

Sound 9/10: Even though the game have no voice acting, the overall plot was able to deliver emotions even thru just text boxes and character emotions. The bgms exactly goes with the theme and surroundings.

Gameplay 9/10: A simple action battle gameplay with enough roster of variety of weapons and skills to go with every maps. I think it suits the overall catch of the game along with some puzzles to tinker your mind a bit before proceeding. Somehow a bit of strategy is needed but if you are keeping up with weapons and how to use them, a player can breeze thru any enemies with enough foods. Overall good. A big plus as there's even a mini rpg "Earthborn" entirely separate to the game plot but integrated to the characters hobbies and likeness. This brings another challenge and trophy hunters.

Controls 9/10: Everything is snappy and active. The only thing seems to be I am having problem with is the targeting using analog controller especially the baseball mini game or Sam's bubble magic sometimes on some puzzles. It would help maybe to put scrub control button on controller to have a minimal precise targeting. But I still got thru without it so no biggie. An addition would certainly help other players. 
 
Graphics 10/10: The art direction is enough to put the whole game deliver what it needs to show to players. Characters are expressive, environment is beautifully rendered, and the animations are smooth as intended. It helps that the world is colorful and even backgrounds have something moving that make the world looks alive and natural. For the Earthborn, it really catches that old school rpg vibes and challenge. Awesome overall.

Value 10/10: I bought this game on summer sale and what a great deal it is to get this gem. I would recommend this to others for the overflowing value you get out of it. Kudos to Pixpil! Keep it up!

145614370.review:
[h1] Sum of Its Parts, Greater Than Its Whole [/h1]

While trying to articulate my thoughts upon finishing this game, I came upon this review: "As of right now it's one of those games that I enjoy playing in the moment, but have absolutely no desire to return to when I'm away from it." 
This perfectly encapsulates my thoughts on it. There's a reason that I took a year-long break and only moseyed my way on back after committing to clearing my backlog.

There's so many wonderful things about it: the designs, the color palette, the score, the feel of the world, and the puzzles. I cannot rave enough about the designs and how beautiful and charming they are.
But for the main driving force of the story, nothing really lasts long enough to feel satisfying.
If you're a fan of character interactions there's only so much dialogue you get through but being sent along on the next fetch quest. Fan of fetch quests and exploration? Have fun with the segments the game allots to you before you're hurried to next story segment and blocked from the area until next time. 

All this could've been easy to forgive with strong main characters. Sure, a silent and gruff protagonist juxtaposed against an excitable and cheerful young child? Excellent combo, No notes.
But I found myself yearning for moments of our main characters interacting or reacting with each other. Even with a silent protagonist, you can have moments of interiority with them. Especially with a team that makes sprite-work this expressive.

There's a moment in New Dam City where a character presents Sam with a pair of new boots, seeing as she never even had shoes. You have this small moment of John looking abashed, even a little guilty, for not providing this seemingly basic necessity. I was starved for moments like that. But as it is, it mostly feels like John is less a character and more just a big skillet you can use to beat the salt out of enemies.

I keep coming back to its stellar opening cutscene. And I find myself nostalgic for a game that doesn't exist. A game where there are giant sprawling worlds teeming with life, where the where the main duo display open affection for each other in this game that is arguably centered around their bond. I want to play THAT game.

All of this being said, this is a stunning debut for a studio. The sheer scope and love that went into all aspects of the game is plain to see. Though I may have not been the biggest fan of the execution, you would never see me call this game lazy.
6/10

145404027.review:
Eastward is adorable in its presentation and a joy to have played, doing the majority of things well or better, but certain aspects of its presentation hold it back from being truly excellent. Having said that, what it does present is still worthy of the time investment. This is especially so if the considering player is unfamiliar with the genre or is on the younger side.

The areas in which Eastward excels and has shortcomings tend to promote this. The visual and audio presentation is praiseworthy, featuring adorable sprite-work and a charming style that references certain classical Asian landscapes or culture. In some ways it's representative of the insidious Western influence upon it, most clearly noticeable from the recipe variety.
Its overindulgence in these matters is demonstrative of the title's shortcomings, however. Eastward is ultimately the story of Sam, and as such is the primary focus, having many endearing sprites to outwardly and with childlike innocence represent her many different emotions. Her counterpart and silent protector, the guardian that is John conversely has relatively few sprites - appearing rather sparse in comparison.
Likewise, it is charming at first to demonstrate this relationship visually, but in conjunction with the approach to storytelling can become a little tedious. In the small world of the prologue where the stakes are low it matters little should someone with custody of a young and spirited child allow them to make decisions and determine directions in order to learn consequences, but John's lack of intervention during legitimately dangerous scenarios and resolve to be utterly silent, following and being at the whims of a child in times of peril, ultimately go against his character and what he ostensibly stands for. What Eastward does best in my opinion; that representation of youthful innocence, curiosity, and sense of justice that is exemplified by the relationship between the two protagonists can terminate by becoming a flaw of presentation. Eastward makes frequent use of dramatic irony, which is suitable for a pantomime where the only recourse for the audience is to shout in hopes of altering the script, or to realise and gaze through their fingers - unable to look away from the mounting inevitability. But for the protagonists of a video game to do this, characters which the player controls to act out the story, can become tedious and a little annoying when used repeatedly. In an attempt to lower raised tension to provide the player with appropriate respite, the story can often be advanced by very convenient means that the player seemingly has little control over. To bring the aforementioned together, there is one instance where the simple intervention of John, made clear by dramatic irony - a scenario where an innocent child would happily part with something dear and important to aid another, but would not fool a sentient adult, would prevent the aimless setback of the player - all in the name of advancing the plot.

The game-play itself, how the player can and is able to interact with the world is fun, simple, but nothing to write home about. The combat and the puzzles match the same description but exemplify the simple to the point of being a little easy and repetitive, hence why it would be a suitable and enjoyable introduction.

Eastward wears its reference material on its sleeves, which is nostalgic and pleasant as a sign of appreciation for what game before, but can give merit to the argument that Eastward is a little too referential and derivative rather than original. When a work is too much so, it can become a lesser sum of its parts, attempting to replicate and copy from too many sources without excelling in one of its own. It is so in this case, as I may consider greater past titles that excel in Eastwards components. For instance, one may point to Mother 3 and Chrono Trigger for the world, storytelling, and graphical influence, Cross Code for puzzle and game-play elements, and so on.

What makes Eastward captivating would almost be better suited to something akin to a slice of life - where it matters not if characters don't grow as a consequence of their actions, an almost static world where the current representation of characters and their interactions with others and the everyday comings and goings is able to shine more readily.

144953264.review:
[h1]Gameplay: 6/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 10/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 6/10[/h1]

✔️ Very beautiful game with an very solid art direction - it is both very anchored in the traditional pixel art & chiptune aesthetics, and manages to have a very personal and unique style. The intro cinematic is crazy good too, and enjoyable to rewatch once you've played through the game.
✔️ Intriguing and zany worldbuilding.
✔️ The game is overall very complete, with an outstanding attention to detail and self-referencing. There's a lot of minor characters with their own little stories to meet, a few minigames, and it is all very fun to go through.
✔️ Nice enough game feel overall.
✔️ Enjoyable alternation of paces between exploration, narration, combat, and puzzles.
✔️ The cooking minigame is surprisingly entertaining.

💭 The game is pretty linear. Make sure to complete areas before venturing forth too, because it won't let you go back.

❌ While a lot of things about the worldbulding are very enticing, I can't help but feel that the story itself lacks something. In the end it didn't make me feel much despite its clear intention to be pretty emotional. It's probably due to the general tone of the game being very gimmicky and lighthearted, which kinda prevented me from getting very attached to characters. Also got a somewhat "why did I do all this again?" feeling in the end.
❌ While there's an enjoyable variety of gameplay, and the gameflow feels nice overall, the gameplay itself is pretty basic. You kinda just bash stuff with a pan, with not much more to it. I'm caricaturing a bit, but still, I would have enjoyed some more interesting enemy patterns that force you to think your actions through a bit more. There are a few, but they tend to be pretty limited. Part of the issue is that they put an ammo system for all the ranged weapons, which means they couldn't require you to use them in fights, because you could just get stuck if they did.
❌ Aiming is somewhat difficult, especially in combat, and especially when you have to charge an attack. Not a big issue, but can be annoying on the long run.

Overall I do recommend it as a fun little (not so little actually, took me 37 hours to finish) game, with quite a bit of worldbuilding depth, and light but entertaining gameplay. Just don't expect a particularly touching story and you won't be disappointed (and maybe you'll have a good surprise if it works better on you than it did on me).

144520807.review:
When I found this title, i was originally searching for something to fill the nostalgia hole left by the unavailability of the first three games in a series called zenonia, which was a childhood favorite of mine. Wow did this game hit the nail on the head for me. From mechanics, resource economy, art style, right down to the amazingly heartwarming story (promise no spoilers ;)). 
The mechanics, while pretty simple, are very unique for the genre, having two main characters with very different abilities to switch between, which allows for much more dynamic game-play, especially since the combat isn't bogged down by turn-based mechanics, which outside of nostalgic favorites, I'm way too impatient for. The puzzles and time limit areas were simple enough as to not present a severe obstacle to story progression, while also making you think just enough to be interesting most of the time. The game also felt very intuitive, i wasn't slogging through tutorials for every new weapon or bomb type, with there only being small text-banner hints for the new stuff, which let the story/dialogue have a lot of room to breathe and grow. 
The only real criticism I have for the mechanics of the game has to do with the resource economy. The game includes a limited crafting system in the form of cooking, which allows you to make different food items that buff your stats, while also restoring health or providing an overshield to your healthbar. While this isn't all that different from other RPGs, the way to acquire ingredients felt a little lack luster, as outside of the selection of items you could buy at the food shops, the only way to get ingredients was to defeat enemies, and hope that the RNG gods would bless you with a good drop. The Ammo also felt somewhat similar towards the beginning, but by mid game you would probably have collected enough in-game currency to not have to worry about buying refills, and they introduce a time-based refill feature. 
You can probably tell by the previews in the store page, but the art style of the game is gorgeous, while lacking the depth of field of similarly illustrated games like octopath traveler, the highly stylized pixel art design is incredibly endearing, and character design is very unique. There are little to no recycled elements (oustide possibly the dungeon areas, I'd have to go back and really scrutinize) and each character and dungeon just screams with personality. 
My biggest compliment would definitely be to the story, outside of a few points mid-game (which did, by game's end, give more meaning to the ending) everything felt important, and the story didn't feel all over the place. From reading other people's reviews, the most common criticism I see is that the story's pacing is a bit sluggish. I can absolutely see where they're coming from, as I feel the marketing strategy was more focused on the combat and action sequences (which there are plenty of anyway IMO). However, personally, I was very much appreciative of the time I got to spend getting to know the supporting cast of characters, rather than the time spent in menus or trying to read item lore after the fact. The story telling really gave weight exactly where it needed to be in the events leading up to the ending, and really built up the player's emotional connection with the characters. What I will say regarding this, though, is that If you come into the game expecting a quick pixel-art dungeon crawler, then this title will certainly not meet your expectations, it is surprisingly long, and I enjoyed every minute. 
100% would recommend this game, and I'll definitely be coming back to 100% complete in the future.

142935335.review:
Short Version; Eastward is a modern attempt at a *very* linear Legend of Zelda style game that's a bit heavy on dialogue, perhaps excessively so to those that prefer to always be in control. If you look at it like a Young Adult Novel with Gameplay and go in expecting that and the number of times you'll have to sit through plot, it's a really good time.
-----------------

I haven't finished Eastward, but I can tell I'm going to. I absolutely love the game to bits. Despite this, this is a game I wish I could give a "hmmm" to, as far as recommendations go. Loving a game and recommending it to others are two very different things. Yet, I had to get my thoughts out now because it's both a blessing and a head-scratcher to be playing something like this.

I didn't get the game when it first came out because it had a "mostly positive" review rating. I waited until it was on sale and when it have "very positive" for it's reviews of all time. I think the people that don't like the game have their right to not like it, but I also think it's harsh to not recommend it the way they do, like the design is flummoxed or lacks intention. This game is made with a lot of intention, love and care... for mostly better, sometimes worse.

I'm reminded of the frustration people have been having with the latest Legend of Zelda, Tears of the Kingdom. A common complaint I see is the story is vapid, utterly nothing, that it sometimes doesn't even feel like a sequel to the last game because of how so much of the last game's events are just ignored entirely. Meanwhile, you're given no time to actually interact with characters. This is intentional, to give the player as much freedom as possible. A butchered quote I see applied to Miyamoto, master of Nintendo and a man known to stick his fingers in all the games, is he hates games that try to tell him what to feel and instead wants to leave the feeling to the player. To that end, it can sometimes seem the Zelda games don't feel much of anything if you aren't prepared to do a fair bit of legwork to get emotionally invested.

Playing Eastward is like playing a bizzarro reality where the word "Freedom" was forgotten almost entirely when a legend of Zelda game was made, and making you feel a certain was was always the goal. Just as the freedom at the cost of plot isn't a bad thing, neither is plot at the cost freedom. The only issue, I think, is not being told one way or another that this is what you're getting into. It's a mistake a lot of games make, in their attempts to maintain the mystique of being a new world, reality or experience. 

In this game, you take on the role of John, at first, and I do believe you'll be playing him through most of the game. Later, you also play as his adoptive daughter as the two try to survive in this crazy world while Sam has magic powers she doesn't understand and there's people that believe the world above ground is a wasteland. It isn't... until you arrive and perhaps cause the second apocalypse.

Although the writing is simple and quirky on the surface, it uses the minimum amount of words and visuals possible to express it's dense story. More than that, it works hard to make you feel like our two main characters. This is impressive, considering John is a silent protagonist who doesn't look anything like a legendary chosen here. In another game. his sprite could be any NPC's. Here, though, his silent demeanor is a real character trait; he's a man of few words and doesn't like small talk. But something you'll find out quick, if you pay attention, is he's a kind man who cares deeply for same. In this way, the game has its cake and eats it too with how its main character feels; you can project onto John a bit, but ohn will always be John.

Sam is, on the other end, vibrant and loud. She's a kid, a real one. The writing here is spectacular, but if you're the kind of person who doesn't like to be told how you feel, Sam might be annoying. The game attempts to endear you to her through John, as John clearly loves her and wants to do what's best for her. Doesn't matter what you want, though, cause John's gonna take care of her. But hey, at least she takes care of John, too. In a way, it's another Dad simulator, but I'd call it a family simulator.

The writing in the game is superb, and I don't just mean the spoken words. If you're attentive, there's a lot of details you can notice, such as how John's house at the start of the game only has one bed, and how he sleeps sitting up. Sam's a new addition to his life, and John had no question in what was best for her. Likewise, several seeds and questions are expertly planted that are answered later, when you might have forgotten you'd even asked. 

The artstyle is also phenomenal. It's as if Legend of Zelda and Earthbound had a baby, then uncle Fallout came to visit, said the baby was cute, and offered old clothes. The game is charming and quirky, with pixel art made with oodles of love and care. The fact John, who wield's a frying pan like a sword, isn't an ambidextrous sprite and turns like a person and doesn't just flip between two sprites says a lot too that. They want John and Sam to feel like real people down to how they move, and I'd say they succeeded. The pixel work is like the days of the SNES, but we never stopped advancing it. In a word, gorgeous. In another word, schizophrenic, but never unintentionally so. Some bits of the UI and character design feels odd (like how the character portraits for John and Sam are anime as heck, with John having an epic smile and a seemingly out of character determination in his eyes), but it feels intentional. It doesn't clash, but sticks out, like it wants to tell you something. 

The second biggest flaw with the game is the pacing can sometimes be a bit... absurd. I was struck by a feeling of whiplash as John and Sam made it to the second town and after only being there a day, the town's prettiest lady falls for John. At the same time, we've gone from the slight octane of a boss fight and getting to a beautiful new world via what we first thought was a death hole to hazing a grand, slow, peaceful time at this new village. The romance plot feels like a way to get us more attached to this place so leaving will be all the more bitter. It can feel a bit like they were throwing out as many hooks to make sure you bit and became caught up in loving this place. Some things were slow, others fast, all at the same time. Give the game patience, take it with a bag of 50 salt (it'll make sense when you play) and it'll pass, but I can see this as a deal breaker for some and I wouldn't blame them.

Perhaps the biggest flaw with this game was to even be a game in the first place. Maybe it would be better received as a book or a comic. But this wanted to be a game and it had good reasons to be, but not everyone is going to agree with that or buy into it. Control is regularly taken from the player for long cutscenes and characters talking to each other for minutes at a time. It's good dialogue, and if you come in expecting it, it's like playing a visual novel with Legend of Zelda (classic) gameplay. But the dialogue is programmed in a way where skipping it isn't fast. It expects you to be here. If you're here to "play", you may be here for the wrong reasons.

I you come to Eastward, come to feel it and experience it. Don't come to play it like a free roaming game, come to play it like a story that has something to tell you. If you don't want that, play something else. Eastward isn't for everyone, and it's beautiful for being willing to do that.

142682564.review:
What sold it is the finely polished pixel art, specially great sceneries and buildings; dungeons and characters look fine at a lesser extent.; But you won't enjoy the moody and relaxing art so much as you'll be constantly bashing the A button to skip long unnecessary dialogues on the cities, or still bashing the same button over and over to kill most enemies in this tedious and simplistic battle system. 
A solid part of the game is making the character walk at a predetermined speed (slow) through the same scenarios over and over in search for some trivial object or character to end some tedious sidestory (I won't consider these sidequests, as you can't opt out of any of those even as most of them aren't directly related to the main quest).

Soundtrack is nice, but what plays in the background almost all the time is the same - an 8-bit soundtrack that repeats itself for hours.

With this completely linear story there are no choices that could change the plot in the slightest, so what's the point of reading all the excessive dialogue lines? 

There's plenty of save points - all of them useless, as every scenery is an autosaved checkpoint. 

Also there's an useless subway/train - it's there but you'll choose to use it only when the story calls for it, and usually won't have (and won't want) to get back to any point you already have been to.

Surprisingly your character will find some arcade machines with an enjoyable minigame inspired by the first Zelda games.

Bottom line: If you like long tedious storylines interrupted by several pointless sidestories in a game where you can't make any meaningful choices (neither in combat style, in character development or on the storyline), this is for you.

142653565.review:
Now I'm torn about this game. Is it a great game? No. If there was a better rating system in place then I'll give this game a 6 out of 10. What makes it worthwhile play is the aesthetics; the graphics is phenomenal the little details and the movement is all beautifully presented and on top of that is a great soundtrack. Everything hits those 16 bit era feel just right with a modern twist to everything. 

The story starts of intriguing if a bit slow to start but it builds character sadly that story loses focus midway where it shoe horns some weak story beats that dont quite belong. Then we get to the pay off and its a tad underwhelming and somethings are left un answered for but its also slightly heart warming.

So the gameplay is very A link to the Past - lite, you have your dungeons and basic functions of a melee weapon. Along the way you are provided with more weapons but they are never really utilised to any satisfying results. Also the attack can be iffy at times, I dislike how you are stationary when executing an attack and on occasions i was unable to hit the target resulting getting injured. The attacks are very basic to a fault and rather slow in comparison the enemy who tend to be a tad faster. Thankfully the game is very forgiving, if you die you are not sent too far back plus encounters are not too difficult.

The puzzles are on the easy side, very similar to Zelda games and even the chest opening music cues and posing is borrowed from zelda games. I enjoyed the puzzles but nothing too taxing.

Now the games biggest problem is how slow everything moves and that includes the text boxes, which has no way to speed up the dialogues and if you accidentily hit interact with an NPC again u have to sit through the whole ordeal again. And by god there is way too much dialogue, though they are well written it goes on for way longer than nessecary. Even saving the game there is a pointless dialogue box to siv through. At 20 hrs it did feel it did over stay its welcome way before the endgame.

Now why i say i recommend it is because there is huge potential on display here. The game is very similar to Zelda and the story can at times be intriguing and there is heart. I think the graphics and the music alone can draw your attention through to the end but definitely its not a game for everyone.

142589754.review:
Despite some nice audiovisual aesthetics, this game really outstays its welcome and has terrible pacing. 

I went in with an open mind, and found the YA-style writing to be quite pleasant at first. However my goodwill was depleted around the 8-hour mark after sitting through another unskippable cutscene full of "quirky" dialogue that added nothing to the plot, and this only got worse with the emotional moments for characters that hadn't earned my care. 

The thing is, good YA fiction makes its simple points and quickly moves on. This doesn't. Neither the plot nor the gameplay are engaging enough to make up for each other's shortcomings. And for me, the aesthetics are not nearly enough to carry it.

Overall the game is fine. If it appeals to your tastes you will probably enjoy it, but I didn't.

142573138.review: It had every element needed to become masterpiece, but unfortunately it isn't. The enjoyed the game, but the lack of good direction and a half baked story left a sour taste in the end.

142511121.review:
TLDR: its a little rough around the edges, and its no deep narrative, but its a pretty good game. 15-20 hours, a bunch of puzzles, the combat is a bit rough, the cooking mechanic is very hit or miss though you can learn how it works and exploit it for heals. Give it a shot if you have some spare cash, if you like story, you cant go wrong with this.

First, the negatives - The pacing is way off. The start is super slow, and it suddenly ramps up to what it should be. The initial bump is after the first area outside the start, though you will quickly become accustomed to it. 
Most animations, dialogues, and cutscences are not skippable.
It can go from feeling very slow to very rushed in terms of story, particularly towards the very end, though I didnt mind this and felt that it added to your momentum and feeling of urgency.
The story is a little flat at times, though I will touch on this more in the positives. 


And now the good - 
The art direction is GORGEOUS, communicating everything from grungy, cramped tunnels to a wide sprawling forest to more... unconventional spaces. Environment design and character art is stunning, just do not expect the most polished product.
The story is a little bit of a toss up, though I think its more good than bad. It can be a bit hard to get invested if you want action and plot right off the bad. But the initial section, getting into a day in John and Sams lives, helps greatly with immersion. You can get an idea of what they, particularly John, feels about their situation. Sure, it may fall off a little between the middle and the late game, but the resolution feels immensely moving. Generally, the story is usually engaging if not weirdly paced at times. 

Overall - I highly recommend the game. For those who like puzzles, theres plenty, even if they can be tedious. The combat is... rough... but face tanking is a viable strategy if you take a few steps off the linear path to find some health upgrades.

142324838.review:
I've only played this game for about 5 hours (as of writing this review) and I can firmly say that it is one of the most authentic and genuine RPG games that I've played in a long time. So far the game hasn't been too difficult but I've found myself time and time again earnestly caring about Sam and John (the main characters) moreso than anyone else in games that I've recently played. The music is fitting, the sound effects are quaint and nice, and the little animations that characters do are so well crafted and fitting for their characters that you'll see just what it adds to the game.

It's cute, endearing and truly a heartwarming game. There's a lot of lovely things included in the game, a fun little side game, what is turning out to be a heartwarming story (don't read spoilers, some of the reviews mention crying and I hope that happens to me too). 

I can't really put my finger to it but this is probably one of the best games I've played this year (up there with Dredge and Fear and Hunger 2: Termina, a uniquely fascinating delve into RPGs) which truly puts the player into the universe that it's apart of. 

If you're a fan of quirky, cute indie RPGs, buy this, at this point I'd say full price is absolutely worth it, because it's got so much heart that it wears on its sleeve that you'll love it by the end of the game.

142277203.review:
Pros:
- Music is great
- Story is good

Cons:
- The cooking system is probably my least favorite part of the game. It doesn't matter what ingredients you use, if you fail the slot machine you're getting something that does less than a 30 cost energy gel from a vending machine.
- It takes FOREVER to get the first substantial upgrade to the frying pan, and it is your only weapon that doesn't cost ammo.
- The charge animation takes too long on the frying pan, making it really hard to use in combat
- There are exactly enough upgrade materials to upgrade all of your equipment, and there is no backtracking. So if you missed one basic upgrade chip, you're out of luck
- Sometimes NPCs blather on for AGES with no way to skip the conversation (and on that note, there are a LOT of animations and processes that just take too long and aren't skippable)

VERDICT:
It's got some flaws, non-skippable animations and conversations galore, but it's a fun game with a decent story. I'd recommend it.

142135387.review:
Combat is a very large part of the game, yet the combat has less depth than games from 25 years ago. No block, no dodge, no abilities or strategy, just mash X. What's worse is that all the enemies feel the same, and are way tankier than they need to be. There's not enough depth to the combat mechanics for the enemies to feel different from each other, and the enemies in New Dam City for example take 20 hits each to kill. There isn't any skill or anything to it, you just stand there and swing your weapon 20 times, for every individual enemy. 
When you're not fighting repetitive enemies, you're watching weirdly slow cinematics ([b]literally[/b] 3 minutes of the title slowly appearing as you stare at the sky with no way to skip), doing a seemingly endless stream of fetch quests, or reading surprisingly shallow dialogue about nothing particularly interesting or engaging. There was one segment about an NPC [spoiler]falling in love[/spoiler] with the main character, but the main character doesn't talk or even react to anything happening, and this NPC had no character development or backstory. There was no depth to this segment of the story or to either of these characters personalities, so it all just felt awkward. It's like the writer just doesn't quite understand how a bond is formed.
The overall story is also lacking, we aren't actively working towards a big end goal, it's like everything we do is just random and unimportant. I know there's something going on with Sam, and there's obviously some story behind the Miasma, which is [spoiler]this black void thing that seems to be consuming the world[/spoiler], but nobody talks about that. Why am i herding pigs, or cooking meals to impress a casino boss while everybody just acts like there isn't anything more important going on right now that we need to deal with? The game is almost all filler without ever getting to the point or tackling anything important.
Visually, this game is great. The locations are all pretty typical and uninspired, but it's got pretty, well animated pixel art. And Sam is a great character. 141761326.review:
Eastward is a modern take on the action JRGPs of the 16 bit era, and with its stunning graphics, evocative music and cliché but enjoyable plot, it definitely invokes the whimsical magic that had a single-digits me glued to a SNES for hours upon hours, and overall I had a great time with it.  However, there’s a few shortcomings in the gameplay department that hold this back from being that slice of timeless indie-game-heaven-pie that we’ve gotten recently with Deaths Door and Unsighted.  

Overall, Eastward is not too dissimilar to the likes of Secret of Mana, Terraenigma or Illusion of Gaia (what I wouldn’t give for a pixel remaster of those last two); a top-down action JRGP with a simple gameplay loop – you hit a town to talk to some NPCs and solve the odd puzzle to keep the story moving, and then inevitably end up in a Zelda style dungeon with a mix of puzzles (lots of bomb puzzles…) combat and secrets.  

The best thing about the game is undoubtedly is presentation.  The pixel graphics are absolutely phenomenal, both in design and animation, and the vibrant colours made me feel like I was playing an interactive Studio Ghibli film.  The music, also, is absolutely top-notch, with a soundtrack that combines chiptune and analogue synths that really gets my nostalgia muscles pumping.  I also really enjoyed the games cast of familiar yet lovable characters.  In like manner, the game’s plot, while hitting on A LOT of JRGP tropes, was well-written and worth experiencing, notwithstanding a few pacing issues in the middle.  The boss battles were also a real standout for me – although none of them were that challenging, they were well-designed and and the best were almost like puzzle battles in Iconoclasts.

The parts that I felt held Eastward back all come in the gameplay, though.  While the game is clearly doing its best to channel the 16-bit legends of yore, it sometimes feels like it’s a bit too stuck in the past.  While the puzzles are generally very good, the simplistic combat really lets the side down. First, this game really needed a dodge or a block function, and certain enemies will just barrel towards you and there’s little you can do to avoid damage.  And while there’s character switching and multiple weapons, none of it feels like it makes a big enough impact or really changes things up.  This may be due to the lack of much enemy variety and the fact that they never force you to use even half the tools at your disposal.  Its not a deal breaker or anything, but it is noticeable that the combat feels a bit half-baked, especially against the outstanding graphics and sounds. 

In conclusion, I really enjoyed my time with Eastward and found it a journey well worth taking, although you might want to approach with caution if you don’t have an affinity for 16bit RPGS as this is pretty much riding the nostalgia train to the end of the line.  I am interested to see where this dev team go next – if they can bring the gameplay of their next title up to the same lofty standards and the presentation, we might have a classic on our hands.    

EDIT - i became aware that this game was mainly made by 3 devs, which makes this all the more amazing

141701437.review:
Eastward takes you on a whimsical adventure in a post-apocalyptic world. Playing as John and his adopted daughter Sam, you'll explore charming pixel-art landscapes and encounter a cast of lovable characters. The game combines action-adventure gameplay with elements of Zelda and JRPGs.

The world of Eastward is beautifully designed, with vibrant pixel art and attention to detail. The characters have unique personalities and the animations add a ton of charm. The gameplay involves navigating through dungeons, battling enemies, and solving simple puzzles. John does most of the fighting, while Sam's psychic powers come in handy for both combat and puzzles.

The main quest takes around 30 hours to complete, but there are additional secrets and side quests to explore. The game also features a roguelike JRPG game-within-the-game called Earth Born, which is optional but enjoyable.

The standout aspect of Eastward is its world and art style. The pixel art landscapes are creative and filled with life, from bustling cities to serene countryside. The soundtrack, while not standout, complements the visuals well.

The writing is the game's weakest point, with some clichéd lines and drawn-out dialogues. However, the overall story is engaging and there are surprises along the way.

The combat is simple but satisfying, with John's frying pan and Sam's powers adding variety. The puzzles, while not complex, offer some enjoyable challenges. Boss fights are the highlight, requiring strategy and the use of both characters' abilities.

In conclusion, Eastward is a delightful journey with charming characters, beautiful landscapes, and a well-paced story. The gameplay offers a good mix of combat, puzzles, and mini-games. While it has some minor flaws, the game's strengths make it a worthwhile experience.

141013417.review:
⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4 out of 5 stars)

Eastward is a charming game developed by Pixpil that seamlessly blends role-playing, adventure, and puzzle-solving into a single package. The game is heavily inspired by '90s Japanese animation, and it shows through its visually captivating pixel art and atmospheric soundtrack.

From the get-go, the game's graphical style is striking. Pixpil has done an incredible job of bringing a dystopian world to life with vibrant pixel art that breathes personality into every corner of the map. The characters, too, are well designed and expressive, each with their unique quirks and characteristics that make them stand out.

Gameplay-wise, Eastward offers a variety of puzzles and combat scenarios that require strategic thinking and efficient use of your character's abilities. The alternating control between the two protagonists, John and Sam, provides a nice variation in gameplay, as they each have their distinct skillsets.

The game's storytelling and world-building are also a standout, offering a rich narrative that draws players into its lore. The dialogue is well-written and sprinkled with humor, helping to foster an emotional connection between the player and the characters.

However, Eastward does have some minor drawbacks. The pacing can sometimes feel a bit slow, especially in certain sections where the storyline seems to meander. Combat, although engaging, can also feel slightly repetitive after a while.

Despite these minor issues, Eastward stands out as an engaging, atmospheric, and overall delightful game that offers a nostalgic nod to pixel RPGs of the past while offering something new and unique in its presentation and storytelling. Whether you're a fan of classic RPGs or just appreciate good storytelling and beautiful pixel art, Eastward is a journey worth embarking on.

140526528.review:
When I started Eastward I was ready to enjoy some interesting vistas, take on some interesting combat, and learn about the decently large cast of characters. When I finished the game I had to ask myself. Did that resolve the feelings that were created in the first hour or so of game play? When in my head I didn't even know the answer, I had to return to basics. I went through the next few areas of the game (no spoilers here) and for every 10 questions generated by a minor plot point, cool world design, or important character moment, MAYBE 3/10 would be answered in any sort of meaningful way. My disappointment in one minor character actually caused me to stop playing for about a week. 
You might then say, man this guy hates the game. No, no on the contrary, I really really loved it. It has some impressive themes, and makes me FEEL something when I think about it and some of the main characters. While combat isn't difficult per se, it was quite well executed, and I appreciated all the crafted areas in the world. I guess it's BECAUSE I love the characters and the world building so much that I am disappointed in some of the lacking areas of the story. Whether it's entirely dropped plot points, characters with super unsatisfying endings, or the definite paradoxes created by the mere existence of some things in the plot, it makes me ask, why did they make those decisions when crafting the story? However, the world building is so incredible, the music is so gut wrenching and effective, and the characters themselves so powerful, that I can't do anything but recommend this game. In all honesty, I want you to feel the same way I do, I want you to love all that there is to love, and hate all that there is to hate. There aren't that many games like this, regardless of what people might say about game play being similar to other things out there. You'll have to try it out, and love the game, be pissed at it, and listen to the music online. Just like me. 

This game could have used four more chapters MINIMUM, but I'm just happy we got this much. Some people say Eastward 2. I'm not against that, but perhaps I've grown to appreciate the game as is, even with the glaring faults that I genuinely believe exist. There are plot points to finish and things to do in the future's of the characters, but thinking up the epilogue in my head isn't bad either. John, Sam, William and the gang, I wish them well.

140222535.review:
I had doubts before playing and upon finishing, I tried so hard to hold up tears but failed. 

For me, Eastward is a hidden gem. But it's not a perfect game, as of June, 17, 2023, only 16.2% player have finished the game. It has flaws but cannot obscure the splendor of the jade.

The pixel art is utterly beautiful and elegant. Fascinating, I'll put it in this way. From all those places- future city, countryside, cropland field, underground places to grocery stores, pubs, apartment buildings, labs to single rooms, each look different and has its own glamour. The graphic is definitely a highlight, pixel art at its peak, looking fabulous in different times of the day and under various weathers, the light and shadow are executed extremely well.

Playing this game is like watching a road film. Travel to places, sightseeing, new equipment, get to meet new people and know  places, chase your goal while helping them, develop friendship and eventually bid goodbyes. You know you won't stay at one place for too long because you don't belong. Many characters are loveable, the lines are short but straight to the point, be it humorous, sarcasm, and give facts - facts so right at some point it hits me, if I've played this game earlier I'll handle some sad moments better. You'll see ups and downs in this game like real life, witness the greatness of love and faith, then accept that even the best of the best can fail.
This is life.

Puzzle-solving and battle takes 50% of the game, they get a bit annoying in the last 2 chapters when you have to reach a certain point before time runs out, without a checkpoint. But the rest are pretty okay for me, as puzzles are easy and battles can be avoided except for the bosses, you can cook foods with various ingredients like in Zelda games. The rest 50% is walking sim and dialogues, the dungeons are fun to explore as well as the cities, usually containing multiple smaller maps with some treasures, collect them to get more hearts and part for upgrades.

The story is not hard to follow, if you pay attention to dialogues you don't need to pay extra to understand. It's good the game does not keep throwing more questions, it gives many hints and explanations along the way, and tells everything at the end, the story unfolds with good path and speed. At the end even I could foresee the end I still cried, for the sadness and a new hope.

Writing here, a quote pops "If you don't fear life, you should not fear death, as it is just one of them". 
But how to face one you love so much yet you still can't save them?

139786784.review:
**Eastward** is done and dusted. It was actually a fairly lengthy game with a really cool pixel art style and an interesting take on a post apocalyptic setting. You play as two characters, *John*, a mute warrior and *Sam*, a girl he found and has been raising. The story follows their travels as they are first exiled from their town and then fight to stay ahead of and possibly defeat the *Miasma*, a death fog that kills everything it touches. Basically.

The artwork is particularly noteworthy in this game. There is a very real emphasis on hand crafted assets. The level of detail and attention to the use of color and shading makes for a fairly stunning visual experience. Considering how many unique set pieces there are in the game, this is highly impressive.

I enjoyed this game, but it definitely has some misses depending on your preferences as a gamer. 

The combat is fairly representative of top down action RPGs, which works well. The RPG mechanics are centered around upgrading your pack and weapons which can be purchased from vendors with the requisite items/money in your possession; and collecting food and recipes to for buff items, which can be found, cooked, and purchased. Quest progression is mostly linear, and there were only a few quests that were search or map dependent. Fortunately, the map is pretty informative and the levels are pretty straightforward overall. I never got lost.

The story is very, very dialogue heavy, and this is probably where people will make a determination as to whether they enjoy the game or not. The intro and first chapter also move pretty slowly. However, the pacing increases as you progress. The character development, both protagonists and NPCs, is quite well done. Similarly, the story is well thought out. It takes some queues from anime, which I guess is also the source material, but it never becomes too surreal and the ending makes sense.

The final chapters rely heavily on a time loop mechanic, which was fine and contextually sound for the story, but also probably the weakest part of the game, and the time loop puzzles were definitely bordering on annoying.

My total playtime was just under 26 hours. It's a game that is easy to recommend, but with caveats as mentioned above. Solid chance you'll enjoy it, but I could also understand if a person didn't find it to be their thing. It is perfectly Steam Deck compatible, which is always nice to see.

139608084.review: Eastward is very very good, and also very very bad. The world is incredibly detailed, with multiple areas in each of the five main locations that all seem very thought-through and cohesive. These locations are also filled with an almost overwhelming amount of npcs, all of which can be talked to. Most of the npcs have dialog that changes according to the events of the game which gives the sense that they all have little stories you can piece together. Some of them also have side quests that can be accomplished. I really enjoyed all of the npc interactions, but if you're not someone who wants to poke around and learn every detail of a world they can be very irritating. The dialog often is very long and unskippable. There were many times that I accidentally talked to someone I'd already spoken with and had to sit through a minute worth of dialog I'd already read. The pacing of the game is also an issue. The game is very very slow, with many of the main questlines requiring you to sit through a lot of unnecessary cutscenes that don't add anything at all to the story and are sometimes just plain boring. One of the main chapters of the game feels more like a movie where you back and forth between scenes than a game. The combat is also amazing in some ways and awful in others. The core mechanic, which is having two characters and switching between them, works very well both in the combat and the puzzle areas. There are new mechanics introduced through the game that kept this part of the game feeling interesting and novel. However, I played with the keyboard controls and I had a lot of issues. It's impossible to disable the mouse and just use the keyboard, so the only way to aim is to use the mouse. I ended up trying to position the mouse in a specific corner of my screen and then running around trying to keep the enemies to that side of the characters, but I almost stopped playing at the first dungeon because of this. Finally, the story and lore are in my opinion the place where this game excels, and also the greatest flaw. (Very very mild spoilers ahead) The game is constantly providing small details that slowly build up the lore so that it feels like you are personally uncovering an incredible mystery. The whole game seems to be building up to a really really interesting finale where you will finally understand how all of these puzzle pieces fit together. Characters are introduced, and then introduced again, and then cryptic details about their past come to light, and it feels interesting and exciting. The game is intentionally giving you questions about the world and about the characters, and for me, the drive to learn the answers to these questions was the whole reason I continued playing the game. But then at the end of the story, literally nothing is explained. More questions are introduced right up until the end of the game (why a train? why monkeys? why is this character appearing again? Where did that character come from? what happened to that other area? what is the relationship between these two characters? why do these people know your name? how did you get to point a from point b?) but the answers to these questions just don't exist at all. I found the end of this story to be a complete disappointment because of this. I think someone who likes interesting puzzle mechanics will really enjoy parts of this game, but not others. I think someone who really enjoys story-based games will like parts of this game, but not others. I'm not sure if people who like combat will get much out of this game, although I enjoyed the combat since it seems pretty much the same throughout the game. Basically, I'm really not sure who this game is for.

139452926.review:
This is undoubtedly the worst game I've ever read.

"Gameplay":
Eastward isn't a game that you play, rather it is a series of random dialogues with irrelevant characters interspersed with shallow puzzles and sluggish combat sections. Over the course of five hours I'd say there were a total of 6 sections where the game actually allows you to do more than loot random crates and talk to people.Each of these are roughly 15 minutes of awful puzzles designed for room temp IQ morons, and enemies that you'd have to try to die to. 

The game could use more lootable crates to distract me from the lack of things to do, since I searched and found a total of 14 or so boxes to loot over the course of five hours. Switching between characters is fun, but it is almost entirely unnecessary apart from solving puzzles. Cooking is nice, but the game is far too easy for you to need to eat all that often and basically boils down to: Choose ingredients, play the slot machine, and enjoy the cooking music. Didn't play that much of the RPG within the game but from what I did, it was okay. Intentionally awful writing and easy gameplay. There are far too many puzzles with not enough mechanical depth to really challenge players, but they are a nice break from the dialogue.

Combat:
I genuinely liked the first ten minutes of combat. The simple enemies, lack of threat or complexity, and general clunkiness were tolerable. However, it quickly dawned on me that there was nothing to the combat beyond spamming the light attack to stunlock enemies. The heavy attack is a botched idea, since it requires you to first throw a light attack and then hold down the button to perform. There were a total of three "bosses", which to be honest I liked quite a bit. The first two are pretty fun, but the third one is just kinda there and gone. They ranged from pitifully easy to mechanically frustating, but it was at least something to do other than listen to people tell me what random minigame I'd be doing that day.

Story:
The plot of this game is unironically brilliant, 10/10. Things just seem to happen with little rhyme or reason, characters come and go, and it is simultaneously rushed and far too slow. Most of the time you're just running around doing random things for people until the plot decides to actually happen for little to no reason.

You're constantly being interrupted so that you can listen to entirely unrelated people talk about things that have no bearing on the actual plot. Chapter 2 is the worst example I've encountered thus far with a whole scene of character growth for a character we just met, someone who will die two scenes later off-screen. 

The game tries to make me care about the second town so it can set up a tragic backstory, but it seems like John and I are in agreement in not giving a flying fuck about it. On that note, John being a silent protagonist that literally ignores the obviously marked for death love interest was pretty kino, and I found that to be pretty funny. Though I doubt that was intentional in the slightest. Most characters are soulless beyond being "Oh So Quirky", and completely one note.

Sam is awful, just awful. She is the designated mouthpiece for John since he refuses to engage with the bullshit of others. As a result, most of the abhorrent dialogue comes from her or is instigated by her, and I just can't forgive that. Other than that she's generically childlike in all the worst ways.

TLDR;
Shallow gameplay, awful story, and barely even a game at all.

138982789.review:
I absolutely LOVED this game and 100% percent recommend it. 

I'm at an age where free time is scarce so I'll give a game 1 hour or 2 and if it doesn't manage to make me want to play the next day then I'm off to the next one. Needless to say this doesn't happen often, but Eastward was the exception.

Now of course what one person can love another can hate so I'll give a bit more detail on what this game is about and what it isn't about so you can guess if you'll enjoy it.

Some people might see a couple of action shots in the trailer and think this is a combat-focused action RPG and they are gonna be disappointed. The game is primarily narrative-based. The storytelling is it's strongest part. Beautiful scenery, lovable characters, hart-warming story, etc. If you played games like Final Fantasy 9 or Chrono Trigger you know what you can expect in terms of world building and storytelling. The game took me a lot of time because I kept coming back to talk to everyone after every quest to see if they had some new dialogue options. If you are the kind of person who goes "skip, skip, skip" then I'd recommend you "skip" the whole game and play something else.

Now what about the gameplay? It consists mostly of dungeons or designated combat-enabled areas where you fight monsters, solve puzzles, encounter bosses plus a couple mini-games from time to time. While the combat becomes harder and the puzzles more complex in the last hour or so of gameplay, don't expect a Dark Souls. You'll probably be able to beat most bosses the first time which is perfect for this game. Since having to try 20 times to defeat the same boss would completely destroy the narrative pacing. You can avoid cooking food if you want to increase the difficulty a bit. 
Now that doesn't mean the combat/puzzle sections feel like a chore. I've found them to be just long enough to be really enjoyable and they contribute to pushing the story forward.

I really cool detail though is that you can play a game within the game. You can find consoles where you can play a traditional turn-based RPG, together with Amiibo-like gacha. It is a pretty cool short game you can play between quests and it's not just some random game, it's actually [ SPOILERS ]

So that's basically it. If you had the patience to read all the way through here without going "tl;dr" after the first paragraph then you probably will love this game.

138478979.review:
Eastward is a game I feel the devs should be proud of creating, when I first bought the game I looked primarily at the art style and thought "This is going to be a cute fun game I can play casually" and although I was disappointed in that particular regard I was not disappointed in how good the game is, for the short of it I will simply say this, it's a game that deserves a lot of love and if you like games similar to the classic Zelda games gameplay wise but with it's own mechanics and style then you want this for sure dood.

Now for the well deserved long review, Eastward is the story of a rather gruff looking man named John and a girl he found named Sam, oddly enough we only really see that via the intro animation to the game (very fancy lol) but suffice to say you live life with her and eventually things get real exciting real fast and as time goes on it get's pretty dang crazy taking some interesting turns I really wasn't personally expecting in the story having a mix of a silly at times cutesy nature while also being rather dark we'll say dood.

Gameplay as I said plays much like a classic legend of zelda game in terms of movement and melee but it has it's own stuff going on too, I can't reveal too much due to spoilers but a lot of what the players will use will be great in both combat and puzzle solving dood.

Talking about puzzles they got really creative with them even extending them to bosses making for some extra fun battles, they can be quite difficult at that although as long as you aren't too forgetful you usually have a nice amount of things to heal yourself up with so the biggest risk is the fact there's 0 iframes after getting hit, like something will peck you to death quite happily dood. XD 

There are nice amounts of collectables in the game, although some will only be money, others will be important upgrade pieces or more health, honestly it's nice to see a game dev make treasure actually useful rather than the typical here's another useless item you can maybe sell for money you already have too much of kind of thing dood.

There is a mini game you can play along with the main game, it's an old school RPG style game, I didn't bother with it because I was too enamoured with the main game but I did play it and it seems like it's decently in depth, outside you have a gachapon that gives you figures, these give you in mini-game items that will help you progress, the game plays like a typical RPG game, turn based, skills, items used, you can recruit certain members, certain enemies and bosses are icons on the map, saving sucks because it doesn't tell you how to, I think it's the night and day cycle which would have been nice to know before I quit and lost my boss progress which put me off doing more, the gacha's are different in each gachapon machine too, it's decently in depth from what I can tell but just not what I was wanting to play around with personally dood.

There's also a cooking mechanic in the game, you get a variety of items you can use to make various meals that come with some nice effects, my favourite of which being overhealth but you can also get more damage, defence and two other effects, there are quite a lot of recipes at that too, some most certainly better than others, it's a great excuse to actually use money along with buying upgrades and such dood.

Anything to improve? That's a difficult one, for what the game is in itself it does it all right, outside of adding more stuff in general I can't think of any-no wait there is one thing, an area with all the gachapon machines would have been nice, not for me granted but for other players who want to play the mini-game it would have been a mighty boon for a myriad of reasons, otherwise yeah I'm coming up blank on any actual in game problems, they did a great job with the game dood.

Overall? I can't see any reason not to like this game a whole darn lot if not love it, it's got a charm to it, a fun set of characters, an interesting story, it's just right out fun to play and creative, it's decently long too considering I have 24 hours on record and I didn't really touch that mini-game all that much, you really get invested especially in the later chapters, I'd love to see more games with this much heart and soul put into it as these days games feel quite shallow so to speak both in terms of gameplay and story, who needs AAA when you got games like these though I say! I wish the devs well and thank them for a great game and I thank you for reading this all, I hope it helps you decide on whether to buy Eastward or not and that you enjoy it if you do dood. ^-^
