138064513.review: It took a minute for me to really appreciate what Eastward is doing -- or, what I'm getting from it, at least. It does a great job paying homage to the champions of yesteryear, but still builds upon the genre with deeper exploration of what a mini-game can do for the narrative, how to hide sleek and modern effects within a retro palette, or how to serve both escort-mission and tag-team-duo without feeling [i] taxing [/i] . The whole deal is very dense, and if you can take some time and really let it wash over you without playing it with the same intentions as you might another game, the game feels brilliant. It took me a second to find that mindset and let it happen. This might be a unique experience for me, though I hope if someone else finds themselves feeling like you're starting to drudge through it, that they find something helpful in this review.

137001018.review:
I really enjoyed this game. It's definitely a slow burner and for a person like me who doesn't usually get too much into RPG's and interacting with characters, it's deepness was daunting and a bit boring at times. But I feel like that's due to my own preferences and not the game's fault, since dialogue is wonderfully written and the characters are all unique, both in writing and design.

I am a really big fan of the graphics. Anything pixel related and you got me looking. But with the added lighting effects and the motion of the environment and characters, this was a 10/10 in that department. Don't even get me started on variety. Absolutely wonderful, each environment had its own personality and felt lived-in. All effects including water, fog and others were also expertly done. It blended the style of pixel graphics with a refined shader and lighting system that just felt very nice to explore.

Gameplay is accessible, meaning I did not find it challenging in the slightest, but almost all boss fights were extremely engaging. It is a forgiving game, so I would recommend it even if you have 0 experience playing games. I would have liked a bit more challenge and Chapter 8 was definitely a highlight. The regular gameplay loop of exploration and beat-em-up style combat was also very interesting, but a bit repetitive at times. The combat doesn't have a lot of depth to it and you can cheese it very easily, but it was nonetheless fun and enemy types were varied.

The story was very engaging and had a nice rhythm to it. It honestly depends on how you play the game and how much exploring you want to do. At first, mostly due to the achievement popping up, I tried talking with everyone all the time. Although well written, it didn't fit my pacing preference, so I went for a half and half approach. I explored up until the point where I felt I had enough and the game did not disappoint. The writing was also subtle and not too much on the nose. I can compare it to a Pixar or Disney movie, where the basic narrative is there, but you can also read between the lines to get some extra details along the way.

All and all, it's a solid 4/5 and if you are a fan of 2D Pixel Graphic Action Adventure RPG's with an engaging story, you have to try it!

La primera vez que empecé a jugar Eastward me quedé en el tercer capítulo y simplemente seguí con otros juegos sin acordarme de haberlo dejado a medias, hasta que decidí volver a empezarlo y me propuse hablar con absolutamente todos los personajes de la historia, explorar todos los rincones del juego e incluso jugar el minijuego de "Earth Born", cuando los minijuegos no suelen ser ni de lejos algo que me guste en los videojuegos en general.

Me he terminado hoy el juego, con todos los logros completados y unas 35 horas de juego en esta nueva partida más tarde puedo decir que efectivamente, Eastward, es un [u] juegazo [/u]. 

Por si te ha pasado lo mismo que me pasó a mí y te estás replanteando si seguir el juego o no aquí te dejo lo que para mí es lo mejor y lo peor de Eastward.

[b] Lo "bueno" : [/b] 
1. En cada capítulo, sobretodo más adelante en el juego, puede observarse que cada rinconcito de civilización del juego tiene vida propia, los npcs tienen sus rutinas varias del día a día, discuten, se divierten o simplemente están pasando el rato en su lugar preferido. Esto es algo que puede pasar desapercibido para aquellos que solo le importe la historia principal pero he de decir que ver el juego en su totalidad y hablar con todos los personajes que me he ido encontrando ha hecho que tanto el ambiente como la historia de Eastward sean mucho más enriquecedores. [spoiler] ¿Quién más hizo que la chica de Ester City decidiese casarse con su profesor solo por estar nosotros cotilleando? [/spoiler]

2. Nunca pensé que diría esto pero el minijuego de "Earth Born" me ha hecho olvidar a veces incluso que el juego que estaba jugando realmente era Eastward y no un rpg retro, entender más de este minijuego te lleva a comprender mucho del humor de Eastward y sobretodo toma un papel muy importante al final del juego.

3. Hablando del humor en el juego este es algo que te alegra por lo tonto que es o te saca una sonrisa con las chiquilladas de Sam pero Eastward no se olvida de la historia que está contado en nigún momento y el juego está plagado de historias que despertarán diversas emociones tanto buenas como malas pero sobretodo algunas bastante complejas que dan que pensar. Esto hace que conectes más con la historia, con como se sienten los personajes e intentes entender las decisiones que toman algunos de ellos. [spoiler] El personaje de Isabel me dejó pensando sobre si lo que había hecho era un acto de locura por la pérdida o más bien de amor por Alva, en cualquier caso nunca pensé que desarrollarían tanto al personaje y me llevé una grata sorpresa. [/spoiler]

[b] Lo "malo" : [/b] 
1. Es un juego que empieza de manera lenta, la trama va desenvolviéndose a lo largo de los 8 capítulos que tiene y muchas veces te sientes algo perdido ya que no hay realmente un villano como tal en el juego y seguir atento en la trama puede hacerse cuesta arriba. [spoiler] ( algunos dirán que Solomon es el villano o incluso que la verdadera villana es Mother pero para mí ambos fallan en este papel, haciendo que estos personajes me parezcan más complejos de lo que podría verse a primera vista, generando una especie de empatía por lo que luchan que me impide verles como villanos de la historia) [/spoiler]

2. El sistema de combate es relativamente sencillo con varias armas con las que crear tu propia mecánica de combate aunque al principio del juego puede parecer excesivamente simple y aburrido para aquellos que quieran pararse a conseguir algo de sal ( la moneda del juego ) con la que comprar mejoras de la mochila y armas. 

Esto es todo lo que puedo decir sobre Eastward y la verdad es que me alegro de haberme propuesto terminar el juego como es debido ya que sino me hubiese perdido una verdadera joya <3

136779646.review:
I was so exited for this game. I thought that I found a diamond in the rough. The opening cinematic was incredible, the art style looked painstakingly hand crafted, and the characters were all visually distinct from one another. But as I poured hour after hour in this game, my cheery optimism gave way to confusion which gave way to pure hatred. I will try to keep this spoiler free.

Starting with what many seem to think is the biggest flaw of the game: the characters will not stop talking. While I don't think this is what outright killed the game for me, it does contribute to the issue that did. If you are planning to play this, the first thing you should absolutely do is turn dialog speed to high. Even the most mundane events will have entire Greek novels of text to wade through before you are able to play again. There is no skip cut scene button so get ready to click X for 30 minutes while the NPC you decided to talk to runs their mouth off about nothing of interest.

The game play itself is also nothing to write home about. Combat boils down to swinging your frying pan at the foe until it dies or, if it has quite a bit of health, stun it and then hit it to death. Better equipment and abilities don't change up play style at all either. They just have better range or do more damage. Puzzles are also bland and uninspired that just consist of splitting up John and Sam or hitting a bomb across a gap. I never felt challenged by many of the bosses either because whatever damage they did to me I just ate a meal and was back to full health. Some of the later bosses do get a bit harder, but it feels too little too late.

Many little gripes pile up as well. When you try to dodge an attack, Sam who is trailing behind you always takes damage. The Earth Born mini-game that is constantly mentioned to be one of the best video games in the world of Eastward is some of the worst turn based combat I've ever played. You get a bunch of salt (Eastward's currency) whenever you kill enemies but never have a reason to spend it on anything other than more inventory so it just piles up once you have maxed it. The music is alright, but the same songs get played over and over (this one song that plays at heartfelt moments was played something around 30 times in total).

All of these are bad, but what killed the game for me was the story. I wouldn't mind if characters talked nonstop if the entire story between the beginning and end wasn't filler. Entire plot lines and chapters are focused on people who do nothing once they are off screen. It feels like the story is a continual stream of consciousness on what a story should be. This happens and THEN this happens and THEN this happens without building on any characters. What the story should be is this happens THEREFORE this happens THEREFORE this happens. The entire meat of the story is just filler. You can take the first chapter and the last chapter of the game, cut everything else out, and plug in anything else and it would be exactly as cohesive as before.

So if I had to say anything to you if your browsing the reviews to see if you should get this game, I have one word to say to you. Don't.

Here's my thoughts on Eastward and how I bought it.

About 2 years ago I was scrolling through the Nintendo Eshop when I found this interesting little game called Eastward... I was a big fan of Undertale at the time and loved it's art style so Eastward seemed PERFECT! Although after looking through the reviews a lot of people said the frames on switch were pretty awful, so I decided not to buy the game. Move on to 2023 and I now have a Steam Deck, and while on the store found Eastward again. I was unsure at first if I should get it, some reviews said they got bored halfway through or the game was generally not fun, but one thing was for sure, the art style was incredible and that was the reason why I'm now sitting on 7.5 hours playtime after having got the game yesterday... And that's how and why I got Eastward.

My thoughts:

Ok, this game is simply the best pixel art game I have ever played and may ever play. The story, the characters, the puzzles, the fights, the monsters, the graphics, all simply blew me away. This game had me obsessed within the first 10 minutes and that does not often happen. I just want to say do not listen to the reviews that say that this game is boring or too easy or maybe even not fun at all, I guarantee that If you like pixel art, adventure games, and/or Undertale... you will LOVE Eastward.

So what are you waiting for...

GET IT!!

135821699.review:
I lost interest in this game after the casino part and around when the circus part happened. Tried picking it back up a few times but I couldn't.

It's pretty and cute, especially at first, and the in-game arcade minigame is amusing for a while, but I found myself getting less and less interested in the plot & characters as time went on. Eventually I put the game down for a few months, tried picking it up again a couple times, and I'm pretty sure at this point that I'm not interested in finishing it at all. Simply put, I went from feeling this game was charming to feeling that it's just vapid.

Sadly, this follows a pattern I've observed for a few other games published by Chucklefish (Pathway, Wargroove, Halfway). Maybe they should focus on writing shorter and more engaging games which meander a bit less and feel tighter/more satisfying. Of course, I'm not a developer and it's not up to me, and I see that a lot of players were captivated by this game, so it could simply be a matter of taste.

I see that several reviewers criticize the game for being text-heavy / too much dialogue. This is *not* my criticism of the game's dialogue. My criticism is just that it's empty and boring. I love reading and I love games where you read like wayyyyy a lot and I love in-depth textual dialogue. But this is *not* a visual novel and it's *not* got thought-provoking, deep characters and worldbuilding. Instead, it's cute, silly, harmless, and annoying after a while.

I think I started playing this game before I started playing EarthBound - EarthBound is better. Just play that instead.

135638843.review:
Very pretty and enticing pixel artwork, but the gameplay just isn't there, at least not for me.

I played this as a sort of calming palette-cleanser, hoping for just an easy-going pixel-told tale with easy-enough combat and intriguing enough characters.

Instead you have a silent protagonist who people fawn over, a story with nothing but side characters who are only interesting in appearance, and have nothing really useful or funny or lore-building to say, music that's fine until you realize they repeat tracks throughout the game vs. unique tracks per city/area, and a lot of jack-of-all-trades business, master of none.

This game is HEAVILY inspired by EarthBound, which is a great game to be inspired by, sure, and I'm all for that-- but what you have is akin to Las Vegas; homages to great things, but empty husks on the inside. Like everyone else has said-- and you can see for yourself-- the pixel artist did their work in spades. The artwork is magnificent and is the reason I put as much time into this as I did.

...but the story is just arduous, so much dialogue to X your way through, and the small bits of gameplay ranges from easy-as-hell puzzles to frustratingly out-of-place-hard combat, with enemies respawning whenever you backtrack and a timed rhythm game at the end out of nowhere. And there's no difficulty setting, so you're just kinda stuck here. And there's an optional-but-is-everywhere minigame that is nothing but a grindfest akin to Dragon Warrior 1 where you can play an arcade game in the game and progress through that. Another homage, sure, but not a very rewarding one.

Pass on this, sadly. So much great artwork and settings without the writing or game design to back it up.

135272428.review:
Despite its beautiful art, Eastward falls short in several key areas. While the character animations are detailed, the pacing of cutscenes is awkward and the transitions between gameplay segments are jarring. The UI is also cumbersome, making the overall experience more tedious than it should be. The combat, although reminiscent of Zelda, lacks meaningful decisions and feels too simple as a result. Additionally, sound effects seem to be missing in several parts of the game. And finally, the post-processing effects intended to enhance the in-game lighting are a nice touch, but they unfortunately smear dialogue boxes and menus into a discolored mess. 

Playing Eastward has made me appreciate the little things that are normally done well in other games. As someone who is in love with Eastward's Mother 3-like style, I still hesitate to recommend buying it, even on sale. John and Sam’s story is buried under a lot of grime that might not be worth digging through.

134740335.review:
🔵[b] Requires light tinkering [/b]

To fix resolution problem change the "high DPI settings" of the game executable:
- Find the game executable Eastward.exe on your system (manage > browse local files).
- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [✓].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game.

Tested on: OnexPlayer Mini Pro 6800U

After finishing the game on almost 20 hours, i gotta say it's quite an experience.

Visually it's beautiful, some areas had this level of detail i don't see very often on pixels. From the grass and the water to the lighting, along with the soundtrack makes it feel wholesome, warm even. The gameplay is pretty much a 2D Zelda game with 2 characters to control, with their own role in combat and for certain puzzles. It can get frustrating at times, especially when you're lacking recovery items, but it's still relatively easy to get through.

The one thing that gave me mixed feelings is the story itself, but even if i didn't like certain plot points (and characters) it's still a good story to get into. The game is clearly inspired by Earthbound, and the visuals, characters and setting just made me wish a few things went in a different direction.

Still, it's worth it. A very charming game to look at.

All of the character writing allows each character to be distinct without making the character too flat, and they are eccentric enough to be memorable. I just hope that it continues to hold up, but I am so taken aback by how great and cohesive this entire experience has been so far. I can't believe more people haven't been talking about this game. 134169712.review:
Eastward is a stunningly beautiful and captivating game that offers players an immersive and engaging experience. Developed by Pixpil and published by Chucklefish, this game tells the story of a young girl named Sam and an aging miner named John who embark on a journey through a post-apocalyptic world.

The graphics and art style of Eastward are truly breathtaking. The game's pixel art is incredibly detailed and vibrant, and the animations are smooth and fluid. The soundtrack is equally impressive, featuring a mix of atmospheric and upbeat tunes that perfectly complement the game's visual style.

Gameplay in Eastward is a mix of puzzle-solving, exploration, and combat. Players control both Sam and John as they travel through a variety of environments, each with its own unique challenges and obstacles. The puzzles are clever and challenging, and the combat is fast-paced and satisfying.

One of the standout features of Eastward is its storytelling. The game's world is richly detailed, and the characters are all well-developed and memorable. The dialogue is sharp and witty, and the story is both heartwarming and melancholic, with plenty of surprises and emotional moments.

Overall, Eastward is an incredible game that is well worth playing. Its gorgeous visuals, engaging gameplay, and captivating story make it a standout title in the indie gaming scene. Whether you're a fan of action-adventure games or simply appreciate beautiful pixel art and compelling storytelling, Eastward is definitely worth checking out.

133265611.review:
6/10 - great story, tarnished by bad combat and very strict linearity 

Grand narrative with wholesome characters. The story is the main winner here, it’s a (very strict) linear game, and that can be a good and a bad thing. It’s a great thing if you are looking to enjoy a story and find a secret or two along the way. It’s a bad thing when you want to complete the game 100% as it is extremely easy to miss stuff and get locked from areas because you forgot to check every corner after every stage of every single quest just in case you can now go there and have all the necessary tools. If you don’t, you will probably miss out on a lot of stuff – including abilities for the main character ?! 

I enjoyed the story; it was a great ride, and the ending – spoiled only by the unresponsive controls and sluggish character movement – was phenomenal. Yes, the combat is a weird thing in this game; it’s very easy in all but the final stage of the game, where the sluggishness and unresponsiveness become sadly apparent as you must act quickly and precisely. Overall, I say I enjoyed the game and were I not locked out from areas I knew I missed but just could not get to because some guard told me to…. I would bum it up to 9/10 (the combat still sucks mechanically – regardless of the very easy difficulty).

133119146.review:
I adore this game!

Some reviews make comments that the game play is too easy, simple, or repetitive. I do not agree.

The wide array of 'everyday' monsters seen on maps (which change based on which area of the world/map you're in) have different attack styles: ranged, charge and jump away, not getting knocked back when you hit them, exploding on death, shooting bombs, spawning smaller monsters, attacking only when you turn away, mimicking objects, etc. And all their designs are unique, which makes it enjoyable just to observe them from a distance while you figure out how they're gonna come at you. If you get more than one type of monster coming at you, it compounds the difficultly. I do concede that once you learn monster's attack styles it's easier to take them down, but I still couldn't consistently avoid taking damage if I engaged with them, even while traversing maps I'd been in before.

All the characters are engaging, not just main ones. Like the guy [spoiler] with antlers in Potcrock Isle [/spoiler] who serves no purpose other than making comments that show he definitely has a crush on John. Some supporting characters could be predictable in terms of the building blocks of their personalities, but I found it necessary to the course of the story as opposed to unoriginal or annoying. Also, essentially every time a plot event happens all the NPCs have something new to say.

The basis of the major boss battles is 'attack until they falter, strike, rinse, repeat,' but since the nature of how to weaken each boss (whether to use Sam or John, which weapon of theirs to utilize) changes, I didn't find it boring.

Using cooking to make meals instead of having to buy basic, boring, pre-made food/potions was really fun for me, too. I enjoyed collecting all the ingredients and deciding which meal's buffs I liked best. Also, every food (and item) in the game has an amusing/fun/interesting description that makes the experience more unique.

I think when getting this game it's important to know the plot, characters, and world are the bigger part of the game (i.e. more than 50% of the game is focused on those as opposed to battling). If you're someone who enjoys storytelling through experiencing the world, I think you'd like this! Go around and talk to everyone, seriously! And yes, I did get emotional over the ending. Definitely recommend.

Sidenote: only the main story goals show up in your quest log. In [spoiler] New Dam City [/spoiler] (world location) characters will ask you for things or give you hints about things to interact with that you might want to remember :)

132501640.review:
This game is beautiful, the pixel graphics are truly a work of art, and I enjoyed playing through half of the game, after deciding to stop.

The Reason I stopped playing, is the only gripe I have with the game, which is 3 things:
1. The Repetitive Level Designs reminiscent of platformers
2. The Linear Storyline
3. The Overall Difficulty

1. In every section of the game, there will be places where you're in a town, able to talk to residents, and all that, and there was a fair bit of worldbuilding and excitement for the idea of being in an underground village in an abandoned subway. But when you get to the levels inbetween these places, the story is replaced with fast placed hack and slashing, as well as the occasional puzzle and platorming obstacle course. This aspect of the game was a real chore, and detracted from my enjoyment of the game, and upon viewing how much harder the game gets as you pass the level I was on, it just gets even harder, and I was playing on the supposed casual mode, so I was very frustrated. And The Save bot was always preaching to me, and that got very tedious too, like shut up, I'm trying to save here, I don't need to be hear it. All in All, there could've been better deigned transitional levels, it felt less like an open world exploration of a big new world, to being a survival game, mixed with a platformer in 2d, which I wasn't a big fan of.

2. The Linear Storyline locked your path in place, you followed one path, no room to move around and explore. When watching ads and seeing the early artwork on the web places, It looked absolutely excellent, I wanted to see more of the world, and not just slash more enemies, but the path of the game, guided me in only one direction, when I wanted to go in ten. The Developers really missed the boat on this aspect of the game, and they ought to make up for it, buliding an open world rpg in 2d, because with these graphics and mechanics, it would totally work, and I would enjoy playing such a game, in a casual easy mode throughout the game. Multiple Endings, depending on your choices, the story felt more like a generic rpg with sci-fi elements, which could've worked, but all of the game's focus was on the girl, which was very disappointing, because it felt like the whole game was about her, not the cool rugged dude with the beard going on a quest, leaving the safety of the abandoned subways. The game probably would've been way more fun to play if this was about the guy, who's character was far more intriguing and developed, as opposed to the rude little girl that the game insists you're supposed to love and feel bad for, and that's sad to me. I don't care if she's a mutant science experiment who's bratty and stupid, or she has an evil twin part of her conscious, I was not engaged.

3. The Difficulty of the game, as I mentioned, was too hard. While I could've sat down and played the game as intended, and tried to, but by the time i reached chapter 3, I was disengaged. I was going through the motions, and wasn't enjoying the game at all.

Like many games, it looks beautiful, but has too many small problems to be worth playing all the way through.

Though, I could see movies being made in pixel art this way.

132180320.review:
There's some genuinely cool ideas and a solid gameplay loop in this game. Great atmosphere and some of the best pixel art i've seen in years. But it's all a little too derivative. eastward borrows a lot of from zelda and earthbound but brings very little of it's own ideas to the table. it's also far too easy, the combat and puzzles don't require any thought at all. there's some secrets to find but they're trivial to find because of an item you can buy pretty cheaply early on. 

I would say this would at least be fun for a kids game, but i can't recommend it because there is occasional swearing in the dialogue and some of the story elements aren't appropriate for kids.

worst of all is the dialogue. there's just so, so many sequences that break up the gameplay, and they're longwinded and inconsequential. the dialogue isn't clever or well written enough to warrant taking up so much time, it's very dull. the zelda-y dungeon gameplay also gets broken up by a lot of fetch-quest stuff that has you running back and forth in a town area for really no reason at all. this game will waste a lot of your time, and the actual good stuff is not high enough quality to warrant it.

the story also has a moment of hard tonal whiplash after the second chapter that i never really recovered from. truly one of the most poorly-paced stories and worst case of whiplash i've ever seen in a game. it's a shame, because i really liked the character designs and worldbuilding.

132046447.review:
Eastward suffers from one of my biggest problems with indie developers nowdays: Make the game pretty, forget to make it fun.

But it also goes an extra mile by trying to be something that truly didnt need to: Earthbound

And also failing doing it.

Ignoring the obvious praise of the art direction of this game (seriously is real good) the game is basically a slog to play. According to the devs its 30 hours long (it took me 24 hours with like 3 being on a mini game that is more fun than the game itself) which you would mostly spend talking with NPCs, putting bombs to solve easy puzzles and talking to more NPCs for the first 10 hours of the game.

Then after it you would unlock the other mechanic of the game which would add another button to your current putting bomb button. Repeat this for another 10 hours.

While doing this you also get to read the story which, on a basic level, it has a lot of potential with an interesting setting and lore behind but that it crashes by the awful pacing and obvious lack of direction cause at the end of the day, the devs didnt know what to do with their characters.

There are, in my opinion, 6 prominent characters in this game, that you get to know during it just so at the end most of them end up doing nothing. It's a great disrepect for probably one of the 3 interesting aspects of the game.

Speaking of characters, this game could theorically have a rock or a box as the main character and i dont think it would change anything. So much shit happening in this world and in front of his eyes and he doesn't react or act to almost anything. It also doesn't help that his sprite makes him look like the most boring and uninterested person ever.

Then, after 20 hours of slog, you reach the final 2 chapters, which are filled with interesting concepts not only story wise but gameplay wise and you are wondering why wasn't the game cut 10 hours so you could just play this sections earlier.

And at the end of the day, thats the real curprit i mentioned earlier: this game is too big. Too big of a story that wasn't developed well enough. Too big of a game that was basically empty from mechanics up to the last 2 hours.

And too big of a disappointment, cause when you really think about the good parts, you can only think what this game could have been if it wasn't trying to be what it isnt.

I am surprised that I enjoyed this game as much as I did. It's kinda simple, the zelda-esque dungeon sequences are pretty fun but very easy, the combat is very button-mashy. The game is VERY heavy on cutscenes and dialogue(at least for me, I read it's Earthbound-inspired so if you like that game then the cutscenes won't bother you). 

But in spite of all these things, which could potentially be described as flaws, this game has a real heart to it. There's just a weird flow of energy through it which is really engaging. Even the characters are rather typical, but they carry the story really well. 

And the real prize goes to the artists. The sprite work is probably some of the best I've seen, the feel of environments is great, the way they use light and colour combined to create real vibes and feelings of dark caves, bright cities, narrow alleyways. Warm lit torches against cool cave colours. It's really, really effective, it really draws your eye without being distracting. It's the perfect garnish. Really, really beautiful stuff. 

So if that sounds like something you'd like then have at it! The game was really enjoyable. I played it on the Steam Deck and it worked really well, save for some weird phantom button presses in menus - it was like it had switched to default ON rather than default OFF. Easily fixed by just pressing whatever button the game thought you were pressing.

130717898.review:
The main advantage of the game is the graphics. I've always liked pixel graphics in games. And eastward has perhaps the most phenomenal and beautiful graphics that I have ever seen. the sky, nature, cities, everything is so excellent, it’s not for nothing that they have been making it for so long. I was literally mesmerized by the scenery of the game and oh God how good they are.
The story is also important in the game. The plot is very original and immediately introduces you to the course of events with the help of the trailer. The way the story moves, the chapters passed did not leave me indifferent. The game tells and reveals its cards slowly during the game and because of this it begins to seem that plot is developing for a long time. 

Music always adds charm and style to your playing. It is the music that shows us the most intense and calm situations in the game. There are problems with the music. And it's not even about quality, the soundtracks in the game are really good and many of them will be remembered by you. I even added a couple to my spotify. It's more of a lack of them. Many tracks are constantly repeated in the game, especially there were moments when this or certain music did not particularly fit the situation in the game, which created a slight dissonance.
 I was very pleased with the great variety of things during the game. In addition to battles and constant walking around the city, there are cool mini-games. The game tries to keep a balance between battles and quiet moments so as not to get tired of one or the other. Uncomplicated pumping, everything is simple and clear, I would add. And of course how without stuffy levels. Some locations were passed for me with great pleasure, while others just wanted to quickly finish and dump. Well, that's my subjective opinion.

My verdict: Despite some objective disadvantages in the game, I still want to forgive them, because the game is actually very good. It is made with soul and everyone who has played the game, I'm sure noticed it. Eastward is a very underrated game and has potential.

130555063.review:
I held off on buying this game for a long time because of reviews saying the plot got convoluted/repetitive toward the end. Now that I've gotten into it a little, I see what they mean but I think the repetition serves a purpose. I identified strongly with the feeling of everything being okay and idyllic only to have the rug pulled out from you again and again. This game is very effective at distracting you just long enough that you briefly forget the other shoe is going to drop.

I'd also like to note that although the battle is simple, it also keeps you from getting too bogged down. There was a time where I considered myself "good at video games" but that time has passed. I'm an adult who plays maybe twice a week. It's nice to be able to play a game for enjoyment and story purposes rather than grinding through dungeons when I just want to advance the storyline.

I also found that I hardly ever got "lost" or stuck in a stage where I couldn't figure out which area or objective I was supposed to go to next. The whole gameplay experience has felt very well-guided even with the many side quests and distractions here and there. It's rare that a game can deviate that much from the "main" plot without making things overly confusing, but Eastward pulls that off perfectly.

130308529.review:
I purchased Eastward in December 2021 and played it in March 2022. After beating the game in January of 2023, I’m proud of what it offered me each time I played it. The art style inside and outside the game is fun and comforting, adding flair and detail to character and setting designs. John and Sam are a delight to play, and I never questioned why John was mute because it never became a clear-cut issue. Every character John and Sam meet has neat quirks because you spend entire chapters alongside them. That’s without mentioning the dark and foreboding MIASMA enveloping everything the game’s setting contains. The empty black space adds tension to each chapter after exploring the game’s world and NPCs. The game’s antagonist, Mother, drives many of the game’s bosses to try and stop you, culminating with Mother fighting John as the final boss.

As for Eastward’s combat and puzzles, some feel too difficult, whereas others feel too easy. The inconsistency varies depending on the player’s abilities, both with a controller or keyboard and Sam and John’s abilities and weapons. The combat mechanics uses John’s arsenal of a frying pan, a gun, a flamethrower, a cog shooter, and three types of bombs to deal damage and Sam’s small but vital arsenal of telepathy to stop enemies and activate other puzzle elements. However, the puzzles and bosses add a challenge regardless of skill level. It’s especially the case towards the end of the game, bar the final boss if you stock up on food beforehand. There are also a few mini-games to add to the game’s experience. Firstly, it has Earth Born, an entire JRPG inside the game. Secondly, there’s cooking, done via a combination of ingredients, which changes the recipe, and slots, which boosts the health given by the food. It gets a bit tedious after 20+ hours of making more food, but it’s a quaint negative to the experience.

However, Eastward could have been so much bolder than it is. Its focus on the MIASMA and Mother could be more present than it was, especially in the first couple chapters. The dynamic between Isabel and Alva could have the same treatment, as their relationship hints at being more romantic, but the game never goes further. The game has more potential than it offers, but it doesn’t mean it’s a waste. I hope the developers have a second crack at something similar to their first outing because streamlining aspects of the story will heighten the experience and create a beautiful adventure. Not everyone will love this game as I do, but that’s a pitfall I’m willing to live with for a story filled with companionship and the determination to deny the end of the world.

130293772.review: pixel art is gorgeous but theres barely any gameplay and the story is unbearably boring

130243384.review:
A lot of what I'm going to say has already been said by other reviewers. However, there are some specific points which I'd like to bring up, and which are [b] very [/b] spoiler heavy. If you haven't gotten at least half-way through the game, don't read the spoiler-hidden sections.

The visuals are gorgeous, and the character design is generally impressive. I do have problems with some characters/plot points being coded as romantic interests through certain... design choices, but that is a personal preference and by no means a universal complaint (though, I will say, it makes the game less child-friendly than might be guessed at a first glance). There is a strong argument to be made for including discussions of sexuality in games - and I do not want to sound prudish - but at some points it seemed gratuitous. [spoiler] I'm looking at you, Alva steam bath scene, Alva naked spirit visiting Izzy scene, "Morning Glory" vending machine, and sex robots at Coin Palace (which a kid is interested in???) [/spoiler] Again, that is likely just a personal, rather than an objective, complaint.

In terms of the story, I didn't feel like it [b] brought [/b] me anywhere. The stakes seemed highest in the earlier parts of the game, and the consequences of the protagonists' inability to act are felt very early on. However, past that point, the trauma is rarely referenced apart from dream sequences and the occasional sentence or two. [spoiler] For instance, Sam's amnesia after the Miasma attacked Greenberg seemed largely unnecessary beyond giving some justification for Sam remaining chippy after a truly world-shattering event. Jasper is the only character who really communicated the depths of trauma associated with losing loved ones to the Miasma, but he is quickly put back into his comedic role without any more references to any struggles he might be having with readjustment. [/spoiler] There are cute moments, but these become mired down in unnecessary fetch [spoiler] or deliver [/spoiler] quests for a plot which meanders itself gradually towards its conclusion. That is to say, I'm not sure the game effectively balanced the equal realities of life's everyday beauty and the emotional weight of living in a post-apocalyptic [spoiler] and pre-apocalyptic, too, I guess? [/spoiler] world, always on the run.

The music is [b] beautiful [/b] , and I did find myself humming along with it quite happily... for the first few chapters. However, the motifs become predictable and grating after ten hours of game play. Rather than allowing the player to come to their own nuanced evaluations of just how "happy" or "sad" or "tense" a scripted moment is, the game took four-ish dominant themes and superimposed them on dialogue to code the dominant emotion. [spoiler] I am also disappointed that, for the most part, the "Arrogant" song i.e. what plays for the Mayor of Potcrock, for the New Dam City goons, and for other characters, usually corresponds with fatter characters. It works with the Mayor - but then it seems as though most every fat character that is in any way intimidating or antagonistic gets associated with that theme. I would have liked to see some variety. [/spoiler] I would be remiss, however, if I didn't mention that there are some absolute gems of musical composition in this game which do make the game feel alive and really drew me in. [spoiler] Like the theme in Charon, for instance. That song is a banger. [/spoiler]

The game controls well, and has a wide breadth of puzzle content. I actually appreciate the simple combat, and the puzzles were generally engaging enough to keep me interested. There is one section which really frustrated me, [spoiler] the stealth section in Monkollywood ... come to think of it, most of Monkollywood in general, to be honest [/spoiler] but it was short, and so I can't really complain about it too much. With so much variety in terms of puzzle mechanics, tools at the player's disposal, and all of the possible permutations between scenarios, environments, and the weapons, not every single puzzle or section will be everyone's cup of tea; but there is enough to go around for most everyone.

The inclusion of a game-within-a-game originally upset me. However, once I realized it was completely untied to progress in the main game, completely optional, and provides a depth of experience to cute and charming moments scattered throughout the game, I came to appreciate it more. I even ended up beating the base quest, but didn't bother trying to beat the New Game+ which became available after that. If you're a completionist, you're in for a ride, but otherwise its nice, optional and light-hearted fun.

TL;DR Most everything has already been said by other reviewers, both good and bad. In spite of the tone that my review has taken, [b] I would recommend this game for people to play [/b], though I would recommend that you wait for it to go on sale. This is definitely a fun experience, especially for fans of the RPG genre. If you're not a huge RPG fan, this one probably isn't for you.

130236997.review:
Pros:
-Unique setting. Charming and sinister at the same time.
-Beautiful art and music.
-The ability to play both John and Sam works quite well and leads to some satisfying puzzles.
-Extensive optional world building. For example, even minor characters have new conversations every day if you seek them out.
-Most of the combat is a pleasant level of difficulty.
Cons:
-Some sections of the game involve repeated fetch quests in the same city. This does have the advantage of building an attachment to the characters, but it also gets tedious.
-There are a few annoying sections that require precise timing. Especially a certain sword fight that took several tries. It's not fun to suddenly be stuck on a task that's much more difficult than the rest of the game.
-The story leaves some ambiguities.

130166177.review:
First the good stuff:
The environments are beautiful, the character designs are adorable. The monster design... not my cup of tea, but the pixel art is beautifully done even if I don't necessarily like their designs. Music and sound design are both great. That's about it.

Everything else:
Game is so close to being decent, but so far from being good. I picked the game up after hearing from absolutely everyone how amazing it is, and I couldn't disagree more. I couldn't even stomach finishing the game by myself, and had to team up with my S/O to tag team through the last chapter or two just to see if the ending made it any better. It didn't. 

The story is the most disappointing stand-out, as there are so dang many loose ends and unsatisfying conclusions. The devs didn't have much of a story to tell in general, which is fine. There are plenty of great games with very basic stories. The problem is that they just keep tacking things on and not fully explaining or expanding upon them. Many characters are just outright unlikable and confusing, and other characters which I wanted so badly to like just don't quite make it there... and are still confusing as far as where they came from, what their involvement is, etc.
After the final scenes of the game, it just didn't sit right with me that the worst character who is least deserving of a happy ending is the only character who got any closure or positive outcome. 
Then there are the rest of the characters with absolutely no closure, or the most depressing endings imaginable for almost no reason. 
There are plenty of theories online that explain things in a more satisfying way, but these are ultimately just theories, and I can't give the devs credit for fan interpretations of the character's stories. 

Although the game seems to be pretty lighthearted and family-friendly with all the jokey and cringe dialogue, it surprised me by having weirdly adult content throughout. In New Dam City, there's just some like 8-year-old kid who is obsessed with a literal prostitute robot. I don't care if there are going to be adult jokes, but it is surprising/jarring when it comes up in a game that represents as family friendly and goofy in every other way. And... why do they have to specifically drag the child characters into it? Who knows.

Gameplay... it exists. You spend most of the game reading through dialogue and wandering around cities, so the combat and puzzle elements aren't something you'd be playing this game to experience, but they're there. 
The puzzles are okay. Some of them are even pretty fun. Some of them are ruined by how annoying the enemy monsters and hitboxes are. There's also this weird issue with puzzle difficulty scaling. Some of the "hardest"(they're still fairly easy) are at the end of the game as expected, but mixed in with those are some of the easiest and most insulting excuses for puzzles that basically just amount to time wasters. I'm talking the kind of puzzle you would expect to get in a tutorial that just shows you how the mechanics work... yeah THAT kind of puzzle is at the END of the game in the final dungeon.

Combat, though, I have nothing positive to say about it. 
Hit boxes for many enemies are awful. 
Mechanics for many enemies are awful or unreasonably annoying. 
Enemies you wouldn't expect to be tanky (a bird?) are unreasonably healthy. 
Enemies you would expect to be more difficult are pushovers. 
Enemies can go inside walls and float around off cliffs, at times artificially extending combat as they are just farting around outside of your range. 
The character you're not controlling can be hit by things and take damage for you even if you dodged something. That character will also be sought out and attacked by things, so even if you leave them off somewhere they'll be out of the way you can still lose health for whatever is happening over there. 
It is cute to have the other character following you around, but as far as combat it's just another thing to be frustrated about.

Overall, the game is beautiful visually, but the story telling is frustrating at best and the gameplay elements can actively feel like a punishment.

130061004.review:
This game means a lot to me. I can explain some of the reasons why; however, there's also a magical element to this game's world that I can't explain that pulled me in hard. The developers have created something truly beautiful here.

A quick note: I initially played this game on another platform, hence my low playtime at the time of writing this review. I have in fact beaten the entire game, though I haven't yet 100%ed it. I am looking forward to doing so here on Steam.

To break it down, this game is a little bit "Earthbound," a little bit "Zelda," a little bit "Mario & Luigi Superstar Saga," a lotta bit unique, and a gorgeous homage to '90s anime. It plays as a story-heavy, top-down action RPG with puzzles, exploration, 
 hidden treasures/loot, boss battles, and a series of minigames that make up an entire playable "Final Fantasy" style JRPG that tie cleverly into the narrative of the actual game. So, yes, this is kind of two games in one. The gameplay loop is very effective and very satisfying, and there are a ton of cool secrets to sniff out, if that is your thing.

As mentioned, this game leans hard into the narrative. While there is plenty of action and exploration you can engage in, this is a linear game and is a fair amount of dialogue/cutscenes. That may seem like a drag to some players, but the dialogue is well-written and the pacing of the story is spread out just enough to keep you engaged while not giving too much away up front. In this adventure, you play as a rugged, non-verbal miner named John and a young girl named Sam that he discovered in cryogenic sleep while mining. John takes Sam in and cares for her, standing in as a father figure. Much of the game revolves around their relationship with each other and the many colorful characters they meet along their journey, with whom they develop a sort of found family. As the journey progresses, you learn more about Sam's origins and the fate that lies ahead of her, while John fights to protect her from strange, paranormal forces and a society on the brink of collapse. I won't say any more about the story, as it's definitely best to go in with very little expectation--the story is at its best during its most surprising moments. I will say, though, that there is a lot of humor, pain, mystery, and many sincerely touching character moments that make you fall in love with these people and their wild, crumbling world. When the game ended, I was just thinking about it for days after, making new connections and analyzing it. There is a lot to unpack once it's all through.

Aesthetically, the game is stunning. It's presented in detailed, layered pixel art with beautiful modern lighting and weather effects, all supported by a brilliant soundtrack. The sound effects and visual effects are all very satisfying, as well. While the character animation is relatively simple, it does wonders for immersion and for making the characters feel especially alive. Sam, in particular, is almost cartoonishly effervescent to great effect. Each cast member feels unique in the way they are drawn, animated, and written, and the developers take every advantage with putting characters together in many interesting, funny, and sometimes heartbreaking ways throughout the story.

The anime influence is very much worth mentioning, as well. There's an overarching Ghibli vibe that is obvious from the screenshots and trailers, but there is inspiration taken from many great animes of the '90s and even earlier. Some are subtle, some are not. If you're not familiar with that material, you will not feel lost--there's so much standalone charm here that anyone can appreciate. For those that are familiar, the developers have mentioned taking inspiration from "Memories," "Tekkon Kinkreet," "On Your Mark," "Porco Rosso," "Astro Boy," "Angel's Egg," "Cowboy Bebop," "Akira," "Paprika," "Cat Soup," "Metropolis," and more. I'm pretty sure "Gurren Lagann," was a source of inspiration, as well--but that's just a guess. Most of this is just present in tone, style, or story beats; but, eagle-eyed players will notice a few more overt references hidden in the world.

Honestly, this is a very easy recommend. If it looks even remotely interesting to you, I would strongly advise giving it a try. This game means a lot to me, and I hope I can get at least one other person to play it and love it as much as I do. In the meantime, I will look forward to playing through again and seeing what Pixpil does next.

129825871.review:
[h1]I’m starting to understand the “tired of quirky Earthbound RPGs” crowd a little bit more because of Eastward.[/h1]
I should preempt this review with the fact that I usually like these types of games. Before anyone jumps my gun at the Earthbound comparison, I am not the first to make this. Literally, every piece of media coverage and YouTuber that’s picked the game up has called it an “Earthbound-inspired” game. There’s literally an optional half-Earthbound parody called Earthborn you can play. The influences Earthbound has had on Eastward aren’t the slightest bit subtle and I think it comes at the game’s detriment. Something that is going to be extremely prevalent in my writing on this game is that I don’t think Eastward has its own identity. Every part of Eastward plays things so extraordinarily safe and it still falls flat.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2910488535
Let’s lead with the gameplay because it’s the only thing it tries to do to distance itself from its obvious influence, except it takes too much from its other source of inspiration. It plays exactly as if Link’s Awakening had the screen limitation cut out. This wouldn’t normally be a bad thing since not many games play like LA, but Eastward doesn’t experiment that much with this. Aside from a greater focus on ranged weapons. The frying pan is just a reskinned sword. Weapon variety is very limited with access to more weapons being restricted by chapter unlocks. Weapon upgrades are so rare and insignificant to the point that I stopped seeking them out, which didn’t exactly fix the situation either. Enemy variety is fairly small and I think the number of bosses surpasses them. They were all laughably easy considering the frying pan stun locks some of them and the rest you can just spam bullets into. The greatest step with experimentation stems from the Mario & Luigi style partner swapping with silent protagonist John and the actual character on the cover art, Sam. This mechanic is used for some rather slow and simple, but inoffensive puzzle design. There were probably upwards of a hundred puzzles but not one stuck with me. Whack a bomb across the ledge. Pull this switch so John can pass and then pull this one so Sam can follow in pursuit. Spam your energy balls with Sam. I never had to really stop and think about a puzzle. And while it’s much worse for a puzzle to force you to look up a solution, I think it’s a huge problem when both your combat and puzzles are so tediously simple.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2910487705
But oh my god, the writing is easily the most irritating part of Eastward. Most RPGs have fun and interesting scenarios to put you in. Eastward just tries to think of the most entertaining time-waster to keep you occupied until they have to actually continue with the plot. The first chapter of the game starts out fairly interesting. You’re plopped into a town built into an underground subway system with a corrupt mayor that banishes anyone he doesn’t like to the surface. Lots of questions get put into place like: Why is everyone living in a subway system? Why is the surface so scary? The story continues into the second chapter immediately after you’re banished to the terrifying surface. You find a town and then Sam does the dumbest possible action ever and faces zero consequences for it because she conveniently doesn’t remember it. Mild spoilers, but lots of people die! Where do you think the story goes after this point? If you guessed we spend half the game making several meals for a mob boss because of a random bet with no actual established risks, you would be right. Chapter 3 is the definition of filler and it doesn’t get much better with pacing until the final few areas of the game. The main two villains don’t offer much in threat factor or even entertainment. Solomon is the one you’ll primarily be encountering and he’s played off as a joke half the time before becoming an actual problem out of nowhere. The only comedic moment that got me feels unintentional as it involves a one-sided romance story with a silent protagonist that shows zero reciprocation. Several story points and character motivations are very confusing as well. It got to the point where I thought it was just a me issue, but the wiki pages for this game are so barren and discussion on the plot is so divided that I realized it was just how the game was written. I cannot stress this enough, Eastward’s plot is boring at best and frustrating at worst. It doesn’t help that a lot of the tropes I personally despise are very common.

The soundtrack is another one of Eastward’s weakpoints. It’s generally rare that I can’t find a single highlight in the OST for a game, let alone for an RPG. I think my problem with Eastward’s music is how generic it sounds combined with how small it feels when compared to the actual size of the game. Describing what makes something generic is rather difficult, but every musical piece sounds like something I’ve heard before. The battle music sounds like it could be pasted into any other game. The suspenseful encounter music is the exact same. It’s the exact same for every other song. Especially when something joyous happens and the happy song plays. That song gets spammed to oblivion throughout the dialogue dumps. I personally feel that Eastward lacks an identity in its soundtrack and I will never be listening to it again.

The art is something I feel conflicted on as well. It’s mainly the character sprites, the actual background environments look gorgeous. Eastward has a bunch of unique locations that are beautifully put together. I mentioned earlier there’s a town built into an old subway station, but there’s also one built entirely into a singular train! While not nearly as absurd, a city being built entirely on and around a dam with there being class segregation for how high up you live was another neat place. And the human factories were probably the most off-putting locations I’ve seen. The story really wasted the unsettling nature of seeing hundreds of test-tube people tended to by the emotionless breeder bots in those segments. The pixel art for the backgrounds is absolutely stellar and I really like how they incorporate semi-realistic lighting into it. I cannot say the same about how people look in this game. I feel as though too much detail was put into their design. Several characters show off every pore, blemish, wrinkle, foundation, etc. shown off in their sprite. Luckily John and Sam themselves look fine, but there was one moment when Sam opened her mouth really wide that looked really off-putting to me. Characters are also overtly bouncy with their idle animations which isn’t too much of an issue by itself. It’s when that bounciness translates to a lot of the female characters having somewhat exaggerated breast jiggling that it feels distasteful. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2910488084
Performance is something that I can praise Eastward for at least. The game never crashed and there wasn’t a single game-breaking bug. The worst offender I encountered for bugs was some NPCs ignoring the collision of objects during cutscenes, as it appears that their pathing doesn’t always factor in the environment. There were no other technical or visual errors that occurred outside of this. I feel as though this is important to stress as more and more releases are forgetting about the importance of stability. Despite my many blatant problems with Eastward, it is still a polished and complete game.

[b]Overall, I’m placing Eastward as a 4/10. I think lots of Eastward can be expanded upon in either a sequel or the development team’s next work.[/b] I’ve played worse games, but I’ve also played much better games. I cannot recommend Eastward because it doesn’t stand out to me. There was some optional content that I skipped out on as previously mentioned, but I have no desire to check it out currently.

129510335.review:
Not the most engaging combat, but that's about the worst I can say.
Original story, interesting mechanics (that are if anything are simply under-explored, hence the less engaging combat) and adorable characters.
There's another review I saw that said the characters felt empty and hollow.
I reaaally need to stress that that's entirely false from my perspective. Maybe they didn't like the characters, maybe they didn't play enough of the game to actually see more sides of the characters, but I can guarantee you that they're not empty or hollow. The charm of this game comes entirely from its story, characters, and the fact that the main storyline is very easy to follow if you're not looking for all the secrets.
You DO need to progress to get to the good puzzles, and you DO need to actively search for the secrets to be able to find the challenging puzzles... But all that tells me is that they wanted anyone to be able to complete the story. You don't need to be great at the game to beat it, but you will need to learn how to use the mechanics to your advantage if you want to find everything.
Severely underrated, incredibly heartwarming, and undeniably original in its setting and story.
If you NEED good combat to enjoy a game, maybe don't play this one, but if you're able to accept a game for what it is, and not what you want it to be, give it a shot... I promise you you'll find something about the game that you like.

Combat definitely feels like it wasn't fleshed out enough, but as I said, that's the worst I can say about the game.

129049426.review:
I've just got to say, that whoever did the pixel art for this game - they really earned their paycheck. Nearly every NPC looks unique and detailed, even ones that serve zero purpose other than just dialogue. It is seriously impressive - unique idle and walking animations that all play up to their designs. I loved it. The environments are also a treat, with so much life and care and personality put into every new area you visit. If there was any recycling of assets, they were hidden well enough to where I never noticed.

The gameplay, however, is extremely simple... a lot of the time, it just boils down to spamming the X button while enemies are against a wall. Bosses, while visually stunning, don't get too interesting either (with a few exceptions, of course, but most of them have that standard "hit him when vulnerable to get to the next phase out of three" thing going on.) I think it was around Chapter 5 where I stopped going out of my way to find weapon upgrade parts in the world - why bother when the game is this simple and easy?

The story, along with the game's visuals, kept me playing until the end. The characters especially are memorable and fun. The game takes the MOTHER 3 approach (one of the many, many things Eastward borrows from it) whereupon after major story beats, character dialogue changes all across the map - I found myself revisiting areas I was only required to visit once just so I could talk to the NPCs and find new dialogue. I love it when games do this, and there is even a fast travel option to facilitate it. 

The story does meander quite a lot, though, with tons of dialogue and cutscenes that... really don't matter? Most egregious in Chapter 3, but Chapter 6 also left a sour taste in my mouth. I think whether or not this kills the game for people depends on if you end up caring for the characters - I loved them all, but even I had to question the pointlessness of the many errands the protags were constantly going on when there were way bigger fish for them to fry, so to speak...

The music is also pretty great, catchy, though not particularly memorable. Standout tracks for me probably include the New Dam City theme, and the boss fight music. At the very least, it stays consistent throughout, and never feels out of place.

I'm glad I gave Eastward a chance, despite the negative things I've read about it from people who gave up on it. It's not perfect, but it kept me interested until the very end, and if a game does that, there's no way I can say it's a bad game.

128588773.review: Alright so, I've been following the news surrounding this game since the trailer released what felt like ages ago. As somebody who grew up on games like those in the Zelda series and Earthbound, I would say the gameplay has an interesting blend of the two with a bit of hotline Miami sprinkled in when it comes to combat. Having just finished my first playthrough I can safely say that Eastward is a great game. However, it does manage to be a bit rough around the edges in certain ways so I'll talk about the bad first and then the good. The story, while I found it beautifully written, i have noticed that it can be a bit confusing at times as others have pointed out. While the game was fun and really enjoyable, the pacing did have some hiccups at certain points where things seemed to drag a bit or play out in an odd way. And finally, the finality of every action you take can be a bit frustrating at times. Walking into a new zone can be a gamble as you could be going into a side room with treasure you can go in and out of orrr you end up stuck having to progress as your entrance just caved in. Also just a side gripe, no potatoes in late game made me one recipe short of getting the five star chef achievement, its kinda similar with a lot of food items though so if you're a completionist be aware of that. NOW FOR THE GOOD STUFF. First the setting/world is phenomenal and the usage of weather and lighting with an overgrown world is wonderfully done. There is also a really amazing blend of styles with American, Japanese, and even Soviet motifs sprinkled throughout the world with an apocalyptic twist. The characters and their dynamics with one another are also really heartwarming and there really is a gorgeous emotional connection with the characters, especially the main protagonists. The fighting is really fun and despite it having a somewhat old fashioned top-down zelda/hotline Miami style, it can prove to be a really fun and refreshing challenge, and with some really well made dungeon puzzles you're surely in for a good time. Overall even though there are some rough spots in the game, I feel like most of them will be fixed possibly through updates and even with them I would still say my time with this game was well spent and really enjoyable.

128082177.review:
I think of this game from time to time, and the reason for that chalks up to scrolling past it before opening a different game on this computer. 

Eastward had work put into its appearance, and its appearance is good. It's hard to find any other substance. As interesting as the design of the game seemed, the devs striked out on writing, dialogue, or a narrative that had any sort of pull. This type of environment and world building should be surrounded by intrigue, yet nothing about Eastward is curious. If you're gonna do an isometric (rpg?) video game, I think the assumption today is that the story is gonna kill- and that's because it's really hard to make an isometric game unique in how it plays. So Eastward has to be fun, then?

To its benefit: it's short, and you don't have to suffer some of the most simple isometric combat and puzzles I've experienced in a while for long.
[b]3/10[/b]

127817430.review: Absolutely beautiful game! I found the gameplay to be a bit frustrating at times, but the gorgeous pixel art and amazing music totally make up for it!

127787408.review:
every bit of this game oozes passion and love, admittedly these days games with that kind of property aren't seen so much, but this game is def an exception.  Everything from the art to the music to the writing just oozes creativity and love, you could really tell when the creators were just having fun with what they were making in this.  The fact this game isn't talked about as much as it should be honestly is a bit of a crime, because it's genuinely a work of art, art in a very weird sense I'll admit but art nonetheless. 

That being said there are a few issues I did find with the game, albeit small.  The most glaring of issues is the odd pacing of the story, the story of this game is very dramatic and a lot of its most heart breaking moments don't get enough time to shine before the next goofy, upbeat moment comes to ruin it.  In other words, this game has an odd sense of timing when it comes to playing with the emotions of the player, because one moment you'll be hit with tension immediately to be broken by very very very inappropriately timed music.  There also lies an issue with the controls during combat, the combat in this game is admittedly rather  clunky, depth perception is often an issue and switching weapons is not nearly as smooth as it should be during fast combat.  I used a lot more healing items than was really necessary most of the time because I kept getting stuck between weapons when switching.  It's such an odd issue with the game that after a while is something I just slowly got used to but even so it's a bit frustrating.

beyond that, it's in short a good game worth it's price tag

127161311.review:
Where to start? Being thrown into a dystopian world that seems to be at the hands of human-made environmental disaster and a cast of idiosyncratic survivors is a great lure for audiences and players who enjoy atmospheric driven stories. One will try their luck adapting to the needs of the scenario, piecing together the histories and relationships of the characters. An embedding and killer soundtrack, which includes one of my favourite cooking mini-game mechanics that I've had the pleasure of coming across. 
Play captures the child-like desire to act immediately with confidence and following a moral compass (which may just be impulse) as Sam, along side the projected stoic, consequence-knowing and quick reactive resourcefulness of John, made for complimentary engaging solutions to the puzzles and dungeons. Akin to audiences that enjoyed the feeling of first watching Adventure Time, these protagonists are often steering toward the wrong path in their quest to investigate new places and help the people they care about in a lush and weird setting. I also feel that there is similitude to Celeste such as increased difficulty at a good pace, harbouring fluid controls, cute art-style, and emotional merit. 
The game does pull the player into making inferences to fill in the gaps of the lore, some may find this confusing or tiresome, but for those in the corner who see the drive and attraction coming from not knowing, it will not disappoint. Something to note is that the music tracks during a dialogue sequence can be repetitive and distract from reading, as well as the type and number of attacks required in boss fights. This is reminiscent of older game-boy rpg games and did not hinder the overall experience. 
The charm and details of Eastward are salient and make it all worth it to anyone who's looking for a beautiful, immersive, narrative driven retreat.

127097148.review:
The way I feel about Eastward is very complicated.

If I could give this a neutral review, I would. But the reason I have to err on the side of not recommending it is because the first 20 hours of my play was extraordinarily boring. On multiple occasions, I was questioning myself as to why I was still playing, even though I wasn't having fun. I think it was a sunk-cost fallacy type situation.

In contrast, the final act of the game is excellent, it wraps up all the story threads in a beautiful way, and plus it just becomes much more engaging. The combat is much more fun once you've unlocked all the weapons, and the puzzles at the end are just more fun.

I can't recommend this game to most people though, unless you're willing to slog through 15-20 hours of boring gameplay and story. The ending is beautiful, and Earth Born is actually a 10/10 8-bit roguelike built into the game once you have a decent amount of the amibo things.

126508538.review:
Let me start by saying the overall presentation of this game is fantastic. The visual aesthetic and the music alone bump this review to a positive rating. What had initially got me interested in this game was the beautiful visual style that was presented in the trailers, and in this regard Eastward does not disappoint. 

From a gameplay standpoint, the puzzles and combat mechanics aren't mind blowing, but they are pretty good and will keep the player engaged throughout play. There's a lot of standard "dungeon" formula, with areas containing a significant amount of puzzles and combat encounters with a boss fight at the end. This is by no means bad design, but it definitely began to feel cookie-cutter the more I played.

This game does come with a catch, however. The sheer amount of fetch quests and dull conversations with NPCs brings the experience down a few notches for me. The amount of times I had to aimlessly run around trying to find the next NPC to talk to that would advance the story became annoying relatively quickly, and resulted in a substantial amount of dull sections overall. This ultimately resulted in me having to practically force myself to finish the game after dropping it for multiple months prior.

Taking these points into account, I still ultimately recommend the game, but only to a specific audience of people that is fine with many dull moments that are solely dedicated to world building or advancing the story in small increments, with combat and puzzles mixed in every now and then.

125968423.review: It's so pretty, but I couldn't bother to finish it. Like so many other indie games, Eastward is an amazing labor of love that suffered from deep ambition cuts and a lack of undefinable polish. The result is a very unique Love Letter to classic pixel adventure games. The game makes constant reference to Nintendo's Earthbound (Mother 2) as an inspiration, but it's closer to Illusion of Gaia in execution - long stretches of stilted combat adventuring and light puzzle solving punctuated by towns filled with painfully dull dialogue. The charming artwork and animation pulled me most of the way through the game, but the lack of story payoff and an increase in combat clunkiness over meaningful progression just made the slog unbearable. "Monkollywood" was the nail in the coffin of my interest. I did not experience what some have described as character progression, just a lot of static, two dimensional stock characters talking way too much about banal things, without the ability to speed up the text scroll. This post-post-apocalyptic world deserves more time to develop and better combat feel. I look forward to seeing what this team can do with more time and money.

What I didn't enjoy is the story. Or rather, how it was delivered. Despite me talking with all the NPCs it didn't help to understand the world of Eastward. 125911516.review:
From my Backloggd: https://www.backloggd.com/u/HumbleReviewz/

This game is so incredibly close to being something really special, but instead of focusing on and really refining its best aspects (characters & story), it decides instead to have the story linger on for too long by padding it with extra unnecessary sections (Monkollywood) which I would've preferred they either cut or replaced with anything more plot relevant. The combat and puzzles also tend to lead to this problem, where instead of serving as fun, engaging sections to break up bits of the story, they instead can turn into drawn out, lengthy dungeons with combat mechanics I wish were better tuned. The art team really outdid themselves with this game though, with a somewhat short but really sweet soundtrack filled with a lot of great tracks and some of the best art direction I've seen not just from an indie game, but any game period. This game is worth a play if you're an RPG fan, but after sinking over a day into it I just wish it was a little bit more.

125720540.review:
I have played almost 40 hours of this game, and it manages to feel both immensely charming and absolutely pointless. Nothing connects logically, and the game builds up interesting new developments only to suddenly hop over to WACKYVILLE with zero rationale for any of it. Worse yet, it doesn't really feel like there's like... a point, to this game. I'm not trying to get anything, or go anywhere; neither of the main characters has any real motivations, or core. Sam is a vaguely magical child who probably caused the apocalypse some vague amount of time ago, John is the Doomslayer if he just liked beans in the afternoon.

An excellent example of this is the cooking wager. At one point John and Sam show up at a new city, for the incredibly personal reason that it was the next automated station the train would take them to, and they get a job as general assistants so that they'll have a room to sleep in. Sam then just... sneaks out, meets some local kids, and at their request goes to the local casino because one of said kids is there. She gets him to go back and then just stays and begins gambling with a magic coin. The mob boss catches her, and like... Decides to have a bet with her, that John and she can't cook a dish he'll like. There's no real reason to go along with it, no real prize or punishment connected to the bet. She accepts, and this becomes basically the main quest.

They get three tries; on the first they go through a dungeon to get a fruit, and then gift that fruit to someone else who sells them a sob story. Not really that annoying, this fits the characters as shown. Second try, they get some high-quality crab, make a crab steamer pot, and then they get pressganged by the local clowns to help them train for the circus' grand opening, for no payment or reason, which causes the crab to overcook and instantly go bad. Thirdly, they go through ANOTHER long dungeon, find some kinda magic fish, feed it to the mob boss, he concedes defeat because it's good fish, and then Sam insists that she wants, as a reward for the wager, that he come have dinner with them every night because she feels they're friends now. No! I've met this man like thrice and every time he's been vaguely menacing at both best and worst! I don't care! WHY am I here! WHY is my search for Alva being interrupted by goddamn Ape Escape! WHY is my search for a rocket interrupted by crappy Jeopardy! WHY is my arrival at Ester City interrupted by suddenly John and Sam teleported into being pirates for no reason!
