125517494.review:
[b]Eastward is such a beautifully-made game.[/b] Its pixel style combined with nostalgic color palette is so pleasing to the eye. I couldn't stop staring at each scenes. [b]The soundtrack is so atmospheric and evocative[/b]--it perfectly captures the mood of the game and was able to make me elicit every emotion there is. It truly brought the game to life. The story of the game is well-written. You can tell through the dialogues and overall narration of the game that the writer really took their time with the process; the conversations felt natural and seamless, and the narration during montages were so poetic, [b]it made me clutch my heart[/b]. The story can get dark, but there surely is a lot of comical and heartfelt moments throughout the game. The flow is slow-burn and some people may get bored in certain areas. But not me. I am into story-driven games and I genuinely enjoy reading dialogues and getting deep within the lore, so my experience with it is just pure fun. Also, the aesthetic aspect of the game just captivated me and it really helped with getting me to hyper fixate on the game that I did not get bored with my playthrough.

In terms of its gameplay, it is very casual like you would expect. But I would be lying if I'd say I didn't get a hard time with specific fights, because I did. In multiple instances, in fact. Nothing too elden ring type of difficulty though. If you've played a bunch of super mario and related games, this is a piece of cake for you. I did not expect that the game would be this long. Not that I'm complaining. But I wish the chapters were equally divided because leaving the game mid-chapter when you have to go about your day or head to bed kind of ruins the momentum—some chapters were too long and felt dragging. I had to chop it off and continue the next day. [i]I'm looking at you, chapter 7.[/i]

One tip that I can give is that, upgrade your backpack and always fill it up with foods because enemies will catch you off guard sometimes. Every time you stumble upon a stove, cook. So you have food along the way, like the true adventurer that you are.

[b]Overall, the game is so beautiful and memorable. I'm glad I played it.[/b] I wish they make a sequel soon.

I think that eastward is a very promising game, a game that i really enjoyed and at times reminded me of the super mario bros rpgs, this game has one of the best art direction in any pixel art games i've ever played.
The gameplay is ok, i really enjoyed the aspect of the two playable characters, each one with a different moveset that complimets the other, even though I wish some gear was given more opportunity to shine due to the fact that some of it comes in late.
Most the characters of this game are memorable and have cool/funny moments.
The only gripe that i have with the character development is that i feel like john is a cool main protagonist on paper but his past, memories or thoughs are almost never expicited, from the top of my head there are only 4 moments where we can tell what john is feeling in the whole 22h of gameplay.
The story is very well told..... that is up to the 3/4 of the game, after that the last 2 chapters feel rushed, not well put toghether and have a bunch of exposition dumps.
The rest of the storyline is very cool and worth sitting through the last quarter of the game, it is full of amazing storytelling and well done atmospheric scenes.
Overall I would give eastward a 7.5/10.
If you have some money spare or this game is on sale I would recommend you get it.

EastWard brings back what was lost in today's adventure rpg games. Games like Space Quest, KingsQuest, Quest For Glory. 
The Game play isn't a story that drags, where you just want to finish so you get your money's worth. EastWards storytelling, is realistic, and for me, does what today's games no longer do! They cause real feelings of love, ager, and hate! Not to post spoilers, but I'm not even far in this game yet, and want karma to bury that evil Mayer!! 
Puzzles are like the old Sierra games, and get more difficult as the game progresses.
For those who like to cheat in games like this, a huge warning. Do not add items you have not gotten in game yet! Adding more tokens, chips, gold, and salt, and locking ones HP is the only safe type of cheating you can do!
Increasing bag size, and adding better weapons and items before you get to the parts of the game where you get them will forever softlock you from ever completing the game. It's not an anti cheat, it's triggering game flags that look at the items you have, and remove the code for the events that would have opened up new reagons for you, and instead forever keep them out of your reach.
EarthBorn game, the only safe cheat is increasing gold and adding exp. Don't raise the levels, because doing so will result in game flags being passed up that give you needed items and reagon unlocks. Adding exp so levels go up nature, by realistic numbers, is only safest cheat to level up. For example, if you have 88 exp and 400 is level up, then add 312 and fight something. Don't go adding 200,000 exp all at once, or your game will softlock!
I'll fix this review to format it better on my PC. Doing this on my phone.
Game play and controlls is simple enough, but a game controller for battels Is highly recommended.
Don't like the controller options, try a utility called Xpadder. It's a utility I myself use, to program the gamepad keys the way In comfortable with. This is great, if you play several games with a configuration your used to, and want this game to use the same configuration. I don't recommend Xpadder for valve games like TF2, as it's been known to accidentally trigger false VACs due to changes it makes in memory.

Eastward reminds me also of the old Ultima and Final Fantasy games, using multiple player characters to complete puzzles, only they can do.

The animations and especially the intro was done with great thought, and not thrown together, just to fit similar game formats.

Back your adata save folder up often! This way if you make a mistake, or auto save, loses a good game, you won't have to start over. 

The only thing I severely dislike about this game, is having multiple intro screens, forced down ones throat , with no way to bypass. It's important to give credit where credit is due, but after the first time, if I'm paying for a game, I don't want to be forced to watch all the games creators, every single time I load the game up. Even running off an NVME, it's damned annoying!

The game starts off, in an underground city. It looks as if an apocalypse has struck, where science of our time, has long been lost. The city is run by a corrupt mayer, who has convinced his citizens that the world above, is a dead and baren wasteland. Question the Mayer, and you and your family vanish. Sent off to what all believe are their deaths, never to return. 
Sam is found in a stasis, and through has no memory of her past, somehow knows the truth of what exists above, mostly by a spirit of herself, that tends to appear in times of danger. 
There are a lot of hidden rooms and treasures that your treasure Meter won't announce, so keep your eyes open for them. 
This is a single player game, but one the entire family can play together.
Definitely worth the price!

125248279.review:
“John, what are you waiting for? -Let’s go!”

I'm not a big fan of reviewing things, but this one's special. -"Eastward" is a game that takes you on a journey. It's destination? -That's for you to find out, within environments that are and intricately crafted, characters that are teeming with uniqueness, and scenarios that you can immerse yourself in.

From the very start of the game what stands out the most is its atmosphere. -Dark, rustic, and desolate. -Yet, the characters which lived in it bestowed it with the warmth, and the color it needed to feel inviting. The environments, and the setting perfectly captures story set in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity is on its last legs. -And as the journey progresses, you come across various other locations which adds stark contrast to where you start the game originally, all the while maintaining the overall atmosphere of it. In addition to that, the attention to detail that you find in each of these environments is simply gorgeous. From the depths of the earth where scant light filters in, to the fields that are bathed in soft afternoon sunlight, “Eastward” has its world crafted masterfully.

When it comes to the characters, the game goes vivid. You find a set of characters that stands out under their own spotlights. Unique, vibrant, and exciting. -From cowards that uses others as an excuse to save themselves, to lovers who wish their love becomes true, to comedians that wants nothing but the best in life, to heroes that put others before themselves, “Eastward’s” characters go above and beyond to add that “light” and “life” that its world lacks. Every character who comes into contact with John and Sam on their journey adds their own flavor to it. Be it an NPC of the main quest, a simple bystander that shares tidbits of their life, the conversations are crafted in a way that makes you – the player – feel a part of their world.

The story of “Eastward” stands out as one of the best in its own right. The journey of John and Sam is rich with emotion as they come across various situations, and characters of the world. The game is brimming with moments that are simple happiness, moments of solemnity and calmness, and of course moments of sorrow and anguish. -And they come together in perfect balance as John and Sam makes their way through the world of “Eastward” making it stand out on its own. Without giving any spoilers, in each part of the world of “Eastward” that John and Sam travels to, brings to them their own set of “troubles” (To which Sam dives headfirst with her bright and cheerful nature, and John simply follows her.). With a mystery element that simply gets you craving to find out what happens next, “Eastward” draws you in to its world filled with adventure, and paired with it, danger.

The gameplay of “Eastward” is very smooth with little to no rough edges. Clearly this game is meant to be enjoyed on a controller, but keyboard and mouse works just fine as well. The weapons in game were simply brilliant, using skill to use them in combat and in puzzles -The puzzle system of the game is crafted to perfection, with just the right amount of critical thinking factor put in to keep you on edge. -Finally, the boss fights were often exciting, providing greater sense of accomplishment, and euphoria upon triumph.

Overall “Eastward” was a game that I will remember a long time. -Not simply as a “game” that I played, but as a “journey” I took together with John and Sam to find out the wonders of its world. -And on that journey I found so much  more than I ever hoped for.

125094150.review:
Tl;dr: a beautiful game, but with ugly characters and a meaningless plot. Do not recommend.

After hearing so much praise for this game I was intrigued. I bought it, installed it, and jumped in with high hopes. Almost immediately I was having fun; the art is engaging and detailed, the world is vibrant and beautiful, and the setup seems interesting. And then this charm wears thin. VERY quickly.

Pros:
The art is gorgeous. Environments are beautiful and detailed. The pixel art aesthetic is awesome to look at and beautiful to explore.
The music is nice. Not amazing, but nice.

Cons:
Everything else.
The characters are pretty much all grotesquely ugly and appear malformed. This is reflected in their attitudes; I think there's maybe four people so far that I haven't felt utterly sick of within minutes of talking to them. The dialogue takes forever, and you can't skip cutscenes or lines at all. The objectives in each area feel absolutely pointless. An example follows:
You are sent to get a berry. You go and get the berry, which involves convincing an old man to let you have it, which is purely arbitrary. There is no story impact whatsoever to this old man or convincing him you can't take the berry. It's just dialogue to mash through until you get the berry and go back to your house. But, before you can actually USE the berry, a scam artist--who is very obviously a scam artist--shows up and scams the berry away from the protagonists, who don't even question it. And that's it. Nothing else comes of this, except you fail in your objective to get the berry and the game continues on.
This isn't helped by the main characters. John is an absolute nothing pie. No characterization, no emoting, no dialogue, nothing. You get the sense that he MIGHT care about Sam, but it's hard to honestly say he does because he's such a blank, scruffy, ugly slate. It was a surprise to me since the game only ever shows off Sam on its cover art, and she's cute! Until she isn't. She does all of the talking for both characters, and at a point it starts to seem whiny. 

The plot of the game is also propelled by truly despicable characters. The mayor and Yohn are two of the most slimy jerks I've ever seen in a game, and not only do they manage to win against your characters, they get no sort of comeuppance. As the player you simply have to accept that the scummy, evil people won and move on. The exception is the second area you end up in--everyone there is pretty nice! But then it all ends up completely devoid of meaning anyway and you have to move on. 

Ten hours in and I'm struggling to understand the praise. Maybe people just have low standards. Maybe it gets better. But as-is? The hype is just hype.

125086444.review:
+This game has a TON of charm, 
+beautiful art, 
+well imagined locations, 
+entertaining characters, 
+well-executed plot and 
+plenty to do.
+The main characters are character you really grow to like, and you really feel for them as you go through this quirky sci-fi adventure. 

[] It is somewhere along an action RPG in gameplay, but it has distinct stealth sections and other digressions of style.
[] The gameplay on a first run seems like it'd take no less than 24 hours, possibly more, to complete. If a dollar an hour of gameplay is worth it to you then this is a plus, if that seems lacking then you may find this disappointing, but I feel it is worth it on my end, and I tend to shop cheap.
[] While there is a lot of experience to be had, that time does blaze by. This is good in the sense that it is gripping, but bad in that it really felt like it went by quickly. The number of locations feels small (even though those locations, themselves, feel enormous, at times.) I feel like you also could do well to explore some of the things that are showcased in more depth at times. There's several places that look like you should be able to enter and explore, but they are just set dressing. This is not a full negative, rather neutral, to me, because, really, if it took me (exploring a lot) almost 40 hours to complete, there clearly _is_ substance. 

- The minigames are a mixed bag. The side-minigames really don't feel worth delving too much into, though I did enjoy the gatcha since it doesn't really intrude on the gameplay, and doesn't affect the main story, I will also give the gatcha mechanic, conceptually a pass. (If the gatcha were in some way required to beat the game, this would be a second minus.)
- The story has a couple pitfalls that kind of disappoint me, personally, but not every note is going to hit everyone just right.
- There can be a BIT of busywork to the gameplay.
- The way this game gets dark when it does has some level of sour taste in its actions that don't fully feel like they always push the plot forward, or they push it forward in ways that feel a bit mean-spirited to the player in a narrative sense.
- Some of the things that happen also make it feel like it wouldn't be fun to replay if you get connected heavily to characters (not in the Undertale sense of that experience, in a different sense.) Replayability isn't mandatory to a good game, but it is worth noting, here.

124921679.review:
After 17 hours, I had to change my review, which was positive originally, afte only three hours. It's negative now.

The game is not too bad, but it's utterly and overly stupid. It's juvenile, it's not even childish, it's puerile!

The story doesn't have any pathos, you are supposed to save people you don't give a damn about simply because the game doesn't make these people feel real, alive. They're just sprites, some pretty and some ugly, with an annoying dancing animation that makes me wanna scream "stop it now!"

For instance, the circus quest. You can't enter an area for no reason at all, the game simply says you can't go on until everything is ready, but no other explanation is offered. Later, you can enter the area and there's nothing there, just a bunch of clowns chilling. Why was not I allowed to enter bedore if nothing was happening? Even later, when I acually had osmething important to do: the stupid brat that clings along with her white hair made a bet with a mafia boss that I could cook him something amazing, and when i had the ingredients, she gave them away to an obvious liar who simply wanted my ingredients; she didn't ask, she just took my stuff and gave it away. next day, I had everything for an even better dish, but she asked me to go train the damn clowns so they could make a good show and not be kicked out. But, why? I'm a digger, I am not a clown, I can't teach clowns how to do their damn jobs! But I had not choice, the stupid brat promised I would, and my dish overcooked and only one day's left to make a good dish and not be killed or something.

It's been three sessions since I had any fun. Fun, in this game, comes from combat. But combat is shallow and repetitive. Still fun, specially ehen everything else is so bad (except the graphics; the graphics are so good... not the NPCs constantly dancing for no reason). But it's been a few hours since I had some combat, and now I've been through story, but the story in this game is drivel. All that circus thing? That's not story, that's just drivel.

In a walking simulator, when you go to another house and open a door, the story moves, goes on, there's progress, that's the game, the story is the game. Eastward wants to be story and gameplay, and it thinks gameplay is having an NPC asking you to go to some house, find three items, and bring them back. Yeah, simple fetch quest like any RPG. Except, the house is a few screens away, but 20 seconds tops, and inside there are three rooms, open, along a single hallway, each containing one item. You enter, grab the item, and leave. 20 seconds later, you go back and give the items... it's so asburds, it's so pointless, there's no challenge. Literally no challenge, not a single enemy, nothing, just walking, pontless walking, the story doesn't move, this quest is not story, and almost every single quest in this game, is drivel.

I don't mind whether a game's writing is Shakespeare or Coelho (i.e. great or sh*t) as long as the game is fun to play. I don't care if a game's gameplay is simple and not too fun, as long as the story is worth to read and see through. This game has sub-par gameplay and bad writing. The graphis are excellent but the graphics can't save a game if the other factors are this flawed. Music... forgetable; not bad, only not interesting, just average.

The first few hours were good, the story seemed to make sense, the NPCs had some charm, but after you leave the first location, every NPCs is shallow and empty and more than silly. I can't recommend this game, I feel cheated.

***

Original review, after three hours:

Super good game.

Only a couple minor flaws: Controlling the characters with the stick is imprecise, and the main character doesn't talk, aren't you tired of silent protagonists? And a nitpick: school bullying is so clichéd, we've been reading and watching stories about school bullying for four decades now.

Other than that, the game is wonderful, at least the prologue and the first episode, and I can't wait to play the next episodes this next weekend! I'm afraid the game will be shorter than expected, but if it keeps this quality for another 10 hours, then no complains from me (but for a game like this, I would like 20-25 hours).

The characters are fun and charismatic, the animation is excellent, the art-style is wonderful, the mechanics are fun.

The worst one is the first one, after that they did improve in frustration meter. However, it didn't stop me from thoroughly enjoying every other part of this game. The character development, the art, the different aspects of each area you visit, the dialog - all of it is just harken back to games of my youth but improved upon. I have played quite a bit of a few other Chucklefish games. Mostly Starbound. I fell in love with the games pixel graphics and music. I can say without a shadow of a doubt that I was carried through this game with more joy than I had experienced from most of the more recent big brand games out there today.

I felt the warmth and love put into this game each and every hour I played it. There were moments were I'd giggle with delight, there were moments where I'd yell and shout at something that caught me off guard. I don't think I've put that kind of a passion into playing a game in many years. So after having played this game, I feel fulfilled in a way. There are just a lot of quality of life issues: there's no way to make the text auto or skip it, sometime's you can't fast travel, or the quest is too vague for you to figure out what to do next. I literally cleaned out my 7000+ camera roll during the cut scenes because it just wasn't really engaging. 

I spent a lot of time using walkthroughs and to be honest, I don't think a game should be so complex that you have to spend majority of it on a walkthrough page. There were so many moments where you can easily miss something really vital if you aren't glued to the walkthrough page. 

I'm not sure what i expected from this game but it didn't really fulfill my expectations. I think you should get this game if it's on sale or if you're really into gorgeous art and long, complex stories. It's like Genshin story quest long where you're sitting there for almost half an hour just hoping to finish it so you can save and move on. I dd finish the game and I think I'm gonna go back to try and see what I missed and get some achievements but I'm mainly writing this so that you understand what kind of game you're purchasing and if it's for you <3

123457961.review:
This game clearly had a lot of hard work and love put into it, but unfortunately, I just haven't been able to come back to it and finish it. These types of games are usually the ones to leave an impact on me, but Eastward has a problem which prevents it from getting the player invested: It's boring.

The combat system and plot are where this problem is most clear. Combat feels sluggish and repetitive, and there is no room at all for putting your own style into it. Every fight feels almost like a chore, a nuisance, or just a roadblock for progression. After a while, it just delays you from the already slow story. 

Second is the plot. Although it was probably very well thought out, the plot is not deep at all. What I find gets me attached to games like these is a great story, one that I can remember for years, or one that makes me think about it whenever I'm not playing. I really wish I cared for Eastward, but I simply don't. I don't know how it ends, or what will come next, and that doesn't bother me. I haven't came back to continue it because I truly have never gained any attachment to it whatsoever. 

Anyways, it's unfortunate such a well made game isn't all that fun.

123245465.review:
One of the many major standouts of this game for me was the incredible attention to detail and style. I thought that the visuals and music combined well with the narrative to create incredible places to explore.
The detail in the character design, animations, cooking ;), earthbound, the UI, backgrounds are unparalleled. Some of my favorite moments without spoilers and in no particular order were the train/animations and design, the zoom after leaving the first train station near the start of the game, the last two boss fights, and the design of the final large city. 

This game is incredibly atmospheric.

I would recommend this game to people who like narrative driven adventures with accessible gameplay, anyone who wants a highly produced and stylistic story with heartfelt characters. The game was a nice and wholly chill escape into a trash punk future. 

Notes: 
Pacing: 
The beginning of the game has long stretches of text only interactions, truly the game has many moments where the dialogue drags a bit from my perspective. There are moments where the dialogue shines through, notably: at the casino, in the fog city, in the mayors house, many of the glitch moments, there are others. Rather, the game is quite linear and the beginning takes quite a while to complete while providing not a huge amount of narrative and engaging gameplay. This game was very ambitious in many ways, and it accomplishes many of them well, but I think that it edges into the realm of quantity over quality.

Gameplay: 
  For those looking for interesting gameplay, you may find many of the puzzles and fights a bit simplistic, although many of the boss battles were incredibly engaging.

I really want to be able to recommend this. The art is incredible, with every screen crammed full of interesting little details. It's a joy to look at, the music is good, and the story is intermittently charming.

Unfortunately, I didn't really have fun actually playing it. Combat in this game feels very slow and stiff. You obtain a number of different weapons throughout the game but none of them ever felt fun to use to me. The game is extremely stingy with health drops and loves to spawn enemies right on top of you. If you stock up on food items you can grind through the missions without much trouble but doing so feels like a chore rather than an accomplishment.

The story, as many others have pointed out, is plentiful but not very deep. There's a definite sense of children playing make-believe here. Characters will proclaim something and everyone will follow along with that plot beat for a while until they get distracted again and take off in a new direction. Nothing really sticks, yet everything is treated as critically important. It all just overstays its welcome after a while.

122938729.review:
This is a qualified recommendation. One with caveats.

The game itself is fun — nice little retro action RPG in the style of Secret of Mana, Terranigma, &c. — when it lets you play. Between the dungeons, you should expect to spend a lot of time reading characters droning on and on and on just to get to the one plot point you need. It's a very verbose game, sometimes to its detriment.

At one point in the penultimate chapter, you have to replay a section 3 times. Most of the mandatory interactions are precisely the same each time through, but you've still got to read them. (And even the fastest text speed option isn't that fast.)

Additionally, not all of the emotional notes are hit as well as the developers hoped. The resolution for a pair of secondary characters [spoiler]Alva & Isabella[/spoiler] feels far more compelling than the final scene featuring the two main characters.

I grabbed it on sale & I enjoyed it, but unlike some of the other games it's taking inspiration from I doubt I'm going to play it again.

The beginning is a bit slow, especially chapter 3, but it gets REALLY good later on. The last 2 chapters in particular were amazing. The highlight of the game overall were the characters, since this game's story is very character-focused.

This game is fairly text heavy and some people might not like that, but I thought the writing was pretty well done. The story can also be a little vague and cryptic at times, though the mystery and how it came together was actually one of my favorite parts.

All that being said: I highly recommend this game.

122657720.review:
RATING: 10/10

Does this game have a confusing story at times? Absolutely. Were there things it could have done better? Definitely. Is this still one of my favorite games of all time?

YES.

I haven't played a game I've loved this much in so long. There's something so magical about the art, soundtrack, and storytelling method. Travelling to each destination was so thrilling, and it was so neat to see the unique characters each location brought. I also really enjoyed the cooking mechanics, and looked forward to unlocking new recipes with new combinations of ingredients. It reminds me a lot of Zelda: BOTW and I adore it. 
One thing that was a huge plus for me about this game is the advancement method. Unlike many other games I've played, grinding levels/fighting enemies is not necessary to progress the story (other than bosses of course). It was really nice to play and not have to go through hours of painstakingly long grinding. 
A lot of people criticize this game for it's story. While there's definitely a lot more they could have built on, and it had it's fair share of plot holes, I found myself coming back for more and more. To me, this game's mystery is one of it's biggest charms, and I think if the developers were to make a second game expanding on the story, it'd be great.

122496495.review:
TLDR: Only buy this game when it's on sale. The art is stunning but the gameplay and storyline kind of sucks.

I've not written a review in a long time, but I just can't with this game. So I got this it while it's on sale and I'd say for the art work, its wroth every single penny and maybe even more. Kudos to the artists! If it's not for them there is almost no reason for me to recommend this game at all. The gameplay and storyline are really just not the best, and I would not recommend paying anything more than 30% off. Disclaimer, at the time of this review, I am at chapter 3 only. It may get better later on so I'd try to comment on the general things rather than chapter specific things. No spoilers whatsoever.

To be fair, I kind of went in blind without knowing what the game is about nor what kind of experience I would get out of it. I bought it merely because of the art style and because it seemed to be a cute RPG game. Right off the bat when the game is launched, there's a short *skip-able* "introduction" or a mini background story on how the two main characters Sam and John met. And that is basically all the information you'd ever get about them. If you pressed ESC and skipped it, you would be left in the dark as to who the protagonists Sam and John are. I'm at the third chapter right now (which is about 8 hours in) and I have not gained much new knowledge on the game's backstory, such as why we're going on the missions, or why the world is the way it is. From time to time there'd be a sentence or two hinting Sam's backstory, but it is very vague and it's all guessing work. 

There's no voice over, which is alright. But omg, there are a lot of cutscenes, and most of the dialogs are long and unnecessary. Most of them can be easily summarised in a sentence or two and be done with. Some conversations are almost at the brink of being pointless because it does not add any depth to any of the characters as none of them had a solid backstory/ storyline significance for players to really get to know them. They all existed because the towns needed some NPCs. Even with "side characters" (if you can even call them that) that had quests or more conversations with, will come and go as the so-called storyline wanted them to. They existed simply to provide quests and nothing more. 

Speaking of the quests. they all felt like tutorial sessions disguised as quests. It just felt like the entire game is about constant boss fight, and some random "quests" to teach you how to perform certain actions that would get you through the path to get to the boss. Most of the quests, if not all, provided no actual value to the plot. Often times I feel like I'm playing super pretty platformer with some half baked dialogs in attempt to explain why the background landscape changed from A to B as I proceed through the levels. To make matter worse, Sam's dialogs just makes her bratty and annoying; and John having zero dialog makes me feel like he too, like other NPCs, is just a hollow character. 

Let's talk about the gameplay. The game recommends you to play with a controller, and since I don't have one, I went with keyboard and mouse. You walk with WASD and fight with right click. This setup shouldn't be chunky but then they decided to do a 360' aiming radar (with the mouse) instead of a simple keyboard North, South (NE/ NW), East (SE/ SW), West and that is where it gets super annoying. Although the range of the aim is large enough to hit multiple targets at the same time, having to constantly twitch the mouse to aim the attacks, all while trying to move the character around is just bad combat system design. 

On top of that, health drains like crazy. Say you start off with 5 HP right? Touching an enemy (if you walk pass them) automatically loses 1 HP. Then of course, if you can't dodge their attacks and got hurt, you'd lose another. There are occasionally HP droplets and weapon replenishments dropped as loot from defeated enemies but you will run out of supplies and die a lot. Based on the art style I was expecting some chill gameplay but no. Because of the auto-safe function I had to restart a timed puzzle so many times with basically 1HP left, and it honestly brought me so much frustration it's crazy. It's okay to die a lot, but instead of having to save the game only at designated spots, maybe allow the player to save whenever they want so it makes the restarts less painful?

There's also an in-game mini game that is very similar to OG 8-bit Pokemon gameboy game. It is as usual, not save-able whenever you desire. And it also doesn't show the enemy's full health. You switch between pokemons (characters in this case) trying to fight monsters without even knowing what level or HP they are at. And that is just absolutely dumb. What if you're level 1 and they are level 10, wouldn't you want to know whether you should fight or flight? And once again, I am not sure why they even added this mini game into the game in the first place. It all goes back to a weak plot. I guess I'm just so confused as to what this game is about. 

I will most likely give it few more chances because I still do want to get through the game to see how other stages look like. The world looks fantastic and although many objects are not interactive, it still is a joy to walk, stop, and admire the amazing details in the pixel art world they've created. Once again, hats off to the artists! If the gameplay/ storyline were better, it would have been so much more enjoyable. It's a game with potential, how I wish they would have lived up to that.

122149549.review:
Yes, I wholeheartedly recommend this wonderful game to anyone who's thinking of buying it. It's a labor of love, and you can tell that from every detail they put into it.

However I do want to point out a few things that have bothered me from day 1 and they don't seem to be keen on addressing any of it:

1) There is an awful lot of unnecessary dialogue that the game forces you to go through. It doesn't add much to the story and basically just feels like it wants to slow you down. While it's fun to read at first it quickly becomes a reason I don't want to start the game. Especially when you realize that all most of said dialogue could have been reduced to a single sentence. So please just add options to skip or speed this up. 

2) The interface of the game. Every time you start the game it has to go through many screens. No option to speed up or skip any of it? Why? I get that you want to tell everyone who was involved. But not every time surely?

3) Dying. Thankfully I don't die a lot, but for the love of all that you can skip: Add an option to either disable or skip the dramatic death animation. You want to quickly go through that instead of having to wait for the screen to load, play the music and return you to the last save...

So yes three points that considerably reduce the fun that I do have in this game. Perhaps these are things that don't bother others, but to me these elements are very important and are usually present in many of the games I enjoy playing. 

But I do love this game. The story and its characters are wonderful. John and Sam as a team really works. 
The artwork is beautiful and reall well done. All the little details they put in are a treat to the eyes. Same goes for the sound design. I hope they will address these issues at least.

121402319.review:
Eastward is a game that's trying to be too many things at once. A dark and gritty post-apocalyptic sci-fi narrative; a love-letter to 8 and 16-bit JRPGs; a tough dungeon-crawler with full-action combat and puzzle-solving; a fun adventure with goofy, lovable characters; the journey of a stoic man and his cheery, optimistic daughter.

Parts of it really work, like the artstyle, world, and characters. Others really don't. The story and tone feel whiplash-inducing at times, telling a tale I think is far darker than necessary (given the endearing characters and goofy moments), and the game's combat system is honestly very poor. The plot is revealed piece-meal, dragged along by vague dialogue and a veneer of mystery, that ultimately never lives up to its full potential.

With that said, the game is extremely beautiful, the characters are super memorable, and the soundtrack is outstanding; and by buying it, you're supporting a type of game that really doesn't get made much anymore. To me it's worth it for those things alone, but it certainly isn't the greatest game I've played.

121366708.review: This is a really beautiful game. From the artwork to the story to the music-- everything was just so well crafted. It's got a lot of puzzle-type map progression and some combat that's not difficult. There's a rich story and lots of reading. So if that's not your thing, you might not enjoy it. But I loved the whole thing- laughed, cried and felt invested the whole way through (maybe not so much on the monkey level).

121328414.review: Another masterpiece from the formidable Chucklefish, [b]Eastward[/b] plays as entertaining as [i]Starbound[/i] or [i]Stardew Valley[/i]. This is a sentimental action RPG with undertones of [i]Chrono Trigger[/i] and [i]Secret of Mana[/i], and multiple references to [i]Earthbound[/i] (nostalgic? These game devs clearly were too). I put many hours into the game and only finished half the achievements, so there's plenty to do for both the perfectionists and the casuals like myself. New players will enjoy the escalatingly epic storyline, hours of satisfying puzzles, the surprisingly adult themes, and a very rewarding final boss & ending. You can't go wrong with Chucklefish, and I'm recommending you give [b]Eastward[/b] a go.

120781515.review:
I think there's a lot of great art and detail put into this game.  I also think this game is more an interactive story than a game, yes there are some puzzles and dungeons but ultimately it's about the story.  So let's look at the story.  It's good I've enjoyed the parts I have experience but I have a huge quirk and that's the dialog.  if I hit a or x it needs to appear instantly so I can then read it instead of painstakingly waiting for it come up and be read.   I'm sorry but this game is already very long and drawn out and at times a gauntlet of patience when it comes to getting through the dialog, especially when the current plot is so obvious you really don't need to read through it.  

Criticism two:  sometimes the dialog gives you descriptions and they are counter intuitive to where you should actually go.  Example: someone asks you to meet them at the cemetery Downtown... The cemetery is in a place literally called Uptown and it's north on the map... 

Criticism 3:  Let me skip the long as intro, no not the cool animation which you can skip, the painfully slow fade in of the eastward title that then EVENTUALLY brings you to the menu...  Most infuriating thing about this game is the lack of being able to skip or move quickly through cut scenes and dialog when you want to.  A lesson in game design for the creators, I know you put blood sweat and tears into this game but forcing us to appreciate that hardship leads to me appreciating it a lot less than I would if I had some control over the pace of the game.

120745771.review:
[h1]"If you were to get someone else's memories... would you be you? Or them?" - The Fridge, [i]Eastward[/i][/h1]

Aside from save fridges inducing an existential crisis and forcing into question the very foundations of philosophical anthropology, [i]Eastward[/i] has a lot to offer. In a refreshing yet polarizing game inspired by Earthbound and Zelda, you follow John and Sam on their post-apocalyptic journey, [i]er[/i], eastward.

Shanghai-based indie game studio Pixpil offers you an [i]experience[/i] flooded with beautiful pixelart, a uniquely wonderful and immersive story, and all the feels. It's a shame this game only appeals to... a very specific audience. [i]Eastward[/i] thrives in it's immersion, characters, art, and story; combat serves more to advance the narrative than being a central mechanic. Of course there's plenty of combat, but it's obviously supplemental. In [i]Eastward[/i], the sum is most certainly greater than the sum of its parts. 

Most critiques I've seen can be summarized by what John Koenig calls [i]the bends[/i]: "frustration that you're not enjoying an experience as much as you should... which prompts you to plug in various thought combinations to try for anything more than static emotional blankness, as if your heart had been accidentally demagnetized by a surge of expectations." To many, the narrative pace, heavy dialogue, omission of narrative detail and clarity, and more simplistic combat (at least early on), are reasons to call the game [i]boring[/i]. My conclusion is that these very features are what makes the game charming and worth playing. The heavy dialogue helps with immersion and truly fleshing out the characters and atmosphere. The story, although a bit obscure, is not your standard structure and felt like few stories I've seen recently that tried something [i]different [/i](with great pay-off, I'd say). 

But it's not a game for everyone: if you like narrative-driven, immersive, and explorative adventures, you'll probably love [i]Eastward[/i]. If you want something more action-heavy, straightforward, or casual fun, this might not be the game for you. 

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Artstyle and Animations are some of the best I've ever seen, especially for pixel art. The color choices and environment design is unparalleled. 
+ Characters are well-designed, fleshed out, and help immerse you in the story and environment.
+ Atmosphere is probably the shining feature for me about this game. If atmosphere and being drawn in is important to you, Eastward is for you. 
+ Story is unique, emotional, makes you piece together and theorize, and is perfectly supported by every other element in the game. Won't say more for spoiler purposes. 
+ Combat is simplistic but has enough variety to stay fun for those sections. 
+ Cooking was a blast in this game -- and I usually [i]hate[/i] resource collecting and cooking in games. 
+ Collecting was at a perfect amount, and was a pleasure to complete.
+ Difficulty never seems too hard, in combat or puzzles, but still enough to keep you involved. 
+ Earth Born -- it's a whole game within a game! I love when developers do this and how it's weaved within the environments and a bit of the story. It was certainly fun to try and master. 

[h1]Cons/Mixed[/h1]
~ Guides or information about many parts of the game are incredibly difficult to come by and more so for achievement completionists (see below).
~ Pacing may take a while to truly grab you; it's a slow burn that requires/rewards patience and curiosity. I say give it until the end of Chapter 3 to see how you truly feel about it (even though each chapter is truly different and it got more fun personally as I went on). Full disclosure: I put the game down after Chapter 2 and it took a year before I came back to it... then I couldn't stop. 
~ Story leaves... questions and a lot of it can be open to interpretation or is left unclear. This could be a good or bad thing depending on your preferences. 

[h1]Completionists: The Good & Bad News[/h1]
The achievements are all fair and a blast to do. There are plenty of missable achievements, even just from the prologue (before many realize they'll want to complete it), but thankfully in one of the recent updates they created a chapter selection and added Earth Born to the main menu as well. This helped me go back and find some missing chests, get upgrades, ingredients, and so on. 

However, the bad news was it wasn't completely optimized. Despite going back into multiple saves it wouldn't completely work with recipes and eating all the food items as there are some missing even though there shouldn't be. (This problem is not standalone to me.) There also should be a way to see which food/chests you're missing, or at least which ones you have, for reasons like this. 

The most frustrating though, is I beat Earth Born via the main menu, but it didn't unlock the 4 pixballs it should have when going back into the saves to the machines. So there's no reason to play it through the main menu and to get certain Earth Born achievements you need to beat it through the saves. I now need to complete it all over through the save to get the pixball achievements -- this is unnecessary and they should either add a machine to the main menu, make it universal across saves, or have it so beating it in the main menu unlocks it in the saves. 

But overall this experience will forever stay with me and is worth the price. 

9.13/10

120670796.review:
[b]what i liked:[/b]

+ a love letter to two of the most influential games of past days - the legend of zelda and earthbound.

+ charming main characters with unique gameplay. sam and john are two of the most lovely main characters i've ever played with. at some point, you'll have to use both to solve puzzles or fend of your foes.

+ great character writing and development. a lot of different persons with feelings, emotions and peculiarities. pretty charming and always a pleasure to talk to the people. overall the character cast was pretty well written with many memorable ones along the way.

+ well executed story - it's a well rounded mix of wholesome slice of life sets and a mysterious, futuristic and apocalyptic plot. eastward is a magnificent roller coaster ride and you'll witness many different intense emotions like friendship, camaraderie, love, loss, despair, fear and many more. fantastic stuff right there!

+ interesting world and decent world building. mysterious, dangerous, yet laid back and cozy.

+ gameplay is "bare bones" at first glance compared to modern video games with a basic action combat system and simple puzzles, which isn't an issue at all imo, but there will be more gameplay and puzzle adjustments over the course of the game. many people complaining about it, but i can't confirm the critique since the gameplay is simple, yet works so well. the controls are responsive and there are no major flaws. a dodge button would be great tho. if you don't care about an overly unique and modern gameplay, you'll be totally fine with eastward.

+ different weapons and special abilities for puzzles and combat.

+ somewhat challenging and unique boss fights. the bosses are quite creative in it's design and accordingly there is a lot of variety as well. in my opinion the boss fights are going to get more complex and strictly better throughout the game. the last ones are an absolute blast to battle!

+ the game is somewhat linear, but there will be freedom in exploring at times and it definitely pays off doing so. a little investment in backtracking is well worth your time, at least if you care about dialogues and for completionist reasons. do keep in mind, if you reach certain story milestones, you'll be locked out of past areas for the rest of the game.

+ gorgeous pixel art and graphics with a lot of love for details. eastward is an artistic masterpiece whit a stunningly detailed artstyle and excellent art direction. 

+ well crafted animations which are even more impressive, considering the minimalistic graphics.

+ well composed and sometimes hilarious soundtrack with calm and relaxing chip tunes and other retro themed osts, absolutely loving it.

+ many secrets and chests to be found - i wasn't able to find everything on my own in the first playthrough.

+ decent amount of upgrades, although upgrade materials take quite some time to obtain.

+ comfortable fast travel to speed things up, but honestly i've almost never used it since the game is so beautiful. everything's a pleasure to the eye and a delight to walk through, so simply delve into the affectionate details of your surroundings. usually it won't take long to reach your area of interest anyway.


[b]what felt debatable to me:[/b]

~ slow pacing since the game is heavily narrative driven with an abundance of dialogues, which i personally enjoyed a lot. the game is chill, providing one of the most relaxing gaming experience i've ever had and so it shouldn't be rushed anyway. could bother some people tho so i put it into the "debatable" section.

~ fantastic opening cutscene with a ghibli-esque art direction which let's you hope there are more of these, but sadly there won't. kinda missed potential.

~ eastward got an okay'ish sense of humor and some npcs are "tropes". it's adorable most the time - so i can't complain much, but some are questionable at best.


[b]what i disliked:[/b]

- i've had a bug in the shop menu which made it barely controllable sometimes, because the cursor gets constantly dragged into one direction. to fix this issue i've had to quit the shop screen and reopen it. nothing too serious tho.

- the stealth section wasn't that great and kinda infuriating at times. may be a personal issue.


10/10

120376073.review:
I had a very fun time playing this, it's a very well made game with a lot of love put into it.
The ability to switch between two characters whenever makes it really interesting. 
You can switch between using a frying pan, bombs or even guns to kill enemies or use magic powers to stun them or heal yourself. Both are used in puzzles most of the time.

The game has a lot of dialogue, so if you like that sorta stuff, I think this game is perfect. My only complaint is that you can't skip cutscenes, which makes the game a bit slow at times.

The artstyle is in my opinion this game's selling point. It's very well made, and while I might be a bit biased because I love pixel graphic games, it's still very beautiful.

 There's a bunch of secrets and other things to find too. And a whole turn-based RPG side-game, while I haven't finished that, it seems like it'd be fun to try.


The game's length is just right in my opinion. However, the difficulty is a bit too easy in my opinion, while it still can be hard.

Final verdict, this game is worth playing. If you don't like story-rich games or unskippable cutscenes though, then maybe this isn't for you.

120129900.review: I was so, so excited for this game. I watched the original trailer several times and the moment the game released I bought it. To be completely fair, I am aware of the very difficult development process the team went through, I respect them for sticking through to the end. That being said, I just wish they would have delayed the game's release. Between the awful progression system that is downright irritating at times, and the story that hops all over the place without reason or explanation, this game was a quick finish and uninstall for me. The amount of times I have gone to get a chest or something with my brand new ability, only for the game to say "No! You missed your chance and now you aren't allowed over there!" when the item is 1 screen away is infuriating. The progression is incredibly linear and forced. Speaking of the story, this game's story bounces all over the place, leaving so many question unanswered. Chapters 1 and 2 set up a decent amount of mystery and questions, the first 2 chapters are easily the best ones. But everything past there is a mess. Spoilers ahead: It is never explained how Alva died, which is kind of a big deal considering how important of a character she is, it is not explained how Isabel knew of Ester City (it is also not explained how she even got to Ester city due to the time fog bs), it is not explained why we fight 3 different Solomons (are they clones? That still wouldn't make sense since the oldest is the last one encountered despite also being the furthest back in time due to the Ester city loop), Ester city being in a time loop to begin with is not explained at all, the fact that John and Sam were magically inserted into said time loop. In all honesty, the villains were extremely boring because nothing about them was ever explained. The villains were simply there. The ending was such a cop-out as well because it was just another "Oh no! Child is dead! Boohoo so sad!" only for her to be reborn or something, which is just another thing that never gets explained. This game looks great but the story was just lazy and poorly written.

119997156.review:
EDIT: Completed the game 

(sorry for bad english, not native, might not review the game with a lot of details)

I'm okay with the difficulty, but the puzzles are the reason why I almost uninstalled it but in the end I tried not to do it. The more you explore, the more tricky the puzzle. At least for me who is not fan of puzzle games or game with a lot of puzzles btw. 

Some pixel based games rely too much on puzzle things, at least for some games that I've played. CrossCode is one of example that have a lot of difficult puzzles. Eastward is no exception. It also rely on puzzle that makes my broken controller give me tough time to solve it. I'm not saying the whole puzzle is difficult, its ez to solve but my broken controller makes it more difficult lol.

In some cases I just, "please no more puzzle, I just want to enjoy the story, I have a lot of unfinished backlogs" and that makes me not really enjoy the game.

But at the other side, I want to know how the story goes, so... yeah, love it or hate it I must finish it.

The story is sadly not explain a lot, it has strong story at first about 2-3 hours, then, meh and boring. It become little bit exciting when we arrived at some climax of its story. 

There are a lot of unexplained things such as how this become that (no spoiler sorry). Surely in the end, it ends cute but, still, I want to know about what exactly happened in its world.

To put it simply, the story is all about daily life of John and Sam in mining town, but things become bad after they try to leave the town. Mayor seems has some explanation about why they cant leave the town and it seems he also have some 'contract', but it leaves us as mystery until the end.

They should've explain the ending about how mayor etc conditions and not leave us questioning about it. 

The character writing is so strong, you will enticed to love or hate them. You will feel devs have gone a lot of hardships writing the characters, it has their own charms. 

Sadly the plot is not. It has a lot of potential but the linear story not exploring things that should've been exciting to explore.

For example, what happened to the world by explaining this and that (again, no spoiler). Why they're become like this. What is Miasma, why it exist. Some are quite exciting if it explained properly, but no.

The music is very good, reminds me to my own childhood playing old Nintendo or arcade games, but it has not much variations. In some cases, they just using the same music again and again for some scenes. Need strong memorable music to represent city or battle or sad scene tbh.

Eastward's visual is beautifully crafted for a pixel game. I like how dev set the lighting and choose the color for the game. Some colors explain how the dark and gritty the world is. It may be the best pixel game ever made in terms of visual.

The world is so much detailed and crafted with love. I loved it. It gives me a nuance that 'it would be good to live there' kind of things in some cases.

Devs should make DLC or expansion about this game's story to explain anything related to its world tbh. I dunno if they will do it or just move on to their next project.

Really look forward to your next project if you're not making expansion or DLC for this game.

You like action adventure game with strong character writing and visually good? Buy it.
You like story? Wait until it gets discounted.

I was torn on what type of review to leave this game but I think if given the chance to go back and not play it, that's what I would opt to do. Therefore, this will be a "Not Recommended" review.

The game starts off fairly simple in terms of combat and puzzle solving and never really progresses too much beyond that, only adding a few simple variations to your existing abilities. But what really makes this a "Not Recommended" title for me is the pacing and overall narrative. It takes forever to really get going, and only in the final act does the narrative make some degree of sense. Before that, you'll suffer through lots of aimless conversations and tangents that I wish I could have just skipped through.

Two positives standout to me - the boss battles are fun and fair to fight, and the art style/visuals is aesthetically pleasing as the soft palette and touch really makes the game a joy to look at. I just wish the rest of the package was as enjoyable.

119844306.review:
To be honest, I was really looking forward for this game, when I saw a the few trailers and a bit of gameplay, I was really interested for a long time, since I'm a huge Zelda and Earthbound fan, I was hyped for this game.
No gonna lie, the visuals are outstanding, the pixel art is absolute top without a doubt, the soundtrack is also charming here and there.

However, the Story and the Gameplay were NOT enjoyable for me at all.
The story starts alright, the problem is the pacing itself, It's extremely slow, when you reach the fifth hour or so you will be starving to see something new, It seriously feels like the story progresses painfully slow, characters doesn't help much either since the main protagonist doesn't offer anything and a few side characters barely appears, so the only character that really pushes the narrative is the little girl, thing is most of the stuff you will read are either jokes or silly dialogues so I wouldn't expect much on that regard as well, I understand they want to mimic Earthbound on this aspect, making silly and weird moments like that franchise I mentioned, but even Earthbound has a good pacing and UNDERSTANDS the player wants to have a good time but also to progress the story itself

Gameplay wise, It's also an issue, I wouldn't complain too much if the gameplay was good at least, but it wasn't the case either, It's fun the first hours but later on, It feels completely bland, the reason why it's simple, the gameplay itself doesn't evolve enough, the dungeons are too simple, as well as the battle system, the difficulty is not that high, not like it matters, especially on a game that seems aiming for a casual audience, but It feels way too simple that I'm not sure a casual player would be able to enjoy propertly.
Puzzles are extremely simple to the point it requires minimal effort, and so on...

I RARELY drop games, I actually detest to do so, but I had to do it because I wasn't enjoying my time, sure, the visuals are stupidly amazing, but to me, the story and the gameplay are vital, and It wasn't enough this time.

Solo he jugado 6h a este juego, me he aburrido las 6h. 

Las interacciones entre personajes se sienten muy forzadas, disfruto lo extravagante de otros juegos como Undertale, pero en este título me da la sensación de que los personajes te tienen que caer bien por su diseño, no por su diálogo y acciones, siendo en la mayoría de los casos extremadamente cliché o directamente pesados. 

El sistema de combate, inventario y crafteo son básicos y no aportan nada a la experiencia, creo que el título ganaría mucho si se centrase en los puzzles y en la narrativa. 

Hablando de los puzzles, tienen un enfoque demasiado condescendiente para mí, moviendo la cámara, cuando la mayoría son muy simples y no usan nada novedoso al género (Al menos en las primeras horas de juego).

Me gusta la música aunque hay poca novedad, el tema se repite tantísimas veces y con transiciones entre escenas TAN obvias y con TAN mal timing que lo he acabado detestando, algo que no me pasa a menudo con las bandas sonoras.

Destacaría que tiene un artwork maravilloso, la simulación entre zonas luminosas y oscuras es preciosa.

Entiendo que una vez el juego avance algunas de estas quejas irán perdiendo importancia y al parecer mucha gente lo ha disfrutado, pero la introducción se me ha hecho insufrible y si pudiera devolverlo, lo haría.

119530627.review:
First and foremost, Eastward is a narrative-driven game.  The story is always the focus, and it isn't one where you can make choices that impact the game.  I'm perfectly fine with that, but I think it's important to know this upfront before considering getting the game.  With that being said, I thoroughly enjoyed this game.  The story was intriguing and engaging.  Not all of your questions will be directly answered, but it isn't hard to piece the puzzle together yourself.  There were a couple writing decisions I don't entirely agree with (specifically the Uva storyline), but nothing that left me bewildered or too upset.  I do wish they had spent a little more time on the final chapter as well, it comes across as a rushed attempt to tie things together.  The ideas are there, expand on them all the way!

The game play elements are fun, if a little simple.  The combat takes almost a dungeon crawler-type approach, which is right up my alley (for example, it is at times reminiscent of The Legend of Zelda).  You have multiple weapons and abilities to use, and the weapons can be upgraded.  The boss battles are generally straightforward, their difficulty climbing appropriately as you progress.  I never felt blindsided by newly introduced enemies or mechanics, everything was very intuitive.  The graphics are fantastic, some of the best I've seen in the "modern pixel RPG" genre.  The music is also wonderfully composed and used to great affect.  It never felt too repetitive or annoying - in fact, I ended up buying the soundtrack on vinyl because I love it so much.

Truly above all, this is a game where you immerse yourself in the story, the characters, the world.  Every single person you encounter has a unique personality.  They have their own problems, worries, and wishes, often times communicated through just a few lines of text.  You absorb all of this when talking to them, and it encouraged me to talk to everyone I stumbled across, whether required or not.  The world building in this game is stupendous, and I enjoyed every second I got to spend exploring it.  You know when you finish a story (be it a book, TV show, or game) and it leaves you with a pit in your stomach, an empty feeling inside?  That's what happens when you've grown attached to that world and the characters, but their story is over and you don't know what to do next.  That's how I felt when I finished this game.  As I mentioned before, I think the story ending could be stronger, but everything else is well executed, so it earns my recommendation.

118762496.review:
i really want to like this game, and ive marked this as a positive review because i want to support a studio that went through a lot of turmoil to make this game, but there are some serious fundamental problems i think people should be aware of before they buy this game

the whole gameplay loop in general isnt particularly deep or engaging. the combat is uninteresting and clunky, the puzzles dont really require any brain power, and most of the quests youll be doing are fetch-quests with no real plot relevance.

the story is a mixed bag. it starts off very strong, the first two hours or so of this game are by far the best in terms of plot and gameplay, as there is a lot of mystery and intrigue built up around the end of the world and a town mayor who clearly knows more than he's letting on about what happened and a prison break, and a middle aged man seeing the outside world for the first time.

my main problem with this game is that all of that intrigue doesnt really go anywhere. the story after reaching the second location you arrive at after the tutorial zone becomes quite slow and meandering, and the whole end-of-the-world plot surrounding sam and her powers and connection to the MIASMA that is destroying the world is seemingly abandoned until pretty much the end of the game in favour of cute, but reasonably short adventures in one location that focus more on character writing than plot writing. thankfully character writing is one of the game's big strengths, but the pacing is ruined by this extended series of fetch quests.

i think the main problem is the game wanted it both ways, it wanted some cute soft-apocalypse slice of life stories, and a big exciting plot about saving a broken world from a cosmic evil, but the two never really converge. nothing in the slice of life stuff is ever interesting or exciting enough to really get invested into (as well as often being pretty padded and contrived, like [spoiler] a cooking contest where sam just gives away the main ingredient to the two world liars ive ever seen, whilst john does nothing about this obvious ruse [/spoiler] or [spoiler] the whole section with a bunch of monkeys on a train that are making awful movies that ruins all the suspense built up by the previous drama of an attack on a city and the wounding of a main character for the sake of a 3 hour long joke about how bad these movies are and an unreasonably long stealth sequence [/spoiler]), and the big saving the world story is never really explained well enough to make any sense. its hard for me to even explain what happens in this side of the narrative because i find the overarching plot of the game to be that confusing.

 theres a number of sections i think are meant to have narrative purpose, like [spoiler] exploring the older sections of the city that have been overtaken by the MIASMA, and its residents turned into mutated monsters, supposed to show the scale of the threat the world faces [/spoiler], or [spoiler] the final plot twist where it turns out the whole apocalypse was because of eugenics, sam is the sole survivor or a superhuman species that want to wipe out humanity in order to grow stronger, and the MIASMA apocalypse has actually happened hundreds of times over now [/spoiler], but all of those events SOUND much more interesting and engaging than they actually are, because none of it is ever really explained. the plot becomes a lot better after playing because all the superfluous sections are forgotten, and all the story is only explained in as much detail as a faded memory anyway, so you think back on it more fondly thinking theres a bunch of other cool stuff youve just forgotten about.

this is a good game to buy and play if you like strong character writing, slice of life adventures, fetch quests, and extremely pretty visuals, those are the games core strengths, but its definitely a 'brain-off' experience. you cant think about it too much or the whole thing will just fall apart. i look forward to pixpil's next game because i do think theres a lot of potential in this studio if they are given the time and budget they simply didnt have with eastward, but i do also badly wish this was the game that was advertised by the opening animation and trailers

118731246.review: If you like Zelda, this is for you. An amazing soundtrack and the characters are so easy to get attached too. The story is brilliant and the way that every new enemy and game mechanic is introduced is seamlessly integrated into the storytelling.  A real gem.

118730379.review:
Intro: For Legend of Zelda fans, you'll be right at home when you play this game. Salt is just rupees. You also have a bomb, and you also get variations of the bomb, and you get a lot of neat tools to help you explore. 


[b]Gameplay:[/b]
As I mentioned, this game heavily reminds me of the Legend of Zelda games. For example, to progress, you need to acquire a tool in order to proceed to the next part. Then the next part will heavily utilize this new tool.

[list]
[*][i] Camera:[/i] Very little camera controls because its a 2D Pixel art game. A way to control the camera is to move around your character or to start charging/aiming your weapon/ability since the camera moves to allow you to see more of where you're aiming.
[*] [i]Movement: [/i]There are no movement techniques like dashing or jumping, but there is a walk and run animation. You'll be running most of the time tho. Game scenes are small enough that it doesn't feel like a chore to move thru scenes, but to make traveling easier, the game provides a way to get to places real fast, like train rides and fast travel.
[*] [i]Combat: [/i]Combat possibly gets its inspiration from games like Legend of Zelda and Binding of Isaac. You have a normal and charged attack with your primary weapon, and a bomb, which is a LoZ staple item. As you progress, you acquire more weapons. Like LoZ, there is almost zero random encounters, which means enemies are predictably placed all over the map. Lastly, boss fights will always involve a trick, but they're intuitive, so just trust in your instincts and hope that you survive long enough to figure it out. 
[*] [i]Economy: [/i]Salt is the currency. Currency can easily be collected by grinding them from mobs. Drops become better as you move to the later chapters. Finding treasure will possibly allow you to have enough money for everything that you need. But if you find yourself poor, you'll have to go out of your way to grind, or find more treasure. There's no passive income mechanic in this game. There is an ingredient inventory, separated from the combat inventory. Combat inventory can be upgraded to contain more items. It is also very easy to run out of items after fighting thru a "dungeon" or during a boss fight, so you'll constantly want to get your inventory filled.
[*] [i]Physics Engine:[/i] There is a semblance of physics engine within the game because of the puzzles.
[*] [i]Saves:[/i] There are 6 available saves slot. On your first playthrough, you only get to use one save slot. After finishing the game, you're allowed to consume other slots to get back to things you missed out on, via the Chapter Select.
[*] [i]Minigames:[/i] Yes. There are MULTIPLE minigames embedded in the game. Earth Born is a major minigame within this game and it is referenced within the story itself, so make sure you play it a few times when you encounter it.
[*] [i]Bugs:[/i] I never encountered any bugs so far.
[/list]


[b]Music: [/b]
Music is made by Joel Corelitz, who also worked on Death Stranding and Halo Infinite.
Iron Carbine, Tatari, Heretic Frypan and Final Boss are my favorites, but To My Knight is also such a heartwrenching moment.
[list]
[*] [i]Number of Tracks: [/i]There are 72 tracks for this game. 
[*] [i]OST in Spotify: [/i]Yes. You can also purchase the soundtrack on Steam to show support.
[/list]


[b]Story: [/b]
There are interesting characters in the game that proceeded to be a major driver of the story. However, it seems that their story, motivations, and what happened to them, parallel to the protagonists' timeline, were only shown in glimpses and could be fleshed out in the form of a DLC or a separate story.

[list]
[*] [i]Voice Acting: [/i]SFX grunts and hyahs. No voice acting for dialogue.
[*] [i]Multiple Endings:[/i] No. Only one ending. Linear progression.
[*] [i]Narration:[/i] It is told in the eyes of the protagonist(s). Small, obvious, and targeted exposition, which means the environment only shows the story when it wants to do so. Minimal lore is told wordlessly through the environment. While the protagonist is usually silent, he does speak and is able to have conversations with other people. It's just that none of the conversations is apparent to us.
[*] [i]Pacing:[/i] A huge portion of your gameplay is spent in the same place from Chapter 3 to Chapter 6. Then afterwards, you'll zoom past everything. This is possibly because I did not have much attachment to the worlds they provided and I just wanted to get them people over with.
[*] [i]Worldbuilding:[/i] A lot of suspension of disbelief is needed. Salt does not seem like a reliable currency. How do they get dough underground? Why is there only one railway line? 
[/list]


[b]Lifespan: [/b]
I would say that after your first playthrough, the magic is gone. Boss Fights will be easier since you understand how their tricks work.
[list]
[*] [i]Chapter Select/New Game+ : [/i]Yes, Chapter Select allows this. Food, ingredients, max health, and certain upgrades are kept intact. 
[*] [i]DLCs[/i]: This game was released on Sep 2021. There seems to be no news of a DLC.
[*] [i]Duration: [/i]How long to beat lists this as 26.5 hours for the completionist duration. I took around 39 hours to beat this. Will possibly take more if you include Earth Born.
[/list]


[b]Graphics:[/b]
The 2D artstyle is a welcome sight for those who wants to play these pixel art games. It's definitely gonna attract you with how beautiful it is. But there's a lack of it for the worldbuilding that you'll just have to imagine how it actually looks like. Also, the scene transitions between maps for cities might distort your idea of how big or small the place really is.
[list]
[*] [i]Graphic Settings:[/i] No Borderless Window support; Art is upscaled at 1080p, and an Oct 2021 update has introduced options for the upscaling method. Very minimal graphical settings due to 2D nature.
[*] [i]Lighting: [/i]Dynamic Lighting exist, because some abilities produce light. Lighting is also used to provide different moods to locations, such as day/night cycles, imminent world-ending danger, and so on.
[*] [i]2D/2.5D/3D[/i]: 2D. 
[/list]


[b]Achievements: [/b]
There are hard achievements for this game, particularly, the Minigame achievements. There's also the Treasure Hunter achievement that will consume a lot of time and effort.
[list]
[*] [i]Missable Achievements[/i]: Yes. I suggest consulting a guide for Treasure Hunter to make sure you don't miss out on treasures. A 2nd playthrough of the game will definitely happen if you miss out on treasures. And there's no in-game guide telling you how many you've missed in a certain chapter.
[/list]


[b]Accessibility: [/b]
[list]
[*][i] Varying Difficulty:[/i] None. 
[*][i] Controller Support[/i]: Yes, with DS4/DS5 Support.
[*][i] Subtitles[/i]: Yes, and these subtitles are different from the text in the speech bubbles.
[/list]


[b]Multiplayer:[/b]
[i] No multiplayer support.[/i]


Overall, I really like this game because the worldbuilding is fantastic and it leaves a lot of open areas to make it a new IP. Hopefully, that happens one day. The music really got me into loving it. The BGM during fights just gets my blood pumping and vibing at the same time.

Story, overall, is good. There are things I wanted them to expand on, so I feel a desire to explore more of the world. However, this is a linear game, so not a lot of things are shown. 

There is an emphasis on trains, for some reason, but you never get to bond with the train. It's really just a vessel that takes you from one place to another.

There is a negligent moment of putting "explore the world again once you get new tools" on the tooltips. But make sure you reexplore dungeons once you get new shiny tools. Either that or mark areas you've couldn't explore because there's a tool/ability that you don't have.

So I do recommend playing this game.

118475718.review:
If you’ve ever gone to a bookstore and picked out the novella with the prettiest cover, congratulations! You’ve likely had the same experience as playing this convoluted ass DDLC-aper/Zelda-grubber masquerading as a good time. Eastward is the gaming equivalent of that time Buddy tops his Pop-tart, M&M, and marshmallow pasta with maple syrup in Elf. Legit, I’ve listened to schizophrenic homeless men get their point across better than this, and that’s shout outs to Earl. Even my geriatric grandmother has enough sense to not waste my time with this much fuckshit before handing me some red, cash-filled envelopes.

Hyperbole aside, Eastward is a game that plods along to the rhythm of an admittedly fantastic soundtrack, however encumbered it is by the weight of its influences, its mediocre gameplay, and most of all, its overwrought plot. I’ve read beaucoup summaries on what the fuck is going on with the story in writing this little review, and after reading my fifth wildly divergent fan theory, I can scientifically conclude that no one actually knows. I know it’s hard to cast aside the game’s colorfully beatific art style, but if you care at all about the 20 odd hours you will never get back on this shit, I am begging you to throw cake on the Mona Lisa and run the other way.

Eastward unapologetically employs a maximalist writing style in execution of the tale it seeks to tell, building in a number of restrained, meditative moments to evoke what clearly expressed story beats would in any other. This is a method common to some of the greatest stories ever told in a multitude of mediums: show, don’t tell. But when you put it in a video game like this, you run the risk of leaving little game left to be played if you don’t also build in compelling gameplay. Eastward treats that risk like a 50-foot ramp to skate down in a grocery store cart without any of the fun that suggests. What's more, by centering the story around a child and her mute caretaker, the game takes a considered choice in taking an ignoramus' perspective on the complicated subjects it grapples with, putting players in an awkward place where there are many questions with no clear answers.

The lion's share of the game is spent caught between droll conversations with an all too expansive cast and mediocre Zelda-styled dungeons. You literally only need to get from point A to point B; there is little to no challenge to any of it, and the lack of creative ideas to bring to the table of a long existing tradition of play dulls the impact of whatever execution intended. Here, playstyle fails to complement story, both existing in vacuums to the detriment of the other. It wasn't until the final two chapters that the game started introducing fresh concepts that provided a genuine challenge, and by then, they had come so late that they came off more like afterthoughts than the complementary elements they should've been.

I actually feel shitty coming down so hard on this one because it is very clearly a child of Earthbound and Mother 3, two games I hold dear to my heart as all time favorites. But if Eastward wants to be taken seriously (and it definitely does), then it's gotta be taken to task for some critical errors in its delivery.
