118177810.review:
This is a game that shows how much care and dedication it took to be made. It excels in presentation, provides content for more than 20 hours and, even though the core mechanics may be too simplistic or unpolished for some, they do not stain the overall experience too much, and lets the game be enjoyed as its own thing.

The art style is stunning. Aside from enemies and a few obstacles, I don't recall any sprite as being notoriously reused throughout the game. Also, as another commenter made me notice, every NPC has their own sprites. Moreover, some of the main tools, like the fridge and the stove, are so well-presented that made me wish I had a physical miniature of them.

The soundtrack is arguably one of my top-three favorites ever in gaming. Even though it's all retro-styled, the quality that modern tools provide shines in it, merging the nostalgic feel that the retro synths evoke with the melancholy tone of a post-apocalyptic setting. It's surprising how some quite frequent tunes, like Home, Weather Talk and Cooking are such masterpieces despite their brevity, raising the annoyance threshold of having to listen to them over and over again quite a bit. Other longer themes like Eastward, Rust and Strange Quest are top tier bangers.

Overall, the presentation manages to create that sensation of longing that most memorable pieces of entertainment achieve, where you crave for a bit of that weird beauty and fantasy in your real life. The art crew did a really good job in making this pixelated world come to life and be remembered.

The story is a typical hero's journey, but the context where it takes place makes it quite enjoyable nevertheless. The world is interesting, the characters feel alive, and the underlying lore, although not entirely clear, combines a few ideas (time-travel, dystopian future, life and death) in a very interesting way. I presume that the writers had a very personal idea or something they wanted to say to the world and delivered it through this game. And despite the use of clear references, still came out as something original in the end, at least in my opinion.

My only complaints would be the excess of sexist humor and the randomness of one of the chapters, which, as several other commenters have pointed out, appears more as a filler than as a continuation of the story.

I feel that the criticism has been a bit unfair for what the game is worth. I had seen some trailers before buying it and, in my experience, offered just what it promised me, no more, no less: a beautiful pixel-art adventure, with an ambitious world-building. The only thing that I didn't consider was that the soundtrack was ridiculously good, so that came as an extra to me. Maybe it's not worth the full price, but if you catch it on sale and are a fan of retro-inspired adventure games and music, give this one a try.

A 7.5/10 if I ever saw one.

117842036.review:
An incredibly charming game held back by its focus on its story

Eastwards is set in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity is currently rebuilding after some unknown events caused a large scale collapse of society despite being incredibly technologically advanced. The various towns, cities and settlements explored throughout the story have a variety of cultural and historical influences from their former selves which make a unique setting to explore. The devs even put a full scale 1980's RPG in the game (in the form of a arcade machine you occasionally find) for the player to explore and try which adds probably one of my favourite bit of side content that I've ever played in a game, it even has a New Game+ which adds a bunch more content to the already optional side-game.

It has a gorgeous art style that is fun to look at, fun and unique characters that make you want to explore and talk to every NPC in town and an interesting story that stretches over a well made and expansive world.

My biggest problem though with Eastwards is that despite having all that, it just decided not to do anything with it. There are no little lore dumps that explains the world that they developers have created (which it could certainly use). There are only a handful of side quests to do across 8 chapters and all of them are either hidden or not pointed out to the player making them difficult to find or complete and the combat remains to the very end of the story to be incredibly basic offering little challenge to the player despite the fact that the mechanics to do so are there.

I have these criticisms as someone who went out of their way to get all the achievements in this game, which was by and large a very painful experience. Everything in this game is missable, and I mean everything. From chests to food recipes, shop sold consumables, to ingredients. There is no way to go back and find any of these things past a certain point and that point is frequently the end of the chapter. With the exception of the recipes/ingredients they won't even tell which of those you are missing, just that you are in fact missing them. They later added a chapter selection (after the 1.0 release) after you beat the game for the first time but they don't tell you that until you get there, for those who care that was a great thing to add

Despite those things I think Eastwards is an incredible game, especially for the first game made from this studio as far as I can tell at least. I'd recommend giving it a shot

117814341.review:
[SPOILER-FREE REVIEW]

It hurts my heart to write this review this way...but i can't recommend it.

I bought the game right on release, and you see on my hours that i have not played it for hundreds of hours. But it took me weeks to finish the game. Not because it was particularly hard...But because it frustrated me massively.

It starts extremely strong. Super super good story writing, it really chained me to my PC / SteamDeck. But roughly at half-time of the game, it loses much quality. To me it feels like that some extraordinary storywriter wrote the beginning of the game, had to leave and some intern picked up where he left. There is so much filler that is absolutely disconnected from everything and just feels displaced. Seems like a waste of time and is just plain boring and / or annoying.

The game builds much on top of it's combat system, but that combat system is clunky and frustrating at times. There are "riddles" that have to be completed on timers and those timers become tighter and tighter, but the whole combat / movement system doesn't allow for frustration-free movement.

Then out of nowhere the story picks up again with it's major plot while you were in a silly filler-episode. And so many things weren't really explained well enough. Character development is basically non-existent.

It is a beautiful game, visually stunning and in theory i would recommend it within µ-seconds. But i had to force myself to play this game to the end. I lost interest so many times, i got frustrated so many times, i was annoyed so many times. All that made me finish that game was the hope that i would return to it's brilliance of the beginning and that it would catch itself and fix everything...It didn't. But i payed for it, so i played it.

So....this is a beautiful game, that has a very very interesting plot and some charming characters. But i just fails to deliver anything deeper. It fails to build these characters up and develop them, it fails to make any meaningful transition from one plotchapter to the next, it fails to use it's systems to it's advantage because it forces you to do sometimes pixel perfect and extremely tight-timed actions on top of a clunky combat / movement system.

I really wanted to like this game...

Looks awesome, sounds great, but narrative is terrible.
Gameplay is: You read 2 hours and play 30 minutes. Repeat.
If what the characters have to say was important that won't be a problem. The thing is that everything they speak is redundant. The game starts with a story that promises a great adventure (first 4 hours or so) but later you get lost in the lives of hundreds of characters with no good motivations. You spend hours reading their blabbering about the most mundane stuff that won't go anywhere and then the blabbering stops and that character is useless forever.
There are people who enjoy this type of things, but I can't care less about reading 15 slow minutes about the culinary tastes of an NPC that it won't matter in any way or form.
Imagine if every game FORCED you to listen to every NPC without being able to skip their dialogue. Well, that's how Eastward manages it's story and world.

The gameplay is nice but robotic. You just hit things. Do some little puzzles and that's it, you never get more interesting mechanics to play with.

One amazing thing is the number of character design and animations. The backgrounds. Everything artistic is perfect. But art can only carry the game so far.

I can't see me finishing this game.

117335719.review:
Overall this game's positives far outshine the few negatives and create a memorable experience.

For me the biggest draw is the story. The little girl Sam is relentlessly cute and makes every scene she's the focus of great, and the other characters have fun personalities as well. But don't worry, this rollercoaster has its share of dark moments as well. There's very good worldbuilding and a good sense of mystery, right up to the end.

It helps that the visuals and music are some of the best I've seen in a while. I mean, just look at it!

Gameplay is pretty standard Zelda-style fair. It starts out kinda slow, and takes longer than it should to introduce new gameplay elements and tougher combat, but once it gets going it fleshes itself out pretty well. I kinda get the impression that the level and boss designers were learning as they went because there's a sharp uptick in gameplay quality by the last few chapters.

One hint: Be sure to grab everything on your first pass though because there's frequent points of no return.

There's also a cute game-within-a-game of a turn based RPG. Despite initially appearing ironically-oversimplified, it's quite fleshed-out and has a fairly clever gimmick--a 7 day time limit to make your heroes strong enough to face the final boss. So it's ultimately about time/resource management more than anything else. It wouldn't really stand up on its own, but it doesn't have to.

117235517.review:
[quote=Edmund Burke]Beauty is the promise of happiness.[/quote]

You should always be extra suspicious around pretty-looking games. Are they good, or do they just LOOK good? Are the reviews good because people enjoyed the game, or they FELT that they need to give the game a positive review? Is the wondrous look a sign of supreme attention to detail, or a pile of wasted resources, diverted from not working on the other, more important parts?

I thought, hey. Maybe this one will be different. Maybe this one actually delivers on the promise, and finally marries the ingenuity of indiedev with the unchained, freeflowing capabilities of modern visual artists.

Nope, it doesn't. Or maybe it does, but the flaws and the general flatness I saw in the first 90 minutes drove me away, and I'll never know.

What's good about this game? The writing's not terrible, and the rest you can see on the trailer. It's a visual affair first and foremost, down to the UI. And that's all I have to say on that topic.

Now let's get to the bad parts. The first thing that annoyed me is that even in those 90 minutes, it was never clear as to where, or why, I was supposed to go. I quickly caught on that I'm supposed to open the map screen and look at the quest marker - and you'd better do that, because for the most part you're left to your own devices. To be fair, not always, but even then you're given more of an idea rather than specific directions. And sometimes nothing at all.

Then, there's the NPC dialogue. Every time you walk up to someone, your characters line up facing them and the screen shrinks in that letterbox effect. In classic JRPGs, such as Mother 3, this was a signifier or an important conversation; you're entering cutscene zone. Here (almost) every conversation is like this. It's not such a bad thing, if it wasn't for the fact that sometimes you're thinking that there's a follow up to this important part - so you talk to the NPC again, only for the whole letterbox thing to happen again; if your characters say something, this is also being repeated. 

The combat? It's there. I've seen worse. Feels a little like classic Zelda. It's passable, but not very enjoyable.

The characters. Oh man. There's John and Sam. John never speaks - you can't even respond to conversations in a "yes/no" kind of way - and Sam is your typical magical overly excited little girl. I've seen this one too many times to treat this seriously. What's cool is that all other characters have clearly different sprites, with little animations to boot - but they still didn't feel particularly interesting. Easy to tell from each other, but still somewhat interchangeable. What a shame.

And then there's ... a game within a game, which seems to be a big deal for Sam and her friends. It's a classic Dragon Quest-style JRPG. Not only it's not particularly fun, but also you know what I do when I want to play a different game? I play a different game. This made sense back in the early 90s, when we were all stuck without internet with just a few game cartridges. 

Maybe the game does get better, more interesting; or maybe it gets worse. I don't know. Would you like to find out? Be my guest. Me, I decided to follow a siren song of an animated trailer and I'm a little bitter about my own foolishness. If you decide to follow my footsteps, please at least know what you're getting into. Hope that helps.

117038474.review:
I feel like I was duped. I had looked forward to Eastward for a long time; I think it had been on my wishlist for years. Finally I decided to try it out... the reviews were in... they were very good. I had seen the beautiful graphics, the great opening anime, and had heard the soundtrack. Everything seemed great. 

Then I played it. At first I was disappointed that the animation was JUST for the intro and not interspersed with the story... I thought there would be cutscenes that were animated... but that's a small thing. So what if they invested in a pretty cartoon to sell the game? 

Then I was disappointed with the main character... our silent protagonist who has no opinions no matter how good or bad a situation is. The guy who follows around a little girl who will seemingly do anything anyone suggests for no real reason. He has literally no character development, and with the small exception of people saying he liked to drink before he met Sam (maybe he still does?), we have no other background about it. Finding Sam, or perhaps a little before we find Sam, might make for a reasonable starting point... but instead the game picks up well after. You don't see how finding a little girl changes his life. You don't see why he'd want to take in a little girl when there is seemingly no reason he would. This is emblematic of the story as a whole: it just sort of meanders around without really making any kind of sense. 

Then I was disappointed with combat. It is terrible and ubiquitous. There is no way to dodge or block, there is no challenge yet somehow everything is mildly annoying (enemies that sit in a spot, impede your progress, and respawn if you  wait too long, for example), the puzzles (only found in combat areas) are also simple to understand and somehow annoying to execute, switching between characters and weapons is clunky, and I need to open a menu to use a healing item. The boss battles are neat, but they are few and far between and certainly not innovative. 

Then there was the pacing... all of this might be fine if it wasn't broken up into these huge, bland chunks. First you have a huge block of time running around a map (often changing screens so quickly you wonder why they bothered to make the area you were just in! I literally blinked when going upstairs and missed a map in between the place I came from and the place I was heading to... WHY BOTHER MAKING THAT MAP AT ALL?!) to talk to NPCs who had poor dialog that is often totally irrelevant... and conveniently for the story... John can't talk or think or express ideas to anyone. He just keeps going on quests because Sam thinks it's a good idea I guess. Then you get the quest and it is a huge block of going through screens, fighting the same enemies over and over (sometimes multiple times on the same map). 

I didn't even feel good when I got a reward: found a chest that will let me get a heart if I find three more chests (who cares?), more salt to buy ingredients to cook things for my very limted backpack (why bother?), I can finally afford an upgrade to my weapon (too bad the difference isn't noticeable), finally I have found more tokens to get trinkets for the game within the game (oh FFS!). Loot is the bread and butter of RPGs. You should find loot and feel rewarded, gain an upgrade and feel more capable... somehow the game even fails to deliver on that fundamental point! None of it means anything so why bother? 

It's all so amazingly tedious. It literally put me to sleep while playing. I only made it to the combat portion of chapter three, but from everything I've read nothing gets better. I don't feel rewarded by the combat, by finding loot, or by learning more of this story that could be immediately ended if John would only speak one sentence. Instead we are running errands for strangers for no discernible purpose! Why did we even need a job? I have enough salt to buy every ingredient from every shop in town! 

This game could have been so much more... without combat it might have had a great story (like To The Moon) with tighter pacing. If they really needed it to be interactive they could have made it a puzzle game and just cut the combat, maybe interspersing the puzzles within the narrative portions again to break things up. They could have made it more survival oriented where you are constantly moving east on a deadline: something is chasing you and you need to prepare, gather what people and supplies you can, and go before it is too late. Instead it's just so fake: all aesthetics and absolutely no substance. I feel like they invested heavily in the art, music, cartoon, and reviewers; they tricked me and it is too late to get a refund.

116849608.review:
I'll start out pretty positive and spoiler-free. The music is fantastic and really grabs your focus while you take in the vivid detail of the visuals in and of themselves. The gameplay is on the easier side, which I'm assuming is good for more casual players with some interesting mechanics in it. Putting aside my personal love of old-school RPGs and developed games within games, The Earth Born game is fun, great retro RPG that has clever, yet challenging mechanics interwoven into the outer game via item collectibles. I'd recommend watching a little early gameplay if you can. The game has good bones, but it really falls apart around halfway from a lack of focus, narrative and worldbuilding. I'd personally give it a 7.5/10 based on it as a whole.
*SOFT NON-PLOT RELATED SPOILERS*
[spoiler]The lack of world-building doesnt make you feel like there's as massive a world as what's should be perceived. It's almost as if there was no greater world, game-wise and development-wise, imagined outside of what was drawn in the trailer. The combat, despite being fun, can be too easy and relatively simplistic compared to other games in it's genre, even near the end when things ramp up. If you could roll or strafe in this, you'd be unstoppable with one hand. Good, immersive game mechanics pop up near the end that you don't get any time to get comfortable before it's over with.   If there was more to the story and world to give, then there'd be room for it, but it feels like 2 games sharing half a plot with another game in the middle that's ironically more thought out in some ways than the game itself (imo but it's a simpler game after all). The narrative weakness is what hurts the game the most. The lack of a real, fleshed-out bond between the two characters you're using. One is not really a character, but more of a plot device/game mechanic. There's no Lee/Clementine (The Walking Dead) bond or Joel/Ellie (The Last of Us) bond made here, despite an uncanny resemblance to Joel that could've really helped here.  It has the bones of something bigger, in how everything thematically could've connected better but it all falls apart because after a while, you have so many questions that never get answered before the plot is hijacked and you'll never get back to the greater "why" and "how" of the events before it's all over. I came in wondering where the road would take them and what would be answered, but left really feeling nothing from not only the questions left unanswered, but left unasked, and how none of it felt like it even mattered in the end. [/spoiler]
*HARDER PLOT RELATED SPOILER WITH A SIDE OF RAMBLING*
[spoiler] After Greenberg. The game sets itself up pretty well with the whole "surrogate father/adoptive chosen child daughter" angle and teases a Happily ever after for them before ripping it away in one of the worst (best) ways possible whilst revealing the why is something much deeper, advanced and potentially caused by said surrogate daughter. But when it get's to New Dam City, and they try to get deeper and worldbuild, it really backsteps.  I can let the child gambling slide if the government can let EA do it. I can let the town busywork slide because it's nice to be in a static location for a while. I can cook three silly-ass dishes for some soft-ass casino boss because I wanna see where all of this leads, but when you essentially rush to the end and have every character in-between be a plot device that eludes to a history never thoroughly explained in the game, I can't ignore that.

It's here along with the fact that every single character in this game has quite a bit of dialogue that you really see the weakness in John's silence and how, with rarely even an inner thought expressed, you can't really empathize with him as a guardian or even as a person. Sam talks for him every chance there is and every NPC is written to compliment him to make up for his lack of a soul to the point where Uva's dog has more personality. He isn't there to help Sam grow as a person, he doesn't have an opinion to run counter to anyone's nor is he isn't even there to be as a sufficient placeholder for the player. If you aged up Sam a few years and reworked the game mechanics, I don't think he'd have a purpose thematically. Even his backstory flashback is technically Sam remembering being found. They could've at the very least said that he gave her the name Sam. It would've given her a good primary anchor to the identity of "Sam", could've served as the foundation for their relationship and why she's extra insistent on being called by that, because it was the first thing given to her, by the first person she ever knew. 

I wouldn't have minded Isabel and Alva's thing hijacking the plot so much if they would've went into greater depth on the past and how they're connected to it other than the stuff after when you fight Isabel, which I feel wasn't supposed to be a first time you fight her given that she's pretty advanced compared to other boss fights and the context of her dialogue during the battle would imply that she fought him before.  (and is wasted multiple boss fight potential imo). 

I'm sorry but if one character does something stupid despite their intelligence and it changes the plot from "stopping the world-ending miasma from destroying other towns full of innocent people to force evolution like the one we just came from and learning why its here" to "no time for questions about any established history, civilization or people before all of this, or even how Mother's personal account of things, just find Isabel and Alva", then that's weak storytelling.
I'm disappointed Earth Born didn't have greater parallels to the game given the setup. With as many locations that were in it, I thought there would be corresponding locations in real world. Big missed opportunity.

If they had a lot of ideas that couldn't be realized because of powers beyond their control then I understand, but by the time I hit Monkollywood, I got a little frustrated with having too many questions that not only was nobody answering, but nobody was asking.
I have two characters; one that denies her past so fervently that it interferes with any exposition, is never explained in-depth nor asked about even when people who knew Mother pop up, and one that's more robot than the robots and essentially exists to chaperone the ultimate lifeform whilst spurring no emotional or storyline development in the process.
 I have Solomon, who's interestingly tied into the game, and teases you with potentially answering some questions about Mother's history but never delivers. I have another train full of movie-making monkeys out of nowhere that's fun but furthers nothing given that the Solomon connected doesn't explain a lot. 
I have no consistency when time distortion is introduced to the story. I have a subtlely advanced yet underwhelming mythical city purported to be the nexus of this evolutionary philosophy stuck in time, but can't accurately explain it's history, citizens nor the actual fruits of the starting humanity over and over  again to never produce a truly advanced society even after countless clones have been created. 
The end really falls flat imo with a lot of questions just left hanging and leaves you with a lot of flowery, slightly pretentious words about how it's underwhelming ending righted the lost time and saved the world. Since Sam and John don't have a lot of special moments for us to see them develop their relationship, the result lacks impact. I rarely feel nothing after a game, especially a game I actually liked but this one did it. 

There's so much space in-between New Dam and Ester that could've been explored, like Margolari's hometown. 

I'm tired of talking so I'm leaving it at this: It has good bones, but it's just that. No meat when you want substance. No brains when you want depth. You look past the aesthetics and perceive something less.[/spoiler]

116806724.review:
[b]Eastward[/b] is a text-heavy, story-driven, action-adventure game.

When I say 'text-heavy' I mean it. I've seen users unironically say that this should be tagged as a visual novel. While I don't share that sentiment, I can not deny how much dialogue is in this game.

For me, this game is just barely a recommend. This review is more like an essay/tangent, so skip to "Closing Thoughts" after reading "Gameplay" if you're not interested in all that.

[h1]Premise[/h1]
You play as John, a dopey-looking guy (if you exclude his mugshot in which he looks positively badass) who lives his life as a digger in the underground town of Potcrock Isle. An undefined amount of time before the game begins, John finds a girl during one of his excavations who he names Sam. They start living together as a sort of family, with John becoming Sam's guardian.

The game starts off with some daily life until stuff happens which kicks off the adventure. You get to follow John and Sam's adventure in which they meet a wide variety of people and visit several interesting places.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game is devided into "story" areas where you can talk to NPCs and interact with the world, and "dungeon-esque" areas where you fight enemies and solve puzzles. These can overlap, but rarely do so.

In the dungeon areas you can switch between John and Sam with the tap of a button. John does the physical fighting and other heavy-lifting while Sam supports with her strange powers. You can also split up and control John and Sam seperately, a feature used for puzzles. John and Sam get additional equipment/abilities as the game progresses. Dungeons have several semi-hidden chests with extra goodies, such as gear parts, that you use to upgrade John's weapons. This made the loot feel worth going after and made finding these very fun.

There's a small cooking part of the game in which you pick a few ingredients and make food that you can use for healing and additional effects. Unlike most cooking systems, there is no general "mistake" food you can make. All "unknown recipes" are actual food items that you can discover by experimenting. This made cooking something actually fun. I was surprised by this.

The other half of the game is the NPCs and the world you interact with. Not a single NPC sprite is reused for two characters. There's an absurd amount of care put into the world and the characters, and when you're not bashing enemies in dungeons, you'll be experiencing this world.

[h3]Earth Born[/h3]
There's a game within this game called Earth Born that you can play in certain shops. This is a simple turn-based RPG in which you go on a quest to slay the Demon King.

You have 7 days to power up your party and collect items and gear before you take him on. When you die, your party resets to level 1 and you lose all your items. The meta game is about finding a route and strategy on which places to visit in order to get the most powerful party within the 7 days. 

Earth Born isn't the main selling point of Eastward or anything, but I found it to be a fun distraction. It's more fun than Eastward itself in some aspects, which is very funny to me.

[h3]Missables[/h3]
This game is missable item galore. To echo my TitS review:
[i]"Are you a completionist? Stay away. STAY AWAY!"[/i]

Locations are one-off and are not able to be revisited. This includes dungeons which have hidden chests. Shops have ingredients that are also missable and by extension that makes recipies and dishes missable. Some of Sam's ABILITIES are missable. Side-quests are missable. Do I need to keep going?

I managed to keep my completionist demon locked away for this game, but I put this section here because I know how this can ruin a game for some people (including myself most of the time).

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is slow-paced and takes a while to get going. Even when it does, some parts feel like padding. Despite this though, there were a few hooks that kept me interested. What was Sam doing deep underground, encased in that orange cocoon? Why does she have strange powers? Who is the image of herself she keeps seeing? Will John ever say anything? Chapter 2 spoilers: [spoiler]What is the miasma? What is the purpose of the freaky human lab?[/spoiler]

Interesting things indeed, and good questions! Then when I got to the ending I went: "Ah. It's one of those stories."

By which I mean that while some of the questions you accumulate indeed have answers, most of them don't. It really feels like mystery for the sake of mystery. There are no answers.

I also didn't get attached to any of the characters other than John and Sam, which is something I see as a failure of the writing. There were clearly attempts at endearing certain characters to the player, but something about the writing and pacing made this not work.

[h3]John and Sam[/h3]
I say I got attached to John and Sam, but that's mostly by virtue of playing as them for literally the whole game. John is already down a few points by being a silent protagonist who rarely emotes. The moments where you actually get to see John express any kind of emotion are so rare they can be counted on one hand, and even then they are so subtle you can miss them if you look away for even a second. Sam on the other hand, is a bright and cheerful girl who openly expresses her feelings and thoughts whenever she gets the impulse to do so. When no other NPC is available to do the talking, she's the one that does it.

I liked their relationship, but not enough was done with it. There are several hints that John are a bit clueless about how to care for a child. Minor chapter 3 spoilers: [spoiler]For example, Sam is completely barefoot for the first 3 chapters. Another character gives her red boots to wear at this point, which she exitedly runs up to John to show off. "John! John! Look John, boots!" John awkwardly looks off to the side and scratches his head. It hadn't even crossed his mind that he should've given her some shoes. She's been running around underground on cold hard rocks with her bare feet. I'd like to think he feels some shame.[/spoiler] He also brings her into dungeons which crawl with dangerous monsters, and leaves her out of sight on several occasions.

But he gave her a shirt to wear, keeps her well-fed and rested, and gives her piggyback rides when she's tuckered out. He's not cruel, just clueless. On Sam's end, it's clear that she's fond of John. She doesn't blame him for anything and is his biggest fan.

I found their relationship rather endearing, which is why it's such a pity it's not focused on. The journey should've been about them settling into their relationship in addition to the overarching plot. This would've also made the ending parts even better.

The final panel of the game would've been a perfect opportunity for John to break his silent protagonist trope as well.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
I feel like I'd wrong this game if I didn't bring this up. This is the best part of Eastward. It has some of the best pixel art I've ever seen. Towns are intricately drawn and unique-looking. As previously mentioned, not a single NPC is reused, they are all unique. Animations are fluid and abundant. Lighting is used to great effect. Truly, an absurd amount of work has gone into this part of the game, and I can't deny how good it looks.

[h1]Closing thoughts[/h1]
I had fun, but several things bog this game down. Pacing that's mostly slow but sometimes is all over the place, filler sidequests that are actually the main quest, missables, filler CHAPTERS, hit and miss writing, story with very few answers, missables...

If you like a slow-paced story with an interesting world to learn about, talking to NPCs, and a dash of beat-em up style fighting and puzzle-solving, you'll probably have a good time.

If you're in it for the action-adventure gameplay, dislike long dialogues/cutscenes and MISSABLES, you'll have a terrible time.

116802355.review: Wonderful atmosphere even though I haven't played the games it was nostalgic for, but the love that it has for those games really came through.

116801407.review:
Now Eastward is a game that I think deserves a bit more attention than it did on its initial launch. It takes so much from classic Nintendo titles, like the 2d Zeldas and Earthbound especially, and jrpg elements scattered throughout.

The plot in a nutshell is basically a father-child adventure story that takes you to enclosed communities, open forests, thriving cities, and more as you trek to your destination eastwards. The plot on its own is solid enough but it is greatly enhanced with the inclusion of well written characters, all having their own unique personalities and motivations. The game's best and most emotional story beats come from how the cast interacts with eachother.

The visuals and music here are just breathtaking in each of their own ways. You can tell how much influence of those retro rpg titles have had on the whole making of the game. And yet, obvious influences aside, the game still manages to make itself stand out in both of those regard.

Now the gameplay overall is the part of the game I have the most mixed feelings about. On one hand it feels really good when you are just casually exploring and solving puzzles. The puzzles being very well crafted mind you. But when it comes to combat, the game really falls apart as it always felt like the least polished aspect of the whole product.

I consider Eastward to be a hidden gem of modern indie rpgs with how gorgeous the artsyle is, varied soundtrack, great cast, and its all wrapped around with a bittersweet story about love.

8.1/10

116749407.review:
To be completely honest... I really loved this game. It just really grapped me and made me want to keep playing. And I will explain why further down, but just know, that the criticism I'm going to give the game didn't really matter to me in the long run, and I would honestly recommend anyone try this game, if you can handle the very slow pace and a lot of dialogue. Just please complete the first chapter or 2 before you start judging the whole thing. As I will explain later it does have ups and downs and the first chapter is not what the whole game is gonna be like.

So first of all the art, music, dialogue and sound design is all top notch. The sprites are all distinct and no character looks totally the same. They really put a lot of effort into having a very wide cast of colorful and weird characters, of all shapes and sizes. I really loved all the characters  especially in chapter 2-5. 
The gameplay is very standard, but does evolve over time. I wouldn't say it's great but it functions for what the game is trying to accomplice. 
The puzzles are not too hard, they start out very easy and get "harder" but I was never stuck on any part. The boss fights was all pretty standard, but none was horrible to go through. 
One minor point is that i feel like a certain boss got repeated way too many times. 
I really enjoyed the boss before the endgame boss the most, cause it wasn't like any of the others, which you can mostly just spam attack and damage tank. I didn't feel like i needed to learn how to dodge, when spamming the weapon you get from chapter 2 forward and healing worked fine. 
Overall the basic gameplay was fun enough to keep me hooked, and there was suprises and mini games along the way to spice things up. 

Now one thing that annoyed me a lot, was the stealth section later in the game... That really wasn't fun, but it was thankfully short. 
Also i really disliked the whole premise of chapter 7. It was really tedious to play and probably my least favorite part of the whole game. Overall after chapter 5 I feel like It takes a slight dip in quality in terms of the gameplay, and It feels like the devs are padding the game and making it longer... 

It was kinda annoying that enemies respawn if you leave a room and come back, so if you get knocked into the transition between rooms by an enemy you have to re-enter and kill everything again.. Doesn't happen that often thankfully and maybe I'm just a doof. Also you can run past most enemies, so it's not a huge deal.

all and all even though i did feel like the game was dragging a bit and it never really peaked after chapter 3-5   it's still kept me going to the end, because i just enjoyed myself despite the things i disliked. I will not spoil the story but I felt like it concluded nicely. 
As mentioned above I really only recommend this game, if you can handle a really slow pace. It's a very solemn and existential game, but it also has a lot of light and funny moments, and heart warming scenes between all the characters.

116430880.review:
Jump in and go on an incredible journey with Sam and John! It reminds of how I got into gaming in the first place... character build up, humour, awesome music (by the composer who worked on Unsung Swan and Death Stranding ) and surprises. Eastward has heart - it reveals biases, daft idiots, the neighbour next door, the dude in the shop, friendship and teamwork. Just a couple hours in and wow I've got that addicting feel again, something not had for a while. Story telling is fantastic, it starts gently then pulls you in bit by bit. John is our next door dude - he's down to earth, says little, supports Sam even when she gets rebellious. He's the dude you can rely on to get things done. After an hour playing Eastward all that crappy stress from work is washed away.  There's some puzzles which get a bit tricky... Hint... learn how to smack bombs cos they'll get you out of difficult places. This is not Doom or CoD (so don't expect to get a dopamine rush or mindless action to chase 1000 points to get a colourful name tag), but more along the lines of jrpg's adventures like Final Fantasy 7 and Chrono Trigger with a Secret of Mana battle system (not as complex though). 
After 15 hours, it's still a chill pill. In another dimension this game could be called a Chilled out journey to the East. There's a bit of a mystery but won't get too deep into it. Like who is Sam? What's happened to the planet? My only gripe is I wish there were more tracks. The few in there are great, but would like each dungeon to offer it's own score.
Anyways, after coming home from work with a buzzing headache, 30 mins of Eastward and it's gone. The end game climaxes s l o w l y. Wish there was a skip chat scene as the conversations become a tad too long. Game difficulty ramps up towards ends and here I say c'est la vie. It's been a ride, a fun ride Eastward.

116410233.review:
Recommended, but barely.

The main draw to this game is definitely its art direction and graphical fidelity. If you like what you see from the trailers, then I'm pleased to say that it remains mostly consistent throughout. The atmosphere and art are really spot on at some points, especially around the middle.

The gameplay is pretty mediocre, a 2d Zelda type experience, with de-emphasised item unlocking and more focus on combat. Puzzles are there, but they're pretty easy. Combat is not particularly sophisticated either. Without story beats,
or a compelling atmosphere it can be a slog to work through a dungeon. There are a few minigames here and there, but you can't do them as you please.

Story is probably the biggest let down. I came in with low expectations, was extremely surprised with how good it was until the middle, where it drops off significantly towards the end.

It was so close to being an amazing game, but as it is, it's pretty good. "pretty good" indie games are a dime a dozen, so the visuals and part of the story are it's saving grace that make it worth experiencing.

116103388.review:
Eastward is a lovely game that captures perfectly the feeling of journey and venturing into the unknown. As a fan of Earthbound, I was looking forward to playing this game since I discovered it.

What I specially like about Eastward are the story and the characters. The story will take you on an emotional journey where you will laugh, cry and be amazed at how extense the world of Eastward is. And both protagonists are lovely: Sam is an energetic, funny girl and John is a calm, silent man. I don't particularly like the choice that John doesn't speak at all in the game, but I was still amazed at how well his character was developed without him speaking. Eastward also shines a lot with the side characters. There a lot of memorable characters with insteresting backstories that you encounter throughout the game.

The game focuses a lot on the story and has a lot, a lot of dialogues. And I also feel like it has some filler that could have been cut from the game to make it a little bit more concise. I don't mind this a lot, because I really enjoyed learning more about the world of Eastward, but it may seem boring to other people that just want to experience the main story of the game. There are some slow parts of the story and some incredible climatic parts.

The gameplay is mainly focused on exploration and puzzles. It isn't something too unique, but I really enjoyed it nonetheless. The puzzles are fun and there are some interesting mechanics in the game. I specially enjoyed that you can swap characters at any time betweem Sam and John and that they both have useful, unique abilities.

Finally, the soundtrack is amazing. I played Eastward almost two months ago and I still listen to some of the songs from the game to this day. I loved the music style of the game.

115008620.review:
Eastward is a lovely game that manages to capture the feeling of adventure that Earthbound had like few others of the many inspired by it. Some people may be turned off by the slow pacing, but I think that the slice-of-life sections enhance the great narrative of a dangerous, dying world seen through the wonder-filled eyes of a young, optimistic girl.

The production value is off the charts, and employed brilliantly. Almost every single NPC (and there are many) not only has a unique set of (beautiful) sprites and animations, but their own personality and substories that make the world feel much more real and cohesive, as well as get you attached to it more. Eastward does not have the best gameplay, settling for a fairly basic if very serviceable Zelda clone with some twists, but oozes so much charm from every single aspect that I never found myself bored. 

Speaking of production value, the pixel art is some of the best I have witnessed in any videogame. Every single location, even the biggest or least important, is adorned with detail, and every NPC is full of personality. Even most of the way into the game I found myself stopping to marvel at the level of detail that went into every single aspect of the art as well as many of the gameplay mechanics. A Dragon Quest spoof that holds a small role in the lore of Eastward's world is entirely playable, quite engaging and filled with its own secrets, there is a Breath of the Wild-inspired cooking system but with dozens of specific recipes, all with their own art and flavor text, and as mentioned before, an incredible amount of NPCs have their own little, unimportant substories that you can follow. Perhaps more importantly, the game is always funny and endearing, and sometimes heartwrenching or thought-provoking. There are some minor issues, like a very annoying stealth mission and a slightly underwhelming penultimate chapter, but the game stays strong for the great majority of its substantial runtime of about 20 hours.

Absolute recommendation for all but the least patient of gamers, which might find themselves a bit frustrated with the pacing of the game.

114996578.review:
Having just finished the game, I really enjoyed my time with Eastward. It's not perfect, but still a charming game, and I'm eager to play whatever Pixpil will put out next.

The game has incredibly detailed and vibrant pixel art, both for the environment and the characters, a great soundtrack and lovable characters throughout. Combat and puzzles are enjoyable, though both stay kind of simple even during the endgame. I still had fun throughout my whole playtime, though I can see how it can get too repetitive for some players. I personally enjoyed the ability to switch between John and Sam during gameplay, and how this affected puzzles.

My personal con would be the games pacing, and the story in the latter third of the game (Story Spoilers: [spoiler] particularly after leaving New Dam City, as I personally didn't enjoy the Monkollywood chapter, and how much additional questions are added to the games mystery during the last 2 chapers, while staying overall pretty vague with the explanations [/spoiler]). The game often throws a multitude of cutscenes at you, only occasionally interrupted by simple fetch quests, followed by more cutscenes. But whenever you get to explore a new area or play through longer gameplay sections, the game really hits it's stride.

If I had to rate the game on a numeric scale, I'd give it a 7-8/10, but depending on how you enjoy the story, and how much of a dealbreaker the rather simple combat is for you.

114905676.review:
This was a gift well-received; a bargain at $20.

It's a pixart action-RPG with immediate charm. Every detail screams "indie passion" right from the intro movie. Gameplay is crisp, everything feels intuitive and the pacing is just right the whole way through. It's the complete JRPG package: engaging mysterious story, silent protagonist with a cooking aptitude, upgrades and ability puzzles, and a deep minigame with a strong presence in the story world.

Favorite feature: almost every save point comes with a lesson in existential philosophy.

Least favorite flaw: The subtitle feature is redundant unless you're learning a second language.

Overall: 9.5/10 - a glitch-free experience that checks all the boxes.

114206076.review:
Okay, so Eastward is generally very good. It does take a lot of inspiration from EarthBound, but mostly just its tone. Mother 3's slogan "strange, funny, heartrending" would probably apply here, somewhat. Mechanically, it's an action game that plays a bit like A Link to the Past. It has Breath of the Wild's cooking minigame, and also an entire game-within-a-game called Earth Born (get it?) that actually plays and looks very much like Dragon Quest.

But enough about what it derives from, let's talk about what Eastward does by itself. Eastward follows the story of a man, John, and his adopted daughter, Sam, who get kicked out of their underground home and have to venture across the ruined surface world. Along the way they stumble on some ancient conspiracy that Sam has some unclear at first link to. And they'll get to meet a lot of people, some good, some bad, but most complicated, and eventually change the world.

The art is gorgeous and the music really slaps. Actually I can't overstate how good the game looks. Finally, an EarthBound inspired game that doesn't look like a Mother 3 romhack, but has its own style. Every nook and cranny is incredibly well detailed, cities are full of life, dungeons are mysterious and foreboding. 

Gameplay involves controlling either John or Sam or both to solve puzzles and defeat enemies. John is your standard action protagonist, and Sam has supportive abilities, and you can switch between the two, and keep them together or even split them up to solve problems like it's Banjo-Tooie. I didn't end up using Sam's abilities too often, it was just more expedient to shotgun my way through most enemy encounters with John. That said, there's cool bosses and plenty of hidden secrets to find if you like exploration.

So, let's talk about the thing most people might find problematic here: this game moves slowly, very slowly. At the time of writing, the any% speedrun world record is slightly over 7 hours long, which is half the time I actually spent finishing the game as a casual player. Granted, I barely touched Earth Born, but still. Most of your time will be spent watching cutscenes, and in a 2D top down game that means reading dialogue. A lot of the plot gets padded by what you could consider filler, which isn't helped by the fact that the "mysterious conspiracy you discover by accident" trope means you only discover the overarching goal when you're almost done with the story, so at many points in the game the narrative feels like it meanders around with no clear objective. 

Just like Mother 3, the story is chapter based, and most chapters involve moving to a new location, which has the side effect of making side quests impossible, since you might not be around later to turn them in (which is probably why they made Earth Born, which serves as basically the one side quest for the whole game).

But of course this all has a point: to make you spend time with the world and its characters. And I felt like that was a worthwhile trade. The game is full of interesting people that you want to learn more about, and it is cool to learn about the communities you visit. But, of course, you might feel different. If you're not a fan of somewhat contemplative character studies, you might come out of this thinking that a quarter of the story could be excised without losing anything meaningful.

One thing the game does not do very well is foreshadowing. By that I mean that the game will pretty much tell you in advance about things that will happen, and is not subtle about it. Whenever some catastrophe happened, I saw it coming. Either my brain is bigger than I thought, or Eastward is a bit too obvious about things. Or maybe that was the whole point. What this mean is that the bits that probably were meant to tug at my heartstrings just fell flat. Hence why I'm not sure "strange, funny, heartrending" fully applies here: it's strange, for sure, and really funny at times, but you can't really render a heart without the element of surprise.

Anyway, I enjoyed it. No matter how fast I would mash through some of the dialogue, I still wanted to power through to see what would happen next to those characters I learned to care about. If that sounds like something you'd like, then give it a shot.

Got this game when it first came out, finally put in the time to finish it. Was drawn into the game from hearing it was a lot like Earthbound (I'll get to this later) and plays like Zelda. 

This game was good on certain aspects:
-GREAT Graphics (Amazing pixel art)
-Good Soundtrack

However, I think there were a lot more parts of the game I did NOT like:
-Back to the Earthbound section, yes there is an Earthbound-like feature (not required for completion) in the game called '''Earthborn.''' That is the only feature that plays like Earthbound. I believe the "Earthbound" side of this game was directed at the plot

113077719.review:
Eastward is very much a story-first, gameplay second type of game, which personally I enjoy but it might not be to everyone's liking.

The main selling point of Eastward is in its beautifully rendered artstyle, which allows for some quite stunning animations, and character/background designs. The story itself is interesting enough, albiet a bit predictable at times. The main duo in John and Sam are captivating and likable enough to keep you invested, as are most of the NPCs you encounter. If you're looking for a story-rich and easy going game with plenty of visual style, I recommend giving Eastward a try.

That said the game does lack in a few places, primarily in the gameplay department. While by no means bad, the core gameplay loop of combat is a bit on the simplistic side, with little variation as the game goes on. And while the story is fine enough to keep you going, pacing does drag a bit at times, often with very long cutscenes and dialogue expositions between relative brief moments of actual gameplay.

Overall Eastward was an enjoyable experience and worth a playthrough, the final act in particular made excellent use of the game's core strengths in visuals and story. My only issue is that as a video game it can be a bit simple and repetitive at times.

7.5/10

[h1]💬First impressions on Eastward[/h1]
A strong presentation is important and Eastward does make a good first impression with its pixel graphics and cartoon artstyle.

Eastward is beautifully crafted, you can feel that everything was created with care and thought put into it, and this is what had me instantly drawn to this game.

[h1]🌟A colorful world:[/h1]
Eastward puts a lot of work into its graphics and every location is rich and full of details and small touches that breathe life into the game. Each region is a sight to behold and even random houses and shops are given a lot of attention.

Most of the cast in this title consists of unique characters with very few examples sharing the same sprites. The game does its best to give every character, even the most minor ones, unique looks and personalities of their own.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2787164462

[h1]🎮A smooth gameplay experience[/h1]
Eastward's gameplay is done from a top-down perspective, or bird's-eye view. It can clock anywhere from 12 to 20 hours depending how slow you want to take it.

Unlike most games of this genre Eastward follows a linear, chapter-based, storyline with little space for exploration and rarely offers sidequests. You move between regions after certain chapters but once you leave one you cannot go back to it. 

While exploration is not the main focus of the game, some chapters feature larger open areas for you to visit and find secrets.

Controls are fluid and work very well. Although a controller is recommended, the Mouse + Keyboard setting works just fine and there weren't any notable issues with it, be it during combat or during puzzle solving.

You also have access to a very simple cooking mini-game, which has a slot machine to get better bonuses, and cooking is one of the best ways to get potent healing items early on.

Lastly there's Earth Born, a side mini-game highly reminiscent of old era RPGs as well.

[h1]👨‍👧Our two heroes[/h1]
During your journey you'll control two characters: John and Sam. Both often travel together and you are able to freely switch between them (once you've gained control of Sam) and there will be times where each character will have to go solo for a while.

John is often used to break things or move heavy objects out of the way. He is also the main fighter of the duo and will be used to kill 99% of enemies you'll face. Sam on the other hand can interact with the environment granting access to more places or dealing with stuff John can't break, however she can't kill the vast majority of enemies on her own.

Puzzles often rely on each of the characters unique aspects, such as John's strength or Sam's power, sometimes requiring constant switching between each to open paths so they can progress. Most of the time the puzzles are fairly simple and don't get too difficult, although some can give you a moment of pause.

[h1]🗡Combat[/h1]
Fighting in Eastward is simple and straightforward: as John you whack things using a frying pan, or blow them up with bombs, or blast them with a ranged weapon. You are able to upgrade John's ranged weapons with gear parts found in chests.

Sam gains a ranged power that can paralyze enemies and leave them vulnerable to John's attacks giving good synergy. She also has access to other (optional) powers, but Sam's role, for the most part, remains firmly on the support side.

Enemies come in a decent variety and you'll fight the small ones, big and beefier ones, and the annoying fast moving ones. All in all, the combat can get pretty intense at times.

There are also boss battles and most of them are well done with a few of them having certain gimmicks, but the game never gives you specific tools to fight bosses and leaves up to you to figure out the best strategy for them.

[h1]🎶An amazing soundtrack by Joel Corelitz[/h1]
Just like any story-driven game, Eastward features a great soundtrack library. The music from the game adds much to the current events of the game and enhances its atmosphere to a greater degree.

Many of the tracks are instrumental in nature, but there's the occasional tune reminiscent of the 8-bit era which, thanks to the ambiance of the game, doesn't feel out of place.

[h1]🌠Play it again, Sam (and John)[/h1]
After you beat the game once you'll gain access to a "Select Chapter" option which amounts to a New Game Plus, allowing you to restart any chapters you desire. This alone can increase the replayability of the game by a good amount.

But some may ask: "What's the point of playing it again?" Maybe to get a chance to replay a part of the game you liked one more time, rewatch a cutscene you wanted again, or fight a boss you liked once more. Or maybe to find those treasure chests you may have missed in your first playthrough.

The interesting part about the Select Chapter is the amount of options given to you: the game allows you to keep your progression (Health and Upgrades), start with a pregenerated save, or start without upgrades.

Games featuring New Game Plus are increasingly rare nowadays, so having one that does it, and does it in such a thoughtful way, is a big plus.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2787167677

[h1]💦Shortcomings:[/h1]
Even though it's a good game, this title has some problems in certain areas.

The story the game tells is fairly predictable and it doesn't have many surprising twists which, for a game that puts such heavy focus on them, is a bit of a let-down. For every moment that you play it's easy to guess what the outcome of a plotline will be or even what will happen to some characters (although the game did shock me more than once).

There's also the feeling that some characters are not fully explored or could've been made more important, held more weight to the story while other characters seemingly have important roles, but end up contributing very little to the plot overall.

Cutscenes sometimes drag on for a while at times, sometimes for too long, and at points where you might be raring to jump into action. There is no option to skip any cutscenes at all here.

While the ambiance is done right, the dungeon design is always very simple, sometimes too simple. There are not many of them that require exploration and many of them are as linear as the game itself.

Speaking of exploration, there is very little of it in the game which is sad, maybe even wasteful, given how well crafted and beautiful the world of Eastward feels.

Puzzles are not the high point either and while there are good ones, especially towards the end, but for the most part they're very simple and never feel too challenging.

Combat itself feels a bit too plain and basic. While John has a fairly decent arsenal at his disposal, Sam's is locked into a single ability as the others take a long time to recharge which makes you feel like you should use them as sparingly as possible.

[h1]💭Final thoughts:[/h1]
Eastward is a charming game and, although a bit rough around the edges in certain places, it never fails to do what it proposes to: it tells a good story, has fluid combat and nice puzzles going for it-- all with great graphics and a fantastic cast of characters.

It's easy to see how much thought and care was put into this game and playing it was wonderful and memorable experience.

It had everything going for it: Beautiful pixel art eye-candy, nice music, very simplistic but fun puzzles, great atmosphere, and for once an RPG that isn't a boring turn based battle system. It's all fine and dandy except for one thing. The story is lack luster. I wouldn't consider it the worst written plot but leaves you filling in the blanks. On the surface level it is great... that's it... just great. Which is kind of a shame because it had so much more potential. An almost masterpiece. Did I enjoy it? Yeah I absolutely did which is all that counts in the end.

If plan on getting all the achievements keep reading:
Most things in the game are missable such as store food, ingredients for cooking, chests, etc. There is NO backtracking once you complete a section/chapter during your first run on the game. luckily for you, after completing the game you have access to  "extras" which allows you to travel back to previous chapters while keeping all the stuff you've earned. Here's the problem: there is NO cut scene skipping. This is a extremely tedious task to do because these cut scenes are sloooow that drag on and on one after another. You'd think that would of been an obvious thing to add to the game but NOPE. Have fun with that! It took me an insane amount of time struggling to remember what chests I was missing and had to constantly hop onto chapters which took forever to get to. There is no checklist for the missing ones so you just have to guess what chapter they're in. So here's a tip: your main priority should be those chests. Look up a guide. Make SURE you get every single chest before moving with the story. Don't be like me and leave it to be the very last thing. Another note, regarding food from stores. They refresh every now and then so keep an eye for any food you haven't eaten yet. Some ingredients and food are chapter locked. There are also cooking recipes that are ingredient specific and so keep that in mind.

112671990.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
  I would not recommend Eastward to players. The gameplay is poorly paced and never rises above OK. The story ranges from OK to bad filler of an anime/tv show. The style and the world are almost worth playing the game despite its issues, but I wish the game was 10 hours shorter.

[h1]Gameplay [/h1]
  You play as both John and Sam as they team up to go on adventures. Using John to melee attack enemies and his bombs to solve puzzles. While Sam gets a ranged stun that doubles for some puzzles. 

  The combat is slow and clunky because your character gets no defensive options, and hit detection is spotty at times. Stunning with Sam then switching to John to kill is never worth it, because enemies recover too quickly. The later weapons feel bad to use, and later enemies charge quickly at you making it so either you have to play defensively or trade hits, both of which make the combat drag.

  Puzzles in the game can be really enjoyable, when they split up your characters so Sam and John are on different parts of the room and have to help each other, it can be really fun. The issue is that most puzzles are not that, and tend to be simple walk around and use your characters ability to progress. In the final dungeon there were a pair of puzzles on right and left which was just using Sam's default attack to get around, the issue was it was the same exact puzzle, but reflected so you did the same "puzzle" twice in a two minute span.

[h1]Story[/h1]
  The story has a huge problem, John is a silent protagonist which can be fine if written well. The issue is that the character never takes an action so I don't know if John cares about any characters outside of Sam. It's always Sam who speaks up for John, so it feels like John is a nothing character that is just there to do gameplay. Later on in the game a character declares their love for John, and I go "why?! You've known him for a day, and he's literally said nothing." After 21 hours with this game, I still don't know who John is and that bothers me considering he was there the whole time.

  The plot itself is OK, but some of the filler was driving me nuts early on. The whole 2nd chapter could be removed, and no one would notice. Later on, you do a fetch quest to get a thing, and right before you hand it in, another character goes "oh, can I have that?" and Sam being the creampuff that she is, just gives it to him. Then we have to do another 2 hours of running around to make up for that. There's not even a good pay off for that, it just felt like a waste of time.

  Others have mentioned it, but later on in the story it gets a bit unhinged/kingdom hearts/legend of zelda timeline levels of magic evil darkness. It makes the later chapters feel cheap, because there never seems like there's any logic behind the "villains." 

End of game spoilers [spoiler] The story claims they are making a greater better humanity and I get the impression that the god figures created let the power go to their head, but they all seem crazy when you meet them so it's hard to say if they were following any sane plan. There's even some story beats that might hint that the world isn't real, but nothing is done with that storywise.  [/spoiler]

[h1]World[/h1]
  The game has style for days, and the locations you go to are both fantastical and grounded at the same time. Seeing new locations was half the fun of the game. The only issue is you spend too long in most areas so the charm wears off.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
  Don't buy. The game play drags, the story drags, and the world while great doesn't make up for it.

112419531.review:
[b]I bought this game a while ago and decided to give a try recently. So here's my review:[/b]

[b]A somewhat good game with a decent story, so I'll still recommend Eastward.
Might want to consider giving this game a chance during a sale.
[u]But make sure this game is for you first.[/u][/b]

Music and the graphics/artstyle of the game are easily the strongest features of this game.
The setting and atmosphere of the game are another strong point. I think I liked every location with the exception of the location on Chapter 6.

Puzzles, which utilized both player-controlled characters were quite decent.

You will spend most of time watching cutscenes or talking to NPCs so be wary of that.

Combat is a little basic and quite easy - I didn't die a single time throughout the entire game.
Even the bosses were so easy that they felt like regular enemies.

You could technically tank all enemies since you have a lot of health and you get so much health from the food you make - you can even pause during combat to consume as much food as you want effectively turning you a god. 

The minor exception is only the boss right before the final boss of the game - that was the only time I felt  nice to not only tank. That specific boss was a lot more decently designed compared to other bosses on the basis that she wouldn't drop dead after 10 seconds. Introduced a cool parry mechanic as well which you would only see again at a portion of the final boss (which was a shame).

Exploring was unfortunately lacking a little as well, because your path was severely restricted, either by natural blocks (e.g. thorny bushes you need to burn later) or by NPCs (Sam: "we cannot go there, we need to go there first, John!").

The slow start on Chapter 1 and the entirety of Chapter 6 also severely kill the pace of the game, the tension really started building up after Chapters 4-5 but then you go on Chapter 6 to do boring minigames.

At least you can skip Chapter 6 after completing the game, since you are given the option to start at specific chapters

Some twists that take place on the final chapters don't make sense, for example [spoiler]how did Isabel know how to merge Charon and Alva, and why does Alva return as a ghost after merging with Charon? Why does Sam even come back to life after Charon is defeated?[/spoiler] 

The game won't give answers to some questions that are raised throughout the story, but this isn't always necessarily bad, for example [spoiler]with the case of Sam[/spoiler]. However, there were cases were an answer to some questions was clearly needed to explain these twists - [spoiler]like the case of Isabel, Charon and Alva[/spoiler] - otherwise these twists feel like they come out of nowhere. To think of a comparison, see how Leila suddenly flies back to the starship after being blown out to space during the Last Jedi. 

It sucks because these could have easily been solved with a few additional cutscenes and/or changes to dialogue, for example [spoiler]Isabel learns about how to merge Alva and Charon from the Mother or from Solomon[/spoiler].

It really felt like there were twists simply for the sake of having twists.

And speaking of having things for the sake of having things, can I also mention that the game will also throw at you random out-of-place and borderline NSFW stuff like [u]stripper outfit you need to retrieve from a brothel to give to a character during a sidequest or a "glory hole" machine on a monkey train of all places...[/u] Yeah.

Still a decent game, but quite a shame as the game clearly had potential to be much much better with a little more time and a little more direction.

112052835.review:
This hits as one of the best Indie and Pixel Games I have every played.
-The beauty and atmosphere is stellar, with such a colorful world and excellent world building, each place visited offering something new, with a retro soundtrack that fits with both the graphics and style to the earlier era of games. 
-Gameplay is quite dynamic and enjoyable, especially when it comes to the creative roster of boss fights, and the various weapons at the player's disposal.   Along with a companion system that is very well done; being able to switch between one and the other on the fly with the push of a bottom, and each with their own traits, making the feeling of taking down an enemy with both of their skills easy to pull off and satisfying when it hits.  That along with how the gameplay can feel like it is changing with each level, while still keeping true to its identity.  Plus the inclusion of a game within a game (if you haven't played it yet, you'll find out) that goes even further to the retro style.
-Finally the story: Oh my god, and anyone who makes the false claim that video games aren't art, need to just stop talking.   I was invested from start to finish.   NO SPOILERS, but the narrative is very well told.  I can't say there isn't a character that wasn't entertaining.  When the emotions hit, they hit hard.  And I got to say, this game probably has one the best silent protagonists, even able to present him with character without ever saying a single word.  While there are some parts that might feel like panning to some, I personally still enjoy them because it introduces more likable characters, while presenting others as very three-dimensional.   Which is probably my personal favorite highlight with the story, how there is an emphasis on characters over plot.

Overall this game is masterpiece in my eyes with how creative the experience (which is something I love) is and I can't actually think of a single complaint.

A Cute and Incredible Game.
I will try to explain what this game has made me feel while playing by parts:

From "better" to "worst" (in my opinion)
[hr][/hr][hr][/hr]   [b]Art, Design and Animations[/b] [hr][/hr] 
Without a doubt the most charming side of this game. The Pixel Art really shows how beautiful this game can be, I really liked every single place that the game shows you, every city really looks lively and maybe possibly real, of course, the animations and little details are also incredible well done and cute (Sam above everithing else).
Also the initial drawed animation is great.

[hr][/hr]   [b]Music and Souns[/b] [hr][/hr]
Another well done thing, the music is immersive when needed and catchy at the right times, and never got tired of listening it. I really recommend searching the ost.
It is quite probable that I will search the music for my phone.

[hr][/hr]   [b]The History[/b] [hr][/hr]
Personally, I liked the history (a bit cliche in some parts) and loved the main characters until the very end.
[spoiler] (made me shed a tear) [/spoiler] 
I'd like to know about how some characters would continue at the end.
Lovable personalities you never get tired of.
I'll add here that it is good [spoiler] and sometimes rewarding [/spoiler] to speak with the people in the cities through the history, there is a lot and I mean a lot of conversations and many of them interesting that will make seem that the npcs actually live their own lives.

[hr][/hr]   [b]Exploration[/b] [hr][/hr]
A little bit lacking in some parts but always rewarding the curiosity of the player, even at the cities.
On the other hand, incredible complex in some points, that will make most of us leave things behind without us knowing.
Classic puzzles.

[hr][/hr]   [b]Combat[/b] [hr][/hr]
In my opinion it is what has the most flaws or at least it is what has least interested me.
The variability of weapons is good, but [spoiler] Sam powers are practically untouched and unused (they're a bit useless, really)[/spoiler], the combat system is... shallow, you try to hit an enemy from a safe position and try to not get touched, and repeat, if you get hit to much, restore HP with the food you cook whenever you want during combat.
Truthly I liked more to speak with people at cities and get immersed in the history and its incredible characters.
[hr][/hr]

I don't know if it's fair to put a number in this artwork. 
But If I have to it will be a [b]8.5 / 10[/b] maybe even a little more.

It is a game that I will surely remember during a lot of time, and I will think that "it was a really good experience and great game".
"Earth Born", Great game inside the game by the way.
I'm hoping to see more fanarts.

110839993.review:
Este es uno de esos juegos que si analizas cada una de sus partes por separado probablemente no te sorprendan algunas de ellas, sin embargo, cuando juntas todo realmente es una aventura en la cual vale la pena embarcarse. La historia creó yo es la mejor parte, siempre te mantiene con ganas de saber que pasara a continuación, desde un comienzo siembra algunas dudas que te llevan a seguir avanzando, todo se ve a través de la perspectiva de una pequeña y podemos observar como lo vería un niño, sin embargo, hay puntos en los que todo se torna realmente serio. Los personajes son muy carismáticos y su forma de ser está muy bien definida y se desarrolla relativamente bien, por lo menos con los principales.
En el apartado artístico lo que más destaca es el hermoso pixelart tan detallado en cada uno de sus coloridos escenarios, la música personalmente no me atrajo mucho en la mayoría de los casos, sin embargo, algunas piezas sí que son muy memorables.
Y dejo el gameplay para el final, ya que es el que menos innova, bebe mucho de la saga de Zelda, donde atravesaremos a lo largo de la historia varias zonas en las que nos abriremos paso entre monstruos, resolviendo algunos acertijos y siempre buscando tesoros ocultos, todo esto con una pequeña variedad de armas y artilugios, aunque es probablemente el apartado menos revolucionario, a lo largo de la aventura no se siente pesado, ya que el diseño de niveles está muy bien realizado.

Actualmente, está en inglés, sin embargo, es un inglés fácil de entender o si lo prefieres puedes esperar a que salga la traducción oficial que ya está confirmada, pero lo que no puedes hacer es perderte esta maravillosa historia.

110824074.review:
If you've never played games like Earthbound, you will love this. Everyone else will sometimes find themselves confronted with outdated stolen ideas from other games and will just want to skip all that boring dialogue, but you can't.
Even then it kept me coming back, because it keeps getting better as you play.
4/5

Pros:
+ Nice sceneries
+ Memorable music
+ Long gameplay
+ Lots of weapons and different mechanics
+ Fun & complex puzzles
+ NPC dialogue/quests feel immersive and tied together well

Cons:
- Towns feel dead, you think you can interact with stuff but most the time you can't.
(Will Sam ever play the damn Arcade she keeps being excited about?)
- Repetitive music
- Unclear level progress and path (often you lose chances to ugprade stuff or take treasure chests)
- Stupid long dialogue with little substance but weak humour
- Often grindy level design (asian influence I prosume)
- Awkward grammar at times like in poorly translated anime (e.g. "I just can't give this game 5 stars IS ALL")
