110615712.review:
Overall great game. The visuals are outstanding if that's not obvious from the trailers. But you should only actually play this if you're a stupid nerd who doesn't mind reading, cause you're gonna be doing that for a good 60% of your playtime.

Gameplay-wise, it's literally Zelda but you play as two characters. The combat's incredibly basic, which isn't a bad thing except that it takes until halfway through the game for the more interesting enemies to show up. Puzzles are pretty straight forward, but satisfying (you won't spend hours stuck in a dungeon confused).

When it comes to the story, it's a plot that I feel like I've seen before, but done pretty well. The main duo is very charming, and the towns you run across each have great purpose in the plot, and are just fun to explore. The only main gripe I have with the story is that I'm not super interested in the main antagonists.

The music's incredible, although I have one pet peeve with it. You'll be listening to a lot of the same upbeat cutscene themes over and over during dialogue. HOWEVER, the town, dungeon, boss, and overall rest of the soundtrack is amazing and really sets the mood they want for the game.

Last thing I want to mention is that this game does a good job with its moments. There're a decent amount of good moments in the game that I'll remember long after having completed it when I think back to it. Although I have some pet peeves with it, Eastward is a beautiful and bittersweet story that I'm not gonna forget.

I wish I had a good, detailed reason why I don't like Eastward, but I think the best I can do is say it gave me a general feeling of walking through molasses. Everything I did felt like it took longer than it had to, got interrupted by more dialogue that wasn't particularly funny or interesting, etc. which was a darn shame because it felt like there was a ton of love put into this game, and a lot of excellent visual and sound design.

But it also felt like the developers didn't trust me to discover it on my own, and instead decided to yank me away from actually playing the game constantly. Of the little over a half hour I played, it felt like most of it was dedicated to getting yanked into extremely slow dialogues(it's all just text, but there's no option, like there would be in a damn SNES RPG or something, to just click once to have the entire text pop out, instead I had to wait for the sloooooooooooooooooooooooow text scroll to get it over with) that I really didn't find myself caring about.

And getting forced into side activities I had no interest in.

Maybe it's just me getting older, but these days I just have such a low tolerance for games that have super-intrusive tutorial sections. Delaying my freedom to actually *play* the game so much just chafes me and leaves me with no real interest in seeing the rest of the game.

109743414.review:
Played from – to: (2022-01-18 – 2022-02-07) – PC controller.
‣ 10/10 – It will all pan out in the end.
‣ Game Audio / Soundtrack - 10/10
‣ Graphics – 10/10
‣ Atmosphere – 10/10
‣ Main Story / Characters – 10/10
‣ Side Activities / Exploration – 10/10
‣ AI – 9/10
‣ Ragdolls / Physics – 10/10
‣ Movement – 8/10
‣ Combat – 8/10
‣ Final notes: It is rare for a game to have so many characters and make them feel unique and interesting. However, I am glad to announce that Eastward nailed it. Well maybe not the monkeys, but anyone else you meet will be great. They have their unique motivations, back stories, and fantastic visual design. Eastward shines in its artwork and carefully crafted facial animations and more. The journey I took with this game was long and very interesting. I won’t deny the story did leave me confused at times, especially when the time concept got introduced, but overall, it was great and really felt outstanding in the pile of 2021 games that I have played. Honestly, as you play the game you see how much love and care the developers put into this. I got nothing but praise for this apart from a few nitpicks here and there. The soundtrack is always fitting and memorable, beautiful even. Food cooking reminded me of Zelda but had its own use and we will leave it at that. My only complaint is the combat. Even if it is a big part of the game, something more puzzle like would’ve suited it more. The last few boss fights really showed how a more pattern-based combat could’ve been more enjoyable even if repetitive. I would have rather had pattern-based combat of some sorts than a one move-based combat. Yes, you have a nice arsenal of tools at your disposal, but in the end it all comes down to John swinging his pan in the same motion repeatedly. In any case, the nice balance between puzzle solving, fighting, and exploring made combat a nice change of pace and the boss fights were great that I am willing to accept the version we have even if I would have loved a dodge button. Overall Eastward is a very interesting game, at first, I had no idea what I had gotten my self into, but the more I played it the more invested I got. At times it felt like a children’s story and at times it rivaled the seriousness of games like God of War.

Eastward is a delightful mix between a classic JRPG and Zelda game. If you're a fan of either Eastward is a no brainer to buy. After following Johm and Sam's adventure to the end I wished I coulf accompany them on more adventures and explore more of their world with them. 

The game certainly feels like it was meant to have more regions/ contents given the animated sequence at the beginning and the fact that some enemies in the late game seem like they belong to different environments. 

The game itself isn't very hard and can be breezed through if you take advantage of food buffs and max out your gun early. It runs about 30 hours long so you get the time for your money. However, there's not much variety for replayability other than intentionally skipping upgrades to make the game harder.

The art and music of the game are incredible and complement each other very well, every environment was unique and fun to explore. 

Overall I'd recommend Eastward to anyone who thinks they may be interested in playing it.

109434392.review:
This overpriced game is graphically sumptuous. Unfortunately, this is its only plus. The rest of the experience is a boring mess, a rambling chaos: 
        1) the plot makes little sense, for multiple reasons, e.g., the characters' motivations for adventuring (repeatedly risking their lives): the protagonist is a mute miner about whom the player knows nothing else nor will learn anything during the game; the co-protagonist/damsel in distress/little helper/daughter/... is a sort of magical creature/messiah/ghost/... with no other reasons apart from an instinctual curiosity for doing what she does and travelling the world; the world itself is as shallow as it can be, reduced to the basic terms both conceptually (nothing is told about it) and practically (your path is traced, rigid and limited); other characters are a mixture of freaks and stereotypes.
        2) the game has no clear identity: it is inspired by classical Nintendo (FC, SFC, GB) RPGs but (as other reviewers also noted) consists mainly of clicking through dialogues, which are nauseatingly lengthy and terribly stupid; there is no need to play the Earth Bound mini-game, despite its being repeatedly mentioned throughout the game and often accessible during it (which is a pity, because merging the two experiences significantly would have given the experience some originality); vast parts of the plot and consequently the level design are incomprehensible/absurd, i.e., inconsistent or not justified enough in relation to the world building and (non-existent) lore, the sort of settings that could only be justified by asserting that the whole thing was just dream or something like that...
        4) Many characters appear inserted wantonly, without finding any sensible justification. This does not impact the main characters for the sad fact that in most occasions they make even less sense. Relationships between characters are childish or utterly nonsensical throughout the game. As other reviewers noted, this is extremely serious a shortcoming for a game whose experience is dialogue-centric.
        5) Dungeons do not make any sense, for the simple fact that they are not supported by any lore and therefore are as absurd as graphically pleasant, with enemies and puzzles as basic in their patterns as nice they are to look at. Gameplay in combat or otherwise hastly phases is not bad but could benefit form a different solution for controlling weapons, because with a mouse (I played with mouse and keyboard) it is too easy to turn towards a wrong direction, thus complicating otherwise pretty smooth encounters. The cooperation between the protagonists to solve part of the puzzles and an almost negligible part of the fights is a plus within this subset of the game experience but nothing so relevant to make me recommend it.
        6) The music is unbearably repetitive and the grunts of the protagonist in combat unpleasant.

As a whole, Eastward can be seen as a sketch of a real game, a demonstration of Pixpil's potential, which has not bloomed yet.

Combat, mediocre.
You click what is essentially two buttons per character. You can't dodge or block, which made me confused on certain fights. In compensation, at least in my sake, hearts are given to you generously. Every other weapon you are given has some sort of problem, especially the bombs.

[spoiler] Puzzle-wise, the floating fire bomb is essentially only needed for one section; plus putting a bomb down on a platform was a pain. Story... eh.

108968788.review:
[quote][h1]Full video review: https://youtu.be/yI0yfjcyVFs
Written review below![/h1][/quote]

I am an absolute sucker for these indie games with beautiful pixel graphics - regardless of what the actual gameplay might be. Sometimes it’s a pleasant surprise, sometimes it's a disappointment and Eastward may be leaning a little too far to one side.

[h2]Overview[/h2]
It’s important to understand what exactly this game is before going into it. Because if you look at the trailer and the screenshots and all that, you might get the impression that this is some sort of Zelda-like action RPG. In reality, it’s more of a visual novel that just happens to have a little bit of Zelda-like action RPG gameplay and some puzzles too.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The gameplay is less “good” and more so just “basic”, without much depth or really anything noteworthy about it. The puzzles are decent enough, but the combat is laughable. You simply hit your one button to swing at things until they are dead. You unlock new weapons as the game goes on, but instead of being better weapons, they’re just more gimmicky and clunky compared to the one you started with.

[h2]Story/Writing[/h2]
The bulk of your time (like 80% or so) is going to be spent reading dialogue and going through the story. As a visual novel fan, I am very used to this approach, but at the same time, that also makes me very susceptible to poor writing and that is unfortunately the case with Eastward.

You get this really cool setting and base plot and then an overall story that moves at glacier pacing and with some of the most overwritten dialogue I have ever seen in the genre. Conversations or scenes that could be cut to just a few lines are instead extended to last for dozens and it’s honestly worse than some of the bloated visual novels I have read.

The entire thing is overwritten and prolonged, with too much unnecessary dialogue, tons of slow panning camera shots dragging out scenes, and a surprising lack of substance given the sheer amount of words used in the game’s conversations.

[h2]Game Loop[/h2]
The game quickly becomes this pattern of: read a bunch of dialogue, go from point a to point b, sometimes engage in combat there, more dialogue, head back to point a, more dialogue, and repeat. This becomes more prominent after you reach chapter three, which has you running to and from a city completing the most mundane of tasks. Unfortunate, because the city also demonstrates one of the game's strengths: its art and music.

[h2]Overall[/h2]
What was once one of my most hyped indie games of the year quickly devolved into a boring loop of barebones combat, running from point a to point b, and so much dialogue that the game could easily be completed in a third of the time if the filler were cut away. Overwritten dialogue and story does not equate to good writing and that’s ultimately what killed the experience for me.

Follow my [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/3215371]Steam Curator Page[/url][/b] for more reviews + videos!

108909546.review:
9/10

Word of warning: this a very text/dialogue heavy game, if you are not into reading long conversations and cutscenes, then this might not be the game for you. For everyone else who was not turned off by this. Read on!

Pros
- Your main melee weapon is a damn FRYING PAN.
- An very unique and colorful take on a world that is trying to turn over a new leaf in the wake of an apocalypse. The world building and presentation always gives off this "hopeful" feeling juxtaposed against seemingly bleak odds.
- A strong and colorful cast of main and supporting characters with distinct perspectives on the current situation of their world. The characters complement the world they live in very well with their "just taking it day by day" kind of attitude that gives off a certain relatable "realness" even though some of them can be downright wacky sometimes with their exposition.
- A heartwarming story that takes a bit of time to get going. I really think the second half of the game after Chapter 3 is where the game's story and world are slowly fleshed out in a satisfying way
- Very focused and phenomenal chiptune soundtrack that sets the mood just right, be that a creepy ominous situation or a very comedic one.
- Fun Zelda inspired levels that has some fun challenges and unique puzzles that aren't all too frustrating head-scratchers.
- Earth Born, the game within the game of Eastward is a welcome, enjoyable, and challenging addition to those who want to get their classic JRPG gears going. Its heavily inspired by the Dragon Quest/Warrior games with a slight time crunch twist and a unique item system represented by pachinko toys you acquire with tokens in Eastward's world. 

Cons
- Aside from my warning at the very beginning, the game's first three chapters are incredibly slow with overly drawn out fetch quests that seem to only exist to pad out the game's length. I've seen and read that this is where people usually drop off which unfortunate since it really gets going in Chapter 4 when the plot starts to pick up the pace and gets more focused. 
- Overall meh and serviceable combat system. Even though I'm given a number of weapons as well as powers, I really only used one or two of them to get me through the entire game with the others sort of feeling like gimmick weapons. Also, I REALLY wished they incorporated a dodge roll system as a majority of enemies in the game just tend to run up to you head on.

Conclusion: a lovely, cute, and heartwarming modern homage to everything we love about classic JRPGs and Classic Japanese Action Adventure Games. Even though it starts off pretty slow and has some questionable pacing, it certainly still paid off seeing it all the way to the end.

108834785.review:
Visuals 10/10
Beautiful high quality pixel graphics with very excellent fluid animations with a very unique and fun art style.  All of the towns and backgrounds have an equal amount of time and attention put into them as well, very beautiful looking game, and the visuals are easily the best part about this game.
Gameplay 9.5/10:
Everything about this games mechanics feels fully fleshed out, bosses and puzzles don't get repetitive and all feel unique and using new ways to use the tools given to you.  The dungeons feel just the right amount of length, I feel like some games dungeons like crosscode for example seem to run way too long (for my patience at least) but these feel the perfect length. The last two boss fights in this game are incredible and honestly I replayed them a couple times bc of how much I loved them. There's also a completely bonus in-game minigame which is a rougelite turnbased rpg that is very fun and I'll probably come back and put a few more runs into even though I've already beat the main game. The only complaint I have about the gameplay is when you and your buddy are traveling as a unit, the back one has a hitbox and can receive damage.  They do walk quite close to you but it's killed me more times than I can count and I personally find it very annoying especially with this games limited movement.
Story 8.5/10:
I think the story in this game is good but I have a couple gripes with it.  Keep in mind these are nitpicks that probably only bother me and you will probably have a better experience than me.  That being said, this is a grade-a, hot steaming example of why I despise the silent protagonist trope.  Sam alleviates this to some degree but the amount of things that happen right in front of John's face and he just sits there and stares. At least animate like some facial expressions man idk.  Like the arc of Isabelle is so good and works so much better for a main character of this story but it's just not the case.  Like I seriously think you can change like 3 story points to replace john with Isabelle as the main character and I like the story aspect like 3 times more.  I can't dock too many points because I think the story is very good otherwise and in the bigger picture a silent protagonist doesn't matter that much but I just find it painfully annoying.  One more thing about the story that includes spoilers, [spoiler]and this is another trope I hope dies along with the characters that are supposed to.  Seriously, why build up that destroying mother would mean that Sam would clearly die too, but then bring her back in the epilogue for no sensible reason, this is how you make me leave a game mad, thats what happened, the ending was so good and impactful and then the epilogue happens and I'm just fuming.  The least your can do is make it ambiguous and not explain how it would make so much sense for her to die. [/spoiler]  Once again this is a very personal opinion and you probably won't have any problem with it yourself.  I know I spent this entire section complaining but the story 90% of the time is good, the characters are charming and entertaining, and it knows how to get serious and hit you hard when it wants to.
Music 8.0/10:
A pretty good all around soundtrack but there are probably only a couple songs I'll come back and add to a playlist, very solid though overall for the game. Some of the 'dialogue' tracks I call them got pretty annoying overtime though as they were used for like every dialogue cutscene maybe just needed something a little more subtle.
Averaging the scores leaves this game with an overall with 9/10 which is quite deserved for this game, definitely would recommend.

108633598.review:
I really did want to like this game as I do enjoy more story oriented games, but ultimately let down as this wasn't a childish game, but a game for children.

    Allow me to explain, a game can be childish and still be enjoyable and fun for everyone. An example of these games would be Undertale, Paper Mario: TTYD, Earthbound, or Wandersong. All of these games can be innocent fun, where both children and adults can enjoy them as there is no need for extremely dark themes or violence for older players to have fun. A game for children however is one where more complex themes or perhaps more dark jokes are avoided, where the characters are as generic as possible and the main plot never rises above the typical good/evil formula.

    I knew going in that Eastward was going to be a bit of a slow burner based on the reviews. I thought that would mean that given time, Eastward would build up to be something more, but when act two hit I knew that it would never be more that what it already showed. When you want into small village, you meet a women you tells you to go meet the mayor. Within 10 minute, she un-ironically attempts to asks you blushing in a dress to go out on a date with the whole town backing her up. Literally the only prior action to this is wacking a couple of pigs with a frying pan. I'm not asking for an intricate high-brow story that defies all pre-conceived expectations with detailed in-depth unique characters, but there is only so low I can set the bar.

    I should also note that, as you already know, the actual gameplay isn't anything to to talk about. You could compare it to classic 2-D Zeldas, but somehow it ends up being even more simplified than that. The puzzles and combat really only serve act as filler between the uninteresting basic story.

    The music can be good though, and I do enjoy the pixel art and animation in particular.

It is not a Zelda game if that is what you are looking for. The game is 70% unskippable cutscenes and dialogue, not good dialogue, mind you; it's the cringy anime-style JRPG dialogue. 

Every time the game gets good, It halts to a stop and forces you to watch the cringiest cutscene. You will be stuck mashing the A button for, no joke, 8 min straight until the cutscene finishes. The characters get so annoying after a few hours. Sam is cute, don't get me wrong, but there's only so much she can do to carry the story. John is the closest thing to a cardboard cutout I have seen in a video game. They tried to give him the silent protagonist treatment but failed to add any nuance to the character. It's a saving grace in disguise since you won't have to listen to more dialogue.

It's a shame. The combat is simple but very fun and the dungeons are great to explore, even with the straightforward puzzles. The pixel art is gorgeous, with beautiful environments and scenery. The game's biggest problem is that instead of telling a story with one sentence, it uses 10. It's almost like a high school student trying to meet the minimum number of words on an essay by adding sentences that add zero value, and its only purpose is to extend the length.

Tbh I loved the game a lot. It took me the 33.2 hours to beat the game, but I enjoyed it from the game play to the story. I read some of the reviews and understand why people were not happy although I think I went into the game without any expectations and thus did not feel any disappointment. While it is true the story can be lacking in areas and end up leaving certain plot points behind for others, I still enjoyed it the whole time. My one con is: they don't fully explain some mechanics. You may learn some here and there, but simple ones I had to google to figure out. So while I don't like games holding my hand, I felt a bit abandoned at points.

108134561.review:
[h1]Like a very colorful sparkling cocktail without flavor[/h1]

While the game offers a [b]nice diverse soundtrack[/b] and [b]extremely well done pixel art style[/b], the core gameplay mechanics are what you could best describe as 'functional'. This usually isn't a problem, but sadly the game fails to deliver in all other areas including characters (development), dialogues and the overall story.

The pacing in Eastward doesn't help either. It starts you off with the right 'adventure vibes' but that starts to fall apart around chapter 4. Although you can't grasp the full story you can't shake off the feeling that you are playing some kind of filler content. I'm not saying that everything in the game amounts to nothing, but the sheer amount of characters that get introduced and dialogues that play out feel extremely bland. You will remember those, not for the unique situations but for how tedious it drags on and on and artificially stretches the time you have to spent to get through the game. Around chapter 6 one thought started to cross my mind quite often: [i]When is this finally over?[/i]

The game takes inspirations from all the right places (90s anime, videogames like Earthbound/Mother 3) but it doesn't help Eastward have its own identity.

Took me around 33 hours finish. You can probably finish it in less if you march through the game and don't look for treasure chests, cooking all recipes or playing Earth Born (retro rpg minigame within the game which was quite fun!). I can't help but feel that the game could've achieved the same (if not more) if it was 20 hours shorter.

The main problem with Eastward is that it's offers a really engaging start only to slowly but surely replace that with most tasks being a hassle to do. It fails to show the player the motivations of many characters and the overall story - though told visually impressive at key moments - leaves a lot to be desired.

108074347.review:
Eastward is... good. I think? Even I'm not sure. Did I like it? I... think so, most of the time anyway. The game starts really strong and that last few hours are great. The last hour is pretty fantastic. But everything in between? Well, it ranges from good, to OK, to kinda bad. Chapter 6 is a particular bruh moment. 

The gameplay is fun. I liked it. It's basically a simpler Link to the Past and that's fine. If you, like me, thought this was an "Earthbound-like" then you, again like me, will be mistaken. To me that's a good thing because I didn't want another "Earthbound-like" (I really mean in terms of combat here).

Music is really great. Nice art and fun animation. It's a good game [i]as a whole[/i] but a lot of the writing, namely the sheer abundance of unimportant dialogue and events, lets it down. However, I think if you enter this game understanding that it's mostly episodic events tied together by something of an over-arching plot, you'll probably have a far better time.

If you understand what you're getting in for, namely one of those "very cutscene and story heavy" games, then you'll be fine. But if you like a greater balance, or the scales tipped in favour of gameplay, or even just a [b]really good[/b] story, then maybe think twice.

108066489.review:
A little over 15 hours into this game and really enjoying it!

[h1]Pros[/h1]
1. [u]The artwork[/u] in this game is absolutely [i]stunning[/i] and can't be overstated. Beautifully rendered environments, buildings, and colors. I'm not usually one who goes for pixel-art games, but there's something truly magical going on here.
2. In the same vein, [u]the music[/u] in Eastward is handled very well.
3. Overall, I'm enjoying [u]the writing[/u] in this game. While there's a deeper narrative going on throughout the background of this game, this game could more accurately be defined by its smaller moments. The simple, character focused storylines and character quests ground this game and give it a certain charm that just makes you smile.
4. As more of a casual player, I enjoyed [u]the relatively simple combat system[/u] displayed here. It isn't overly burdensome, but still allows for enough interesting mechanics and pathways to keep things fresh. 

[h1]Cons[/h1]
1. Although I've enjoyed the combat so far, I can't help but feel [u]this game could have benefited from even more combat throughout[/u] to break up some of the narrative sections of the game. As I said, I'm more of a casual gamer myself, but even so, I found the game to drag significantly towards the middle.
2. That brings me to my last complaint, which I'll basically sum up as [u]issues with the overall length, story, and pacing of the game[/u]. Eastward is a beautiful, charming game with lots to love as a casual gamer. Even so, I definitely felt the burden of this game's slow pacing. I'm about 15 hours in with no real understanding where this story is going or how long it's going to take to get there. Right now, I'm simply meandering from one low-stakes quest to the next with no real signposting of how this fits into the overall structure of the game. While I've enjoyed the simple, slice-of-life stories told through the calmness of the game, it's becoming increasingly difficult to stay focused within the game with no clear goals set before you. If this was 100% a casual game, this could have worked. However, with the sporadic combat and larger narrative moments sprinkled throughout, you're continually reminded that a larger story is going on in the background. You're just not included on what that story is, how it relates to your presence in the game, and when you will actually get back to that story.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Eastward is a joy to see, hear, and play. It harkens back to simpler times in life and puts heavy emphases on the small moments. It's truly something special and I'm glad this game exists with all of the nostalgia it brings. The pacing isn't great and the game struggles to find balance between its overall world story and the intimate moments of the everyday. I think with a slightly tightened up mid-section and perhaps a bit more from the combat/action - this game would have easily risen to one of my all time greats. Overall, definitely worth a play!

108025866.review: Fantastic art design wrapped around an entirely tedious and ultimately disappointing game.

108022179.review:
Eastward is one of those games that I really wish I could give a "neutral" review for, rather than positive or negative. I do like the game, and I'd recommend buying it more than I would avoiding it, but only by a [i]very[/i] small margin. 

This game had some pretty high highs, but it also suffers from having just as low lows in my opinion. There are 8 chapters in total, and while I was having a blast with the first five, the game takes a nose dive at the 6th. I found the actual gameplay passable; Nothing amazing relative to similar games I've played, but its mechanic of swapping between John and Sam, the two main characters, was interesting, and overall actually playing the game was bearable enough to keep me interested in the real meat and potatoes; that being the story, and environment and whatnot.

Without spoiling too much, I absolutely loved chapters 1 through 5. The game was still somewhat challenging at this point, the story was lighthearted fun that was carried mostly by its colorful cast of characters and gorgeous visual, all topped off with a looming sense of mystery, and a desire for answers. I was seriously debating whether or not I should recommend this game or not, but honestly the first two thirds or so of this game were just that pleasant.

Then, of course, comes chapter 6... The best way I can put it is that everything from that point on feels like it was handed off to an entirely different team of writers who had no clue what was going on. The narrative they were going for gets completely abandoned in favor of something else entirely, the mystery is completely forgotten about it seemed, and is just haphazardly explained right before the penultimate boss, and all in all it just seemed like a jumbled mess. It wasn't [i]all[/i] bad, as the few returning characters from chapter 5 and prior were still pretty good, but after waiting so long for this game, it's hard not to be seriously disappointed.

I could absolutely see myself going back to replay it, but only up until chapter 6; at which point, I'd just close the game and pretend I just played a really long demo to a game that never fully came out. Maybe the devs could do better with a sequel, and learn from their mistakes, but for now, that's all I've got to say.

108012730.review:
I have a few mixed feelings about Eastward but overall I feel like the positives outweigh the negatives.

Positives:
-John and Sam make for an adorable team. John's silent protagonist angle works really well coincided with Sam's childlike wonder and curiosity. They have strangely good chemistry despite John never saying a word.
-Art and music direction is beautiful. Some really well done sprite work and the tracks fit all the moods really well.
-Combat feels satisfying, thought a little simple.
-The games highs hit really hard. The emotional beats come through quite nicely.
-Some clever and well written dialogue.
-Once the main cast is established they have solid moments.
-I personally really like the ending. Leaves things a little more open ended than they could have been but in a way that still feels satisfying to the journey.

Negatives:
-Game has some definite pacing issues. Some chapters feel like they needed more exploration and others feel like they drag.
-Some of the side characters fall a little flat and the ones that are developed well wind up not getting used very much.
-The story runs in circles just a little, and takes too long to find its footing. [spoiler] It would have flowed a little better if not for getting stuck in New Dam City for so long compared to the other locations in the game. [/spoiler]

If you're looking for a more story centered RPG, you'll probably enjoy Eastward. There tends to not be a lot of combat so if you're looking for something a little more action packed, you won't find it here. I really hope the devs continue to make games though, because I think if they can push past some of the issues here then they'll have something truly wonderful to share.

107944959.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 22.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realise that.

Thank you

107725768.review:
17个小时通关，说一说对这个游戏的感想。（不包含大地之子）
  从开始一直到大坝的剧情，总共流程的前2/3讲了一个很流畅的故事，废土风、美国末日风格的两人旅途。画面虽然采用了独特的像素风，但通过像素画面表达出来的人物面部表情以及肢体动作非常生动，相比一些大成本制作的游戏，更能感受到人物的感情（说的就是你，剑盾）。在地图美术设计上也很不错，我很喜欢大坝整体的设计风格，还有波特岛那种废品堆成的建筑。
  相应的缺点则是在于作为一款2.5D动作rpg游戏，战斗过于单调，武器强化升级系统缺乏变化，没有人物技能加点，迷宫设计欠缺火候，最终boss甚至变成回合制游戏，导致打完最终boss并没有带给我成就感，反而觉得智商被拉低了。
  但是我认为这款游戏他的强项在于他精美的剧情以及人物刻画。瑕不掩瑜，虽然战斗很拉跨，但直到大坝剧情结束为止我还是玩的非常开心。刻画了很多很可爱的角色，珊，艾娃，杰斯本，伊莎贝拉，力哥，青豆，长老.....
  但是过了猴莱坞之后，进入无限大厦之后，就开始走下坡路。剧情挖的坑没填，前因后果没有讲明白，很多地方的剧情都在结尾没有得到解释，所罗门呢？生命工厂怎样了？珊为什么会变小？为什么会分离？以前的珊是怎样了？为什么红色的珊会那么痛恨人类甚至不断冷嘲热讽？所以整个世界观应该是怎么样？为什么人类会退化至废土时代？很多很多的问题没有得到解答。
  上了卡戒之后的剧情，有点跳脱，很多不相关的剧情展现，比如突入而来的回忆杀却发现要认路，然后突然跳到黑潮的追赶，突然又跳到伊莎贝拉，又突然就打boss，这里面的剧情很多都对解答上面的问题没有帮助反而会带给玩家“我在干嘛？我在哪里？”的挫败感，我进入卡戒之后，就完全是为了通关而通关，缺乏那种前面带给我的探索感。而恰恰这时是作为解答之前埋下的伏笔，达到起承转合的收官之处。处理的不好，很大影响了游戏的体验。
  人物的成长从大坝之后就没有继续，珊在从地底到地面，从一开始的懵懂无知到下定决心，整个人物的成长并没能通过结局表达出来。大坝作为“第一个”地面建筑，让珊下定决心找出真相，一直到这里的成长，我觉得都还行，但之后，却没有进一步的发展下去让人不免感到惋惜。
  无限大厦已经后续的场景美术设计，有很多让人匪夷所思的地方。尤其卡戒里面的关卡，关卡跳跃感十足，各种虚幻的场景让我不知道我在哪里，我认为既然作为废土风的游戏，为啥不全部使用真实感的场景，这样效果也许会更好。
  最后，作为一款讲故事的游戏，剧情是她的顶梁柱，一切场景设计、人物刻画都将辅助其存在。但明显到达游戏后期，这些都没能很好的表现出来。如果只玩到大坝为止，游戏我给9/10分，如果加上后续，只能最多4/10分。推荐大家抱着看剧情的心态，对战斗不报任何希望的去玩，玩完大坝后删掉。那样这还是个不错的游戏。

107414421.review:
Before I say anything, I'm just gonna say it. This game is great. I love it. I won't spoil the ending but it was definitely a phenomenal one.
The pixel art in this game is jaw-droppingly beautiful at ALL times. The music is great. Gameplay is great.
I don't need to say any more about the good aspects of the game. It's just good.

Anyways, that's enough gushing. Onto the few gripes I have with this game. No game is perfect, and eastward definitely has a few flaws.

- The lack of unique music
My biggest gripe is that there is a LOT of reused music. I don't know if I'm just spoiled by games like undertale or what, but I found there to be a severe lack of music in this game. There's 72 songs on the OST, definitely not a number to scoff at, but with a playtime of about 24 to 30 hours, you're going to be hearing a certain few songs a LOT. There's a theme for silly things, evil things, happy things, and these themed songs get reused over and over. It got to the point where I could predict exactly when one was going to play. While this isn't the biggest issue in the world, it really kinda got on my nerves when I heard the same "oh here's some quirky characters! here's the quirky character theme!" music over and over again. For this reason alone I recommend you enjoy this game in chunks. Play a chapter or two, then take a break for a week. This way, the repetitive music won't drive you insane. Now that's not to say the music is bad. Far from it, actually. I LOVE Eastward's soundtrack. I just wish there was more of it to love.

- The Beginning
A lot of people seem to complain about this game's writing. I personally loved most of the writing and it drew me into the game's story, characters, and world; However, the first few chapters are really jarring, and it's not until a few chapters in that you really start to get used to the game. The first few chapters just kinda give you whiplash. They're not bad, they just confused me as a first time player.

- Other small nitpicks
> The way assets in the game are layered makes certain things, such as your weapon, get cut in half sometimes when brushing up against objects. Not a huge thing, but it kinda bugged me a little.

> The cooking mechanic is great. Love it. But the ability to skip the little cutscene that plays after you begin to cook seems to... disappear at random? Sometimes I can skip it, sometimes I can't. There was a section at the very end of the game where not being able to skip the cooking cutscene kinda killed the mood a bit.

- Conclusion
Overall? I think if you like a good pixel indie game, you should play Eastward. It's fun, you get really attached to the characters and the world, and it's just overall a really really good game. While I have some gripes with it, overall it's an extremely polished experience, and if anything I think you should play it just to gawk at the pretty pixel art alone.

8/10. Love this game. Play it.

107298371.review:
This game is a very mixed bag. I'm a big fan of SNES RPGs and pixel art games so that is what immediately drew me to this game and it is still the game's biggest strength. It's great to see what a well-made modern, 2D pixel art game can look like in the modern day. Characters all have interesting designs and are very well animated.

Unfortunately, the gameplay and the story don't live up to the same standards and let the game down. Gameplay is very shallow and basic. Despite looking very much influenced by them, this game is not an RPG. There is no levelling up in the traditional sense and no weapons/armour to buy and equip. The game is entirely linear and things like weapon upgrades are mostly tied to the story. Instead, you just run from screen to screen fighting entirely optional enemies for no real purpose. Outside of a few mandatory fights tied to progression, you can skip combat entirely to no detriment. You might as well, because combat is extremely basic. There are no interesting combos to pull off, almost all enemies can be killed in exactly the same way, and there's no real reward for killing them anyway. Change screens and they all respawn anyway.

The shallow gameplay might be OK if the story was any good, but it raises more questions than it answers. The game introduces plot threads and side characters that never go anywhere and just get forgotten about. I kept playing thinking the game would eventually fill these things in, but it never does. These are some very fundamental questions about major characters too. Questions like: [spoiler]Who is John? What is his relation to Sam? Why was Sam found in Potcrock Isle? Why does Sam just forget major events, like Greenburg? Why has she forgotten who she is (or will be) and why does she have the split red/blue personality thing? Why does William have a robot called Daniel and a real son called Daniel? Why does robot Daniel need an operation? What is the relation between Alva and Isabel? Isabel suggests she was 'made', not born, for a purpose. Why and by who?[/spoiler]. The most the game will do is hint at answers to some of these questions and you have to infer the rest. The problem is, this extends to major antagonists like Solomon and Charon too. Who are they and why do they do what they do?

It's a pretty game but ultimately that's all. I would say it's worth a single playthrough if you enjoy games like Earthbound and other 'quirky' 2D games, but it's missing too much substance to be anything more than OK.

107158693.review: I really wanted to like this game but it never really grabbed me. The actual gameplay is incredibly simple Zelda-esque puzzle dungeons with a neat 2-person switch mechanic. A lot of narrative driven games have weaker gameplay, but the narrative is not up to the task of carrying the game. It shares a lot of themes with Mother 3, which is completely fine, but it's not really delivered well. It's hard to explain something so subjective but the dialogue felt very stiff and unnatural. The characters themselves from what I've played are very one-note, and it doesn't help that the main duo might be the worst part. Having both a gruff silent protagonist and an energetic kid sounds fun, but the former ends up standing there doing nothing most of the time outside of gameplay, and the latter is really overplayed and just has way too much text dedicated to shouting about whatever is currently happening in the story. I get they wanted to show that she's energetic and excitable but there could have seriously been half the amount of text boxes conveying this, or at least balanced it out with dialogue about anything else. From what the other reviews have said it doesn't seem to get much better. I really wanted to like this and I think the dev team could do something great in the future, but 5 hours in I have to call it for this one.

107150542.review:
I enjoyed my time with Eastward but there are some very apparent flaws with the game that make it impossible for me to recommend. I want to give this warning to the people who are considering buying Eastward. If you are looking for a "life changing story" and a "Zelda-like gameplay experience" like some of the reviews are promising then you will probably be disappointed by Eastward.

Spoilers ahead:

Its easy to praise Eastward on some corners. You would be hard pressed to find a person that wouldn't call the visuals beautiful, Sam has a nice energy to her, and the music serves its purpose even though the game could benefit heavily from more tracks. I wont dwell too much on these positives because they have already been stressed more times than you could count in other reviews, just take note that those aspects are there.

The main gameplay of Eastward would make you believe that the game is meant for young teens, I'm not a god gamer and I was almost never at any real risk of dying with the one exception being the epic anime samurai battle vs Isabel. Weirdly enough after this fight comes the final boss in which I only got hit once, The main reason why the game is so easy is it utilizes Breath of the Wild's food system which was one of that games biggest detriments. Since you can eat at any time during battle with no cooldown your healthbar isn't actually how many hearts you have its your number of hearts plus the amount of hearts you can get in total from all the food in your inventory which is an insane amount so getting hit is never really a threat. The puzzles are also very simple, I don't think there was a part in the game where i had to think for more than 10 seconds about what to do. None of this is inherently bad because Eastward is very much a narrative driven game, after all 75% of your time in Eastward will be spent reading dailogue so having easy access gameplay ensures everyone will get to experience the story. The problem with this is that the game depends entirely on the story, an area in which it falls flat.

the first two chapters of the game is strong and a good setup, The people in the potcrock isle think that the outside world is a dark place plagued with maisma and believe in dark god Charon (which is just a train). We as a player and sam as a character who has seen the outside world know that this isn't true and it makes us excited to get out of potcrock isle. The great part is the twist in which the miasma is a real plague and Charon is a real threat. This was a great twist and a good way of getting the player invested in the story and mystery. Unfortunately this is as good as the narrative gets and if you are interested in the mysteries that the story poses you are going to have to wait till the very end..... in which your questions will still not be answered. This is a serious problem in Eastward, it eludes to so many big reveals and that "in time you will understand", makes you wait for the entire chapters 2-7 in which the main story isn't progressed at all and mysteries are just reiterated, and then either very loosely gives you an explanation or doesn't mention it ever again. After playing Eastward i'm still just so confused about what what actually happens that it makes the ending, which tries to be emotional, just feel empty. Sam is explained away as a perfect evolutionary being but lacks everything that that would entail, such as omnipotence and omniscience. Instead she can just use magic? Why does Sam have a second soul bipolar personality living inside her? I understand its suppose to be her from the past but it's very apparent it's an entirely different entity that thinks and acts purely independent of Sam. Why was Sam asleep in a chamber underground in the first place? did she lock herself down there to stop the factories from activating? if that were the case she could you know.... just stop activating the factories. Who even is Solomon? He is very involved with time science but that doesn't really explain why there are three of him at different ages running around and why the keys that they have open the final door in Charon. Isabel is Heavily alluded to being a robot/test tube baby like 3 times and then never mentioned again. what was the cure that Isabel and Alva were searching for to? Why does Sam merging with mother at the very end stop the harvest? Why can Alva just be a ghost???? All of these are questions that I didn't have answered to me playing the game. I can infer possible answers to a couple but they remain pure speculation without concrete evidence. The longer I sat through the ending of Eastward the more and more I feel like it was taking heavy inspiration from the End of Evangelion, there's a lot of similarities to be seen between the two. What made EoE work despite its janky convoluted plot was its interesting characters and themes. Eastward has neither of these things, John is a silent protagonist that just does whatever, Sam is cute but not interesting, Alva and Isabel are somewhat interesting and their conflict resolution is alright but not enough to carry the game. The game almost has no themes or philosophy besides the refrigerator you save at that talks like a 15 year old kid who just read some John Locke and then smoked weed. The game tries to be philosophical and hits towards some deeper meaning but never talks about it.

Eastward wears a lot of its inspiration on its sleeves. Earthbound is the most obvious but I was initially surprised to see just how anime influenced it as well. The most obvious one is Hayao Miyazaki and Studio Ghibli as Miyazaki is a shop keeper in the game but given a different first name. I don't mind media showing off what inspired it and you are allowed to deviate from it but you should still be in the spirit of what is inspiring you. What I'm getting at is it's almost insulting to show off Miyazaki in a game where you add ample amounts of fanservice. The game goes overtly out of its way to add in a bunch of anime horniness whenever it can and It gets weird. At the very least the brothel in New Dam City makes sense, making us retrieve a dominatrix outfit from it is odd but it makes sense in the world. But for the love of god please explain to me why the monkeys have a virtual anime cat girl glory hole machine? like seriously? and out of the three girls that have some importance in the story and aren't 9 why do two of them have to have comically large chest? Ulva is a mature woman so i can see her character design reflecting that but its still out of proportion. And when you see the Alva replicas inside Charon my god they are just massive and for what? it doesn't add any personality to the story or characters and it doesn't serve any theme so why?

Eastward is far from a bad game but i seriously don't know who I could recommend it too. If you wanna play for the gameplay the story takes up too much time. if you want to play for the story the gameplay will be a boring slodge to get through, the non main characters aren't really interesting at all, and nothing really happens till chapter 8. And if you wanna play for both then you will probably be disappointed by aspects of each. The easy gameplay and nature of the story wants you to think its for kids but the off the walls story and "adult" moments makes it seem like its aimed towards an older crowd. 

the most enjoyable time I had in Eastward was playing Earth born, in which I got both endings. I think Earth Born was a great addition to the game however whoever on the development team designed the gull knight fight can perfectly parry my ass.

106749722.review:
A wonderful sort of zelda-like RPG with team-splitting mechanics and an odd but well-merged blend of DNA from lots of other games. There's also a game-within-a-game; a small sort of roguelite take on classic JRPGs called Earth Born tucked away in many of the hub areas.

So far, I think the best way I could sum up both the praises and criticisms of this game is just by saying that it's very Chucklefish. It comes with all of the hallmarks that you'd expect from a Chucklefish game: There's a big focus on gorgeous visual design and animations to the point where the pacing sometimes feels sluggish, similar to how Wargroove could feel frustratingly slow; a lot of the dialogue tries to be that corny sort of charming, and some of it falls flat and feels almost irritating instead; there's a lot of super clear DNA from other games here, but they've managed to merge it very effectively and it doesn't feel out of place.

All things considered, if Eastward just rubs you the wrong way for some reason, you're in no short supply of gripes to bring up. There's definitely plenty of ammunition here if you're looking for reasons not to like it... But they're all kind of minor. It's just that kind of cheesey charm that will grate on you if you let it, but can just as well sweep you up if you want it to.

The gameplay is honestly pretty tight. The main game loop is similar to a 2D Zelda, but it starts to pepper in more mechanics - you can cook ala Breath of the Wild to fill up your inventory with powerful healing and buffs, you get a second character with their own set of skills, and you really start to realize that there's something special here the first time they split the two up and you have to hot-swap between them through a series of puzzles and obstacles to. It feels fantastic to team them up and tackle the split-party puzzles.

Overall, I encourage folks looking for a kind of leisurely paced adventure with a charming and vibrant visual style and setting to pick Eastward up. But if you want something that takes itself a little more seriously, you may want to look elsewhere, or at least hold off until you're in the mood for something that tries to be a bit lighthearted.

UPDATE:
After completing the game, a few more notes...
Most of the original review is relevant for the whole game. Visually, Eastward is gorgeous from start to finish. The music is also excellent - and every time a new song pops up, it's absolutely a banger. Between some stunning graphics and incredible music, you get some truly breathtaking scenes. Where the game is strong, it stays strong! 
Likewise, where it's weak, it stays weak. The dialogue often feels grating, and it's made much worse by *some* characters getting different dialogue when you speak to them a second time, but you always risk getting the same long dialogue a second time instead. Without spoiling too much, there's a later part where this feels *especially* glaring. Honestly, the game needs a skip button for dialogue you've heard before, the same way you can skip the cooking scene if you've made that meal before. It would really help the most major shortcoming Eastward has.
The cooking gets a little stale later on. There's not really much way to find recipes besides rubbing three foods (and a spice) together and seeing if something comes up with a question mark. There's a lot of combinations that are possible from this, and it's hard to justify spending the time to try them all. Further, there's no reminder of what food has what effects, so it feels like best practice to just remember a couple of good ones and stick to them.
Finally, just to address it, a friend had told me that they'd heard Eastward makes fun of fat people, so I tried to keep an eye out for that - but I didn't really see it. It doesn't really make fun of anyone, persay... but many of the characters are absolute caricatures, and a couple veer close to unfortunate, with several fatter characters being probably the most obvious. To be fair, it doesn't feel mean-spirited as much as a choice to give the animations more lively with bigger expressions and interesting body shapes and designs. They don't stand out as visual outliers in a game this eye-catching, and it's never teased or mocked or otherwise treated as a negative thing in the game's dialogue.

106732246.review:
Eastward is an incredible looking game. This showcases some of the best pixel art I have ever seen. Not just environments, but  the animations and even background NPCs. The way they introduced 3D into the mix for lighting and particle effects. The towns are cluttered and the walls are scrawled with graffiti. There's a level of attention to detail here to make the world come to life that is rare, even in the best and most immersive video games.

Unfortunately, nothing else lives up to that standard. Visually, it's stunning. In a good way.
The writing, combat and puzzles are stunning, too. But in a bad way.

A solid 2/3rds of Eastward's story is DBZ-tier filler. The rest of it just doesn't make any sense.
I honestly cannot tell you the theme of this game or what the story is ultimately meant to be about, it's so sorely lacking in any direction.
None of the characters really get a chance to develop because all their major events happen off-screen.
And the dialogue is approaching CAD and Megatokyo levels of word soup that shouldn't be possible.
Maybe it's just lost in translation or cultural differences, because I don't think you can really miss anything major, it's a fairly linear game.

The combat is serviceable, but never evolves as the game goes on. You get multiple different weapons, but you don't need to use any of them specifically to defeat anything. The same goes for Sam. Most of the enemies just mindlessly dash at you, which makes them bomb fodder. The ones that don't, you can usually put them away in two hits with the other weapons.
The boss fights are also pretty much the same. Aside from one or two where you need some timing to beat, they're boring and start to really wear on by their third phase.

The puzzles are basically non-existent. Despite all of the mechanics and different weapons, you solve them all in pretty much the exact same way, just in a different order. Every time. These puzzles easily take up 50% of your gameplay and none of them require even a moderate amount of problem solving. I spent more time waiting for platforms to come back than I did trying to figure out how to beat them.

And honestly, the sad part is there was a solution to all three of these problems.
Just let the other characters join my party!
If they didn't only exist inside cutscenes, I'd be able to get attached to them.
There are mechanics that exist in the game which could be taken advantage of by the other characters in ways that would have made the puzzles and combat much more interesting and fun. It's an absolute missed opportunity because this stuff is already in the game and the characters have the animations already. Would've taken nothing to add.
Like John lifting things Sam can't. What if there was stuff not even John could lift and he needed help?
Huge gaps that you couldn't shoot across. What if someone had a deployable drone that could pick up items/bombs?
Enemies that you can't beat by bludgeoning them with your pan, so you have to enlist the help of someone with a cool sword?
For the sake of spoilers, I won't elaborate more, but there's a wealth of missed opportunities here.

Just having those characters playable in the game would open up the avenue of having to be able to play through those plot critical off-screen events, removing the need for the awful filler arcs and the massive text info dumps that make up the majority of Eastward's run time to boot.

But at the end of it all, I still enjoyed the game. The Earth Born minigame is a lot of fun and pretty high effort as far as minigames go. I didn't encounter a single bug or crash and despite the writing, I still found the world and implied lore interesting enough that I wanted to continue. If for no other reason than to see more of that gorgeous art.
Can't wait to see what PixPil make next.

106582214.review:
If you like a bonkers ride and is patient to read Eastward might be your game, but before you buy it keep this in mind:

* Miscellaneous:
- Game took roughly 25 hours to finish, but there is a reason behind this tough (1).
- Game is half story-driven, half exploratory. Story is linear though and because of this there are missable things.
- But fear not as you complete the game you will be able to replay chapters and such with inheritance from your last gameplay. Which is good as you don't have to replay the game in its entirety just to get missing things.
- There are 8 chapters in total subdivided in subchapters with each having a plethora of quests to get by. They don't follow a recipe tough. So some chapters are specially longer than others. Particularly 3 and 4.

* Pros:
- Pixel art is superb. There is so much detail put into every single aspect of the game.
- Animation is also superb at some points (if it was done with the same engine as the actual game).
- Characterization is also superb. Every single extra is so detailed to an annoying point (1).
- Music-wise is also superb. Particularly the entry song.
- Gameplay mechanics are reminiscent of old games like Seiken Densetsu 3, Secret of Mana/Evermore with a few unique aspects. But WASD with mouse aim pretty much sums it up.
- You play as two characters (Sam and John) switching back and forth depending on the challenge/puzzle. You are also able to "detach" from each other to cover a wider range of action/area. If that makes sense. With this in mind you can actually perform combos if you're quick enough, but don't expect this to be always true as this is not a focus of the mechanics sadly.
- Puzzle-wise the game has plenty and they're actually pretty good with a good variety. Some puzzle requires you to detach. Other requires you to switch back and forth. You have hidden puzzles and time attack puzzles mixing these aspects.
- Skill-wise John and Sam can be regarded as the warrior and mage/cleric. You will pick up upgrades and new "skills" as you go in the story. 
- Boss-wise this game is superb in the challenge aspect. Good variety and excellent mechanics for each of them. There are also a lot of mini bosses around.

* Cons:
- Up to chapter 5 the story is a roller coaster of emotions, but it feels logical although rushed. Chapter 6 onwards is just "What the fuck?! Why?" all around. Not bad, but it kinda breaks the mood of the previous chapters. Chapter 6 is particularly ridiculous tbh with no actual reason to be there.
- (1) Being half story driven the game puts a lot of time into dialogues and "cutscenes". This is not bad if the dialogues and animation weren't so f'ing slow. Even if you speed up the text to fastest you can still feel you're growing old and fading away reading the HUGE amount of dialogues the game has. Also since the game is extremely detailed every extra has a lot of dialogues too. Some are good some as bad, but if you're that kind of player that likes to click every NPC in game expect to age and die. Remember the 25 hours put into the game? I'd say 15 hours is only dialogues + animations. 
- The story had so much potential, but by the end I felt relief beating the game. The script is not bad, but its not good either. The ending was not quite impactful as you'd expect from this game. Taking into consideration the other aspects of pros and cons I'd say they lost a huge chance for an epic story.

106257982.review:
In a world where society hides underground is the unlikely duo of John and Sam. John is a no nonsense hard worker who lets his actions do his speaking, and Sam is a strange girl that John found and rescued, and has now been raised as his own. The unlikely pair are about to start on an adventure that no one saw coming. In Eastward the world is more than it seems, and it will take John and Sam to determine what that world will end up being.

I have to admit I had no idea what I was getting myself into when I started playing this game. All I heard was that if I liked old-school action RPGs with some quirks sprinkled in, I was going to like this game. Judging by putting in over 21 hours into the game, I think this game was indeed right up my alley. There’s plenty of substance to this game. You have a very unique story that seems to slightly mirror an old school TV show and video game favorite of the kids. There are weapons to gain, skills to learn, obstacles to be overcome, and that’s not even including the cooking portion of the game. That’s right folks, there’s a very odd, yet interesting cooking piece to the game. The food you create can give you stat boosts, or perhaps it is something that someone, somewhere in the game, is craving. There are several different locales that you’ll get to traverse, and there are several characters that you’ll befriend, and/or have to deal with. The story woven throughout the game definitely has its gut punch moments, and there’s also a good amount of twists and turns that will keep you guessing.

The combat is real time, and there will be parts where you’ll want to switch quickly between John and Sam, in order to deal the pain. You’ll also need to switch between characters rapidly during some of the puzzles that you’ll have to face off against. This also includes one of my least favorite puzzle types, timed puzzles. There’s nothing quite like being a second or two too long and having to redo an entire sequence that leaves you pulling out your hair. Now that’s not to say that at any time I was ready to throw in the towel, but I will admit that I did have to take a few “time outs” and walk around a bit if I failed to complete the puzzle in the allotted time. 

This game was just so unique to me. The story was bizarre, the characters you interacted with were sometimes beyond strange, but there was just something about this game that made me keep going. I literally couldn’t stop playing this game. I needed to know what was going to happen next, what new twist was going to change the flow of the game, or perhaps how I felt about certain characters. This is a good game, when the credits hit I was sad, but I was also satisfied with the ending.

106257384.review:
Full disclaimer: I haven’t actually beaten the game yet, but I have gotten further than… 82% of players at time of posting. I intended to write this up as I played, up to the game’s conclusion, and I do kind of want to see how it ends to see if any of the narrative payoff is worth it. But I have to force myself to launch the game, there are days or even weeks in between sessions. So I offer this to you now, to perhaps save someone from buying it.

Ahem.

Prior to its release, I was hoping Eastward would come out swinging in the leagues of Undertale, LISA, and Omori. An Earthbound-like game with lots of color and weird people and enemies to encounter. It is technically that, but it doesn’t hit nearly as hard as the big players. The biggest reason for this is the game’s writing.

The game stars John, a bedraggled man who does not speak (except for when he inexplicably does), acting as caretaker to the ever precocious young girl, Sam. John can cook and can hit things real hard, Sam is adorable and is.. magic? The game actively strives to not explain this, or have other characters even acknowledge it, for quite a long time despite it being the central plot.

The original version of this review recounted the problems with the story bit by bit as I played it, but there were so many minor and side events that don’t matter at all to the story that I eventually had to just cut all the fat. So here is the condensed version- Most characters are just there until they aren’t, and are victims of a weak, poorly-paced overarching narrative. The writers decided certain things need to happen and so the characters are there to enact those things or see (and rarely appropriately react) to them happening. There’s a strange rollercoaster of moods that doesn’t snap hard enough to really register as tonal whiplash, and the pacing and sense of stakes suffer for it.

There’s.. a lot of things I could go on about. John’s complete lack of agency, the utter fumbling of Sam’s backstory, Jasper’s character in its entirety (seriously I hate Jasper for so many reasons, and I'm not alone because I know someone who might have straight up stopped playing because of how much they dislike him). Threatening or enacting pointless deaths for no reason because the narrative demands a weightless tragedy that it’ll forget about in five minutes. A few bits of random anime horniness. The pacing of the dialogue (and by extension cutscenes) is on the slower side and the writing isn’t good enough to warrant it, and across a game this long it adds up to a lot of frustration. There’s multiple very obvious plot points and the characters absolutely refuse to engage in them for the sake of a “twist” later. There’s a game within a game that is constantly brought up in the first Chapter, and is kinda mentioned as a background element in later ones, but doesn’t really have any weight or meaning to its inclusion until Chapter 7. Save points are fridges with talking screens, each with its own Deep Message that means nothing at all. Minimal to no backtracking means the various new tools you get carry less weight and if you miss any resources they’re gone forever.

I originally thought the game was going to focus on the journey, being named after a cardinal direction. (This is NOT why it’s called Eastward, by the way.) I pictured going on a long trek as John while he escorts little Sam to a vague destination. A cuter version of Last of Us. Then I learned about Earth Born, the ingame media giant, and thought it was going to focus on that, considering how much the kids talked about it in the beginning and gaining the ability to play it is one of the first things you do. The eventual payoff takes so long to come to fruition and ultimately it’s just.. there. They made a mediocre game inside their mediocre game. It’s another symptom of the team having a lot of ideas and little direction. For a game named.. Yeah.

The artwork in this game is absolutely phenomenal, its some of the best pixel art I've seen in any game. The backgrounds and environments are AMAZING. The characters as well are extremely detailed with very expressive and interesting personalities. Those are my pros for the game. The cons are pretty big though. I'd say for the 11 hours I played only 2 hours of that was actual gameplay. This game is cutscene HEAVY. There's always a cutscene around every corner and some of them last a LONG time. And if I WASN'T watching a cutscene the rest of my time was spent walking around, which I wouldn't call gameplay. I found my self just not that interested in most of them and it made me bored. another one of the cons is that the combat isn't very engaging and I felt that having to switch between both characters to perform any sort of combo was clunky. Overall I'd say, while this game has a lot of charm and clearly a lot of visual effort put into it, there's probably something better you could be playing. As I'm writing this I'm thinking back on the story and I hate that I don't know how it ends. who knows whether or not I'll go back to finish it. I don't like giving this game a negative review (I wish I could just select 'mixed') because I don't think it's a terrible, it's just not something for me.

Edit:
I came back to the review because I remembered so more things I liked and disliked about the game.

One more thing that I like about the game is the cooking. It's very charming and I think it was a very cute and unique way of doing cooking in a video game.

One more thing that I disliked was an aspect of the combat; there are no health bars. John has a few different types of weapons that he can use, and each type does different amounts of damage depending on the enemy type. But because the game doesn't have health bars you don't know how you're supposed to go about doing certain boss fights. There was one fight that I remember where I was using one weapon the whole time. it was taking me a really long time and because of that i eventually died. The second time I tried the boss fight I switched weapons and killed it EASILY. if there was a health bar that indicated the amounts of damage I would've gone, "ah, this isn't doing a lot of damage, let me switch to something else."

Another thing that confused me was the gun/shotgun that you get. I could not tell how far the range on it was whatsoever. I thought it was going to be a direct upgrade from the frying pan, more range and more damage, but I would sometimes be point blank with an enemy and deal ZERO DAMAGE. it's frustrating. The combat in this game is not great.

106015434.review: [i]Eastward[/i] is an absolute masterpiece! The pixel art is stunning, with a beautiful blend of vibrant colors, retro style, and modern high resolution. The soundtrack is phenomenal, emphasizing the intense, action-packed sequences or supporting the calm, but emotionally-charged segments. The combat is varied enough that it doesn't overstay its welcome; evolving slowly throughout the game and providing you with enough options to be comfortable with a favorite style by the end. The art style draws heavily from [i]Earthbound[/i] and [i]Studio Ghibli[/i], and it does them proud. The story is as charming as you'd expect, given its inspirations, and is worth every moment you spend with it. Don't miss out on this delight, especially if you enjoy similar games such as [i]Earthbound[/i], [i]Omori[/i], and [i]Undertale[/i].
