105942068.review:
I really wanted to like this game, but it just doesn't cut it for me. Here are my thoughts:

Music: 10/10. This game has incredible music! Seriously, you should check it out.

Art: 10/10. The world is vibrant, interesting, and uses pixel art in a way that feels modern. 

Gameplay: 5/10. The gameplay is very average. It's not very exciting, but not the worst thing ever.

Story: 4/10.  The story in this game feels like it was written by separate people. Parts of it are really good, and others are really terrible. Unfortunately, the overall story is not very good. It's so confusing that even the official wiki doesn't know what happened. 

Final Thoughts: If you play a game for music and atmosphere alone, you'll really enjoy this game. If you care about gameplay or story, you'll only be disappointed.

105914258.review:
It's an awful pity, but I feel like I'd just be giving the game a pass solely off the aesthetic if I gave this thing a thumbs up.
I've got four major gripes with this game:
Story 
Characters, Christ Almighty...
Combat
Exploration
To start off, this game's story and dialogue is just so goddamn [i] boring [/i]. I won't go into much detail because this game is primarily plot driven (which ultimately is why I chose to thumbs down this game) and fairly linear, but the plot is pretty generic which by itself isn't really an issue (the plot holes out the wazoo certainly are, but the story as a whole is such a mess you just sorta stop caring after the first 2 or 3). You'd be hard pressed to find a story, whether in game or book format, that didn't take SOME inspiration from something already done. However, what helps is to give it engaging aspects to make up for predictability or staleness of the story. Like say... Characters! Something this game claims to have a colorful assortment of! Buuuuut they're all generic as hell too, or just completely boring, underdeveloped and honestly? I blame the dialogue. The dialogue is pretty damn basic it's the type of dialogue you want a faster text speed for and for a story driven game, that's a problem. The most colorful thing about really any of the cast are their designs. The characters are either gone too quick to really get attached to them, boring as ever loving hell (which was the vast majority of them), or are just weird stereotypes hoping to come off as quirky.

Beware, a spoiler teeming character rant ahead:
[spoiler] Okay, I gotta rant about the main four or 'supposed' main four (I don't really see why the two lesbians were considered main characters on the main website when we interacted with them just about as much as we did Lee or the deadbeat Dad, William). John is the first one of two characters we play as and is categorized as a silent protagonist, which gets acknowledged. Alot. Like, we get it. He doesn't say anything. Now silent protagonists are fine, but when they heavily incorporated into the dialogue? It's probably a good idea to make them at least expressive when they're being talked to, and maybe even have them interact with items with personalized comments if you're feeling spicy. The point is to give the man some personality since you don't want us to get to know him through dialogue. Now, the game lured me into a false sense of security in making me think that we'd get John's thoughts on things as we progressed through the story, but nah that first bit after you leave the first major area? That's it. That isn't happening again. All John's has left in him are overused victory poses and head scratches for the rest of the game. 
Now next is Sam... She's mostly just a giant plot device and the central mouthpiece since John doesn't say shit. I wanted to like her. I really, really did. And for the first 10-15 minutes, I think I did! And then I didn't, lol. I dunno man, the pep thing was cute when she was fresh eyed learning about basic shit, but the corniness of the friendship spiels and borderline anime dialogue... I was getting tired of her really quick by Chapter 3 or 4. To the point, I felt nothing when she died (and I wish games would just commit to killing off a main character, you really didn't have to bring her back it really didn't do anything for the ending).
Okay, next is Lesbian 1 (also known as Alva, but I'm sticking with Lesbian 1) who is a short one. She's the pink haired princess/inventor/guardian of the 3rd major area's town... as you can see alot going on there. Now her personality? She can be summed up in about 4-5 things:
the more likable lesbian
lee's sister (I think adopted... Lee was raised by Lesbian 1's granddad along with her so I'mma just assume sibling relationship which isn't important, BUT I actually FELT something for Lee when I realized he didn't even know she was dead and was now on his own with the town.)
bad cook
good inventor
There ain't much to her, frankly. They try to play the whole cute, contradicting trope of this girl being a super genius whose in charge while also acting like a bumbling, albeit very nice, fool with huge tits (they put a weird amount of focus in her tits when they're visible, fuck me there's this one scene toward the end of the game that had me wheezing cause of that, look up Isabella's fight) for quirk's sake. It's not a big deal, and I'll take her over the Lesbian 2 any day.
Okay... time for Lesbian 2 (a.k.a weeaboo dyke, a.k.a dog killer, a.k.a corpsenapper, and a.k.a Isabelle) whom is Lesbian 1's girlfriend. There isn't much to cover about Lesbian 2 either. Main thing I'd say is that she has the disposition of drying paint... very possessive and overprotective drying paint. Plot-wise she's considered very powerful, but this is poorly shown because our fight with Lesbian 2 is probably the quickest bossfight in the game (though for some reason we don't dome her like we do literally everyone else). Her most noticeable traits include her big 'ol weeaboo sword and her inability to give a shit about anyone else aside from her girlfriend (which would be fine, but when you knowingly do it at the expense of everyone else's life well... let's just say I don't find it to be tragically romantic). Oh, and she killed Lee's dog when they were younger... for some reason. It came too close to her waifu or something, despite her knowing the dog. And then the writers try to damage control that whiplash comment by having Lee tell us, 'she gave the most sincere apology'. 
Considering what she does at the end of the game, yeah, I'mma say cap on that one, Lee.

P.S. In case anyone is feeling uppity about me labeling them Lesbian 1 and Lesbian 2, I'd like to elaborate a tad on why I did that. You see, the game's story puts... quite a bit of focus on this particular relationship. Why? Who knows, but I do know that when you have two fairly unmemorable characters having significant limelight as well as their relationship, well, you may wanna make them more memorable, or the relationship is all they end up being.

P.S.P.S. Also can we have a moment of silence for Jasper's potential character development just thrown to the curve? You already did him dirty with that design, but the minute you open up a event for him to develop off of... we're done with him. You made me endure his clownery for 30-40 minutes and then when potential rears its head, you go "nah, just throw him with the background NPCs". 
For-shame.
 [/spoiler]

Combat... sucks. I wish I was just whining, but I don't think aiming my weapons with a game-pad should be as irritating as it is. Hitboxes can be choppy, like a miss looking as if it should've connected. Enemies are something of a respawning free-for-all. I guess they're that way to try and force you to utilize Sam's stun (because outside plot devices and two-man puzzles she's fairly useless) instead of just giving us a damn dodge button. Bosses... are nothing to write home about. They had a good thing going with the first one where they had you utilizing bombs to make it vulnerable to attacks... and then they stopped that trend almost immediately and instead you steamroll till like the last 2 bosses. Speaking of those 2, they introduced timing your attacks to 'clash' at the very end of the game. It would've been a nice mechanic to do for mini-bosses instead of spawnwaves.

Exploration was such a missed opportunity man. This one actually makes me sad because of how beautiful the environments look, but there isn't much point to them. There aren't any lore based secrets hiding around or new gear. The best you'll come across is some game currency (salt), heart orb piece (think LOZ's heart pieces), or 'gears' which are a required material to upgrade your weapons. The linear environment doesn't even have much to interact with.
Okay, tangent over. I'm more than happy to answer any questions since it's the least I could do after such a long tangent.

105888117.review:
[h1]I gave this game a recommendation, but I feel myself reaching for the other button...[/h1]

This is the most visually detailed game I have ever seen. It's genuinely incredibly beautiful: the character designs are interesting, all the animations are alive, it all just looks very pretty. Gameplay-wise - it's not repetitive, but it's not great either, a solid 3/5. 

[b] My main problem is with the dialogues, as well as the story. [/b]

Now, I know this game is not natively in english. It might be the rough translation, poor choice of words, but I don't really feel like that's the issue. Most of the time the dialogues feel incredibly dry, and don't give much character. The animations do a far greater job at that.
 
Then there's the story. If you expect it to explain the majority of the details - you could not be more wrong. A lot of things are left unexplained, and it really makes me mad. I am the type of guy to read the lore notes in games, but there are none. All you're getting is the most basic explanation of what's happening. Also, sometimes things just happen, without you realizing what exactly is going on - don't get me wrong, it can be done really well (for example, Katana Zero), but this is, unfortunately, not the case. Characters like to speak in riddles, but the riddles don't make sense. They're just there to make it sound more important. Some reactions, also, may not be very believable. 

One last thing that put me off a little bit - the enemy designs.
Sometimes they don't feel like they really fit in some areas. But I am willing to overlook that - it's all incredibly animated.

[h1] Overall [/h1]
Give this a try for the animations and the soundtrack alone.

I just WANT to love this game, and some part of me already does, but I just can't fully embrace it. How I wish it was done a little different.

3/5

105409404.review:
This is a good game that is just on the very cusp of being an all time great game- if not a classic.

It's rare to see games coming out that manage to evoke the feelings of older experimental and rare properties like Earthbound, but Pixpil have managed to touch on that vein and strike it very hard with the world of Eastward. 

Gameplay was fun and offered a decent amount of challenge- Evoking the control schemes of Top-Down Zelda titles mixed with a bit of Secret Of Mana's combat as well. Involving the use of weapons and abilities to dispatch the variety of enemies and puzzles that are littered throughout. Weapons always felt good, even if some were more useful than others. I found myself defaulting to the Frying Pan and Bang-Bang Gun when I played- As those two covered most of what I needed when playing. I never felt particularly overwhelmed by the combat challenges. Bosses were fun and cleverly designed- And you are never long without options to fight whatever comes at you. With John's Arsenal and Sam's psionic abilities. While Sam did get reduced to being more of a stun option and puzzle solver- Her abilities did come into play when they were needed.


The story has strong beats. It starts off like RPGs of old, with the discovery of something of the wider world and the exile from the home village- Eastward starts off strong with a intoduction to the world that John and Sam live in. You see a myriad of beautiful spritework and music- Despite how dreary and down Potcrock Isle is meant to be. As the story picks up, the game's tone becomes apparent. A funny adventure that is willing to make some dire turns. And it's a strong start that continues until the half-way point.

The story begins to wane after this. Becoming a series of distractions that, while fun and do engage the player, aren't going to feel as connected or as important. Some parts left me rather frustrated, especially when the story does pick right back up, only to hit a very hard wall. And this repeats from the half-way point on. Sadly leaving the story with a number of loose ends and potential that was not quite reached. 

Despite all of this- I could not help but to see the good of this game. It's flawed. It's repetative- Very obviously padding itself out by making the player re-visit places they've been again and again and reusing resources a lot. But it's a game with heart. It's got that spark that you have to stop and appreciate. 

I want to see more from this world. The ending left me in a place similar to Mother 3's ending. But nowhere near as satisfied. And if I can't see more from the world of Eastward, then I'd love to see more from Pixpil. If this is just them getting their feet wet in the world of games- Then experiencing them at their full stride will be something remarkable.

104759658.review:
I do recommend this game, but with a warning: Be ready to put your brain in a jar and forget everything you know about logic, character development and continuity. Because, by god, the story is so goddamn weak.
Don't get me wrong, you will get engaged in that up to certain point. But after a while, and this won't take long, you will start to notice that the writer had too many ideas and decided to use every single one of them instead of filtering what would fit his game the most. Problem is, more than half of those ideas don't go too well with the world, the story, or the characters. I can't get into too many details, but without spoiling it, and I won't spoil a thing.
Then again, the pixel art in this game is astonishing, the music is chill so good, the gameplay is fluid and easy to get around. You even have a whole rogue-lite game inside the game. The game is fun to play. But for real, it would be better if I didn't talk with a single NPC and didn't try to follow up the story, that ruined it all for me.

I will probably come around and update this review later to explain in better words about the plot itself, but after finishing the game, I just don't want to think too much about the story.

104214020.review:
Eastward is a difficult game to review, on the one hand the game if full of charm and fantastic attention to detail both in its visual style and its wonderfully retro yet modern sounding soundtrack by Joel Corelitz. On the other sits some fairly bland gameplay with some bizarre design choices. It is a game that I feel some nostalgia for despite the fact that it is undeniably a modern video game. 

The games story starts out incredibly strong with a tightly knit set of core characters and connections as well as a decent dose of mystery and sinister overtones surrounding the Town. However, it is not too long before you begin to set out on a journey literally to the east. Unfortunately (no spoilers though) the quality of the story begins to dip and slows down considerably over the course of the game, only to begin to throw things at you in the last couple of chapters and then come to an abrupt stop. It is because of the strong start and well written characters that it makes the low points of this games story even more obvious. (and In some cases fairly nonsensical moments, fellow players of this game would be likely familiar with what I am talking about.) 

Gameplay wise it is a fairly straightforward action combat game with few weapon choices (which are a bit too clumsy to swap between) and the occasional fairly easy puzzle solving sections. Generally, it is nothing to really write home about and it usually didn’t get in the way of my enjoyment of the game, however as you near the end it becomes more and more apparent that instead of your power really increasing of the mechanics being built on top of in a logical progression, they instead change over time to be different rather than innovating on what was already there. Why new mechanics where being introduced as late as the last chapters is beyond me but they don’t build on existing ones and therefore are a little confusing at first and feel out of place. Another awkward moment is a forced stealth section that has very little margin for error and some frustratingly placed checkpoints.

With all of this being said I still recommend Eastward, the games visual style and soundtrack alone deserve praise and it is still a thoroughly enjoyable experience despite its flaws. I will continue to watch this developer (Pixpil) with interest in their future projects

104169225.review:
A Link To The Past is one of my favourite games of all time.  And it’s not just being viewed through the rose tinted glasses of nostalgia.  Firing up my SNES mini recently I found it to be every bit as good as I remembered.  The pixel artwork, the soundtrack, the open world design (and the sense of freedom it gave the player) and the dungeon design are all still excellent and it seems crazy to me that the game recently turned 30 as it holds up so well today.  

So when a game draws favourable comparisons to Zelda, it piques my interest and I saw a couple of reviews compare Eastward to that series, among others.  Just looking at the screenshots you can see why, the pixel artwork, and top down view, the colourful world design.  But are those comparisons justified?

Well yes and no.  First up, it’s very slow to start, the starting area isn't particularly colourful and its pretty exposition heavy.  And this is a recurring theme through the game.  There is a lot of running backwards and forwards just to talk to characters, which can get a bit tiresome.  The game really shines when it lets you off the leash to explore, to solve puzzles and get into combat (which does feel very Link-To-The-Past-like) so being dragged into yet more plot exposition just makes you long for the next time you can get out there and play again.

The pixel art and animation is first rate.  It must be some of the best I’ve ever seen and once you’re beyond the starting areas muted palette the game really pops with colour and atmosphere.  The music is incredible and Joel Corelitz has created a soundtrack that will stay with you long after you finish the game.

The story itself is pretty good, if not exactly original, with some very likeable characters. I felt pretty strong Final Fantasy VII vibes and there were a couple of moments where I felt it was trying hard (and succeeding, to a degree) to elicit the same emotional responses as Square’s masterpiece.  But the game is fairly linear, unlike LTTP, and there isn’t much to do in the main world beyond follow the main plot thread.  It also seems to lose its way a bit towards the end.  The intrigue that had built up in the first two acts didn’t get a satisfactory pay off in the third for me.  Perhaps I just wasn’t paying close enough attention but I thought there was too much left unexplained.

There is quite a neat game-within-a-game Earth Born.  I tried it once and thought it was a cool distraction but since there doesn’t seem to be any way to save progress within this sub game I didn’t really go back.  The cooking sub game was also really fun with you trying to discover new recipes by combining various ingredients you can find on your journey.

Overall I’d recommend Eastward, even if I did think the Zelda comparisons could only be made at a fairly superficial level.  To be honest the game it most reminded me of was Chrono-Trigger, which is no bad thing!  I enjoyed the time I spent in its world.  I’d just caveat the recommendation with the note that you’ll just need a lot of patience with the dialogue heavy sections.

103942365.review:
Admittedly the game has some weaknesses: 
- most dialogs go on noticeably longer than they would have been in SNES RPGs like Earthbound or Final Fantasy VI; they are in my opinion well written and witty, so no doubt this would have been perfect for a (graphic) novel or an animated series, but in the format of a retro game the amount of text often seems a tad too much. 
- the action battle system is similar to Legend of Zelda: A Link To The Past but for some reason it feels a bit wonky; personally I think this is because a lot of games with a similar battle system incorporate some means of active defending against enemy attacks like a dodge roll or dash (one example from SNES times would be Terranigma; some examples for pixel art games with a top down-perspective and melee combat from recent years would be Hyper Light Drifter, Titan Souls, CrossCode) which I think would allow for a more dynamic back and forth during encounters with regular enemies and bosses 

On the plus side this game has one of the most beautiful pixel art which I have seen so far in games and a ton of animations for the huge cast of great looking characters. I was also amazed by the awesome hand-drawn opening animation of the game. 

As I personally did like all characters and was invested in the story with its mysteries, so that the long dialogs were not that much of an issue for me, I give this game a thumbs up and can recommend it to all pixel art enthusiasts.

103668222.review:
This one of those games I had my eyes on for a LONG time, ever since it was announced years ago.

Eastward brings back that love of games that are similar to The Legend of Zelda that was on the original NES.

Though it can take some getting use to, the controls are simple once you memorize them.

Even though I haven't gotten far, there is so much of the world to look at and explore.

Where the game shines is the story, the characters and the music.

The story has plenty of drama, suspense, mystery and humor. It's slow burning but it is easy to follow and can keep ya hooked even if it starts to lose your grip on it.

There are so many diverse and quirky characters in this story, I feel like you won't see two characters that are a like.

And the music. OH LORD THE MUSIC. Ear candy. Buy the OST when you get the chance.

Don't let this diamond be forgotten.
